talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Quarrying at Exit Cave
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, noting the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee concludes that `even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values', respectfully call upon the Federal Government to take all necessary measures to prevent further quarrying at Exit Cave.

petition.title: Constitutional Monarchy
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

petition.para: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

para.tab: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

petition.para: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

para.tab: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

petition.title: National Flag
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
petition.para: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: National Flag
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Women and Work
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) That Australia has one of the most highly sex segregated workforces of any OECD country;
(2) That after nine years of Labor Government, women on average still earn only 83 per cent of equivalent male wages;
(3) That women suffer disproportionately from unemployment, making up 75 per cent of discouraged job seekers;
(4) That inflexible working hours and a lack of sufficient childcare facilities are detrimental to women in the workforce;
(5) That the economic platforms of both the Government and the Opposition fail to address these gender issues adequately.

Wherefore your Petitioners request that the parliament should recognise the significance of these facts, immediately take appropriate action to remedy the disadvantages suffered by women in economic life, and ensure that the power to make economic decisions affecting women is placed in women's hands.

petition.title: Nuclear Waste in Urban Areas
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) That exposure to radiation causes cancer, leukemia, and death;
(2) That the storage of radioactive wastes near urban areas risks the health of residents;
(3) That the Land and Environment Court of NSW has declared that the present storage of radioactive waste at Lucas Heights is illegal;
(4) That a Bill before the Senate seeks to remove all State restrictions on the storage of radioactive waste at this site.

Wherefore your Petitioners request that the Senate reject the
Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill, 1992
, and that the Senate take action to prevent the storage of radioactive waste in any populated area.

para.tab:
Motion (by

speech.speaker: McMullan Sen R.F.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.para:
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The speech read as follows
—

speech.para: As honourable senators would be aware, the Government is committed to the ratification of International Labour Organisation (ILO) Conventions which are suitable for Australian conditions. Ratification of appropriate ILO Conventions is desirable because:
it supports and strengthens domestic policy and program initiatives;
it confirms and maintains Australia's adherence to international labour standards, with consequent benefits for workers and employers;
it lends credibility and authority to our international standing on labour, social and broader human relations matters;
it underlines our support for the ILO; and
it promotes higher labour standards in the Asian and Pacific region.

So far the Australian Government has ratified 51 ILO Conventions. In May 1991 the Government established an Interdepartmental Task Force to review some 75 unratified Conventions with a view to determining their suitability for ratification and increasing the number of Conventions ratified by Australia.
The amendments set out in this Bill arise from that initiative.

As a general rule Australia does not ratify a Convention until law and practice in all relevant jurisdictions complies with the requirements of the Convention. The Bill proposes amendments to the Migration Act 1958 and the Navigation Act 1912 which will bring Australian law into conformity with a further two Conventions, No. 108, Seafarers' Identity Documents, 1958 and No. 73, Medical Examination (Seafarers) 1946. The proposed amendments will also enable further progress to be made towards achieving compliance with Convention No. 147, Merchant Shipping (Minimum Standards), 1976.

Peak employer and union bodies, through the National Labour Consultative Council, have endorsed the suitability of Convention Nos 73, 108 and 147 to Australian conditions and the desirability of their ratification.

Amendments to the Migration Act are contained in Part 2 of the Bill and are designed to bring Australian law into compliance with the requirements of Convention No. 108, Seafarers' Identity Documents, 1958.

This Convention has been examined by the ILO Conventions Task Force, in conjunction with the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and has been classified as a suitable Convention for ratification by Australia. The Convention is one that is solely within the competence of the Commonwealth Government and does not require any action by the States and Territories to achieve compliance with its provisions.

Convention No. 108 deals with the issue and recognition of seafarers' identity documents by the appropriate authority in each country. It also specifies that the documents shall remain in the seafarer's possession at all times.

The existing provisions of the Migration Act comply with the terms of the Convention in relation to the issue and recognition of seafarers' identity documents. However, the Act currently specifies that a seafarer's identity document is to be held by the master of the vessel or the officer in charge of a resources or sea installation.

The amendments to the Act are designed to bring Australian law into full compliance with the Convention by providing that a seafarer's identity document is to remain in his/her possession at all times.

Amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 are contained in Part 3 of the Bill. They are intended to facilitate the ratification of ILO Convention No. 73, Medical Examination (Seafarers), 1946 and to establish substantial equivalence with Article 5 of Convention No. 68, Food and Catering (Ships Crews), 1946.

Convention No. 73 applies to sea-going ships and provides that seafarers shall not be employed on a vessel to which the Convention applies unless each seafarer holds a certificate attesting to his/her fitness for the work at sea for which that person is employed.

Most sea-going ships in Australian waters are engaged in inter-state or overseas voyages. They thereby come within Commonwealth jurisdiction and are covered by the provisions of the Navigation Act. A small number of sea-going ships, however, fall within the jurisdiction of a State or Territory.

The proposed amendment, which has been developed in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory, will enable regulations and orders to be made under the Navigation Act to give effect to the Convention in respect of all sea-going ships in Australian waters. The Bill provides that such orders and regulations will not, however, apply to the extent that any existing or future law of a State or the Northern Territory gives effect to the Convention.

The second of the proposed amendments to the Navigation Act will amend sections 117 and 118 to enable Australia to establish substantial equivalence with Article 5 of Convention No. 68, Food and Catering (Ships Crews), 1946. This is required if Australia is to ratify Convention No. 147, Merchant Shipping (Minimum Standards), 1976. Convention No. 147 is the principal ILO Convention dealing with maritime labour matters.

Convention No. 147, amongst other things, provides that compliance or substantial equivalence must be established with the Conventions or Articles of Conventions specified in the Appendix to that Convention. Article 5 of Convention No. 68 is specified in that Appendix.
The proposed amendments will ensure that a ship is carrying water of suitable quantity and quality and also food of suitable quality, quantity, nutritive value and variety for the crew of a vessel.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

The speeches read as follows
—

para.emphasis: HEALTH INSURANCE (QUALITY ASSURANCE CONFIDENTIALITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

speech.para: It is generally accepted that health care consumers can suffer adverse outcomes from health services. Some of these are known and accepted risks of procedures and treatments, even when these procedures and treatments are expertly performed. However, sometimes adverse patient outcomes are attributable to poor quality of patient care.

While little direct data on the incidence or causes of adverse patient outcomes are available in Australia, United States data suggest that approximately four per cent of all hospital admissions result in avoidable adverse outcomes not associated with the patient's original condition. Four per cent of all hospital admissions in Australia could translate into approximately 170,000 patients per year with avoidable adverse outcomes.

Effective quality assurance is an important way of reducing the incidence of adverse patient outcomes. It is a positive approach to the reduction of adverse patient outcomes. It can be achieved by providing funds for initiatives and studies which identify problem areas, by encouraging activities to address such problems, and by providing appropriate legislative protection for quality assurance activities so that health professionals feel able to participate. The Government has provided some seminal funding for quality assurance activities in this year's Budget. This legislation seeks to provide the statutory protective framework for quality assurance activities.
Quality Assurance Activities

Quality assurance embraces a wide range of activities. These include: hospital based peer review processes, such as clinical audits into surgical mortality rates; academic studies into the incidence or causes of adverse patient outcomes; peer committees to counsel or assist other practitioners who are having difficulties which may lead to adverse patient outcomes; and the performance evaluation of individual health care professionals for the purpose of determining the clinical privileges of that professional.

There is widespread support amongst medical practitioners and consumers for open, positive and voluntary participation in such activities to prevent adverse patient outcomes and raise the quality of health care delivery. In terms of outcome, quality assurance activities are the embodiment of the phrase prevention is better than cure".

In the past these activities have been inhibited by the fear of health professionals that information generated by quality assurance activities may be used by patients in personal injury litigation. In addition, there is a fear held by health care professionals who participate in any peer review activities which can affect another practitioner's practising rights, that that colleague may sue the participants if they are dissatisfied with the outcome.

A number of States and Territories have introduced legislation to address these concerns and this Bill is based on current legislation in New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory. However, the existing States and Territory legislation will not prevent actions under Commonwealth legislation or in courts exercising Federal jurisdiction to subpoena material created solely for the purpose of quality assurance activities. This Bill also provides protection for national projects and studies which are undertaken by the Medical Colleges or other professional associations across all or a number of States and Territories.

This Bill will promote the undertaking of a range of quality assurance activities by providing statutory protection in the form of confidentiality of quality assurance information and immunity to quality assurance activities and committees which are declared by the Minister.

The Government recognises that conferring confidentiality and immunity on the activities of a particular group of professionals has the capacity to affect individual rights and interests. For this reason, a number of checks and balances have been built into the Bill.

In summary, activities will only be declared under the Bill on the application of those carrying out the activity and after the Minister has satisfied himself or herself that among other things, it is in the public interest to provide the protection. The Minister's declaration will be by way of a disallowable instrument and so will be subject to Parliamentary scrutiny.

In circumstances where information gained by a quality assurance activity may relate to a serious criminal offence, the Minister may authorise the disclosure of the information for law enforcement, Royal Commissions or other prescribed purposes.

Further, before members of committees established for the purposes of evaluating the services provided by other health care professionals will be entitled to the protection of immunity from suit, their participation will have to have been in good faith. The Bill will not provide immunity in relation to proceedings for the breach of the laws of procedural fairness, thus providing balancing protection for affected health care professionals.
Confidentiality

The confidentiality provisions of this legislation will only make confidential, information which is created solely for the purposes of quality assurance activities. It will not make secret, information which is generated in the ordinary course of health care, such as hospital records. It will also permit disclosure of non-identifying and aggregated information—an important factor in promoting the educational and practical use of information obtained.
Disclosure of Information

This Bill prohibits the disclosure of information which has been created solely for the purpose of authorised quality assurance activities and studies, and which may identify individuals directly or indirectly, unless all those concerned consent to the disclosure.
Statutory Immunity

This legislation also provides statutory immunity to members of authorised committees carrying out quality assurance activities such as credentialling. This will hopefully encourage high quality health care professionals to participate in these activities without fear of suit. At the same time, it is important that the person whose conduct is being assessed is treated in accordance with the principles of procedural fairness throughout these quality assurance activities. These provisions again seek to balance these competing interests in a manner that is broadly acceptable to the community.
A Complementary Approach
A co-operative approach is integral to the success of quality assurance activities. This legislation embraces this concept by complementing the existing State and Territory laws.
Conclusion

This legislation is intended to encourage quality assurance activities and responsible activities such as credentialling in a very direct way. Many doctors have indicated to the Government their strong concern for improving the quality of health care and reducing the number of adverse patient outcomes. This Bill provides the protective framework to foster these activities for the benefit of the whole community.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

I am pleased to be able to move the introduction of an important piece of legislation that amends the Health Insurance Act 1973 and will build upon the foundations of the best health care system Australia has ever seen.
Medicare was established by this Government in 1984 and fulfils three major functions:
Medicare guarantees access to public hospital services provided by the States and Territories to all eligible Australians;
Medicare guarantees access to services provided by medical practitioners and optometrists;
and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which is the third leg of Medicare provides access to essential pharmaceuticals.
This bill is concerned with the first of these health care functions, that is, continued provision of public hospital and other public health services to Australian residents.

While a solid health care foundation has been laid this Government is not content to stand still. We want to ensure that there is some national policy consistency and momentum on important issues such as improving public patient access to hospital services and improving the planning, efficiency and delivery of public hospital services.

The National Health Strategy has set the direction for reform and identified the challenges we have to face. We know that the projected population change will mean increased demand for health services into the next century and that technological change often brings more expensive medical interventions. The National Health Strategy has also identified the impressive efficiency gains our public hospital system has achieved over the last ten years and ways to improve those gains by developing better waiting list management, better hospital budgeting by identifying and comparing treatment costs and through improved integration of community and hospital care.

This Bill is the vehicle for maintaining the impetus for hospital reform. It will establish the framework for the Commonwealth/State Medicare Agreements and provide a special appropriation to guarantee funding certainty to State and Territory Governments over the next five years. The money to be provided under the Agreements will fund hospital reform initiatives across Australia in co-operation with the States and Territories.

This Bill and through it, the Medicare Agreements, offer scope to make public hospital services stronger, to tie in assured funding for five years and provide incentive money to kick start reform pilots in all aspects of hospital planning, management and service delivery.
The Commonwealth has two objectives for the legislation.
First, we intend to provide a funding guarantee to the States and Territories for the five year life of the Medicare Agreement from 1 July 1993 to 30 June 1998.

Second, our objective is to enshrine the Medicare Principles and associated Commitments in Commonwealth legislation. The Principles and Commitments have been developed in consultation with the States and the wording reflects State suggestions. While the Principles focus on the provision of public hospital services to eligible persons, it is acknowledged that they operate in an environment where eligible people have the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance.

Nonetheless, the Principles are centred on public hospital provision for public patients, since their purpose is to articulate the reasons for Commonwealth funding of State hospital services. The Principles are:
Principle 1: Eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients.
Principle 2: Access to public hospital services is to be on the basis of clinical need.
Principle 3: To the maximum practicable extent, a State will ensure the provision of public hospital services equitably to all eligible persons, regardless of their geographical location.

The Principles articulate the concepts of choice, equity and access in public hospital service delivery. They give expression to the security that every Australian resident is looking for in their public hospital system and the reason that our health system is so much better than other nations.

The Bill also outlines the broad conditions for funding that will apply in the Medicare Agreements. The most fundamental of these is that receipt of funds is conditional upon signature of the Medicare Agreements. These conditions include taking steps towards passage of State and Territory legislation that is complementary to the Commonwealth Bill and which enshrine the Medicare Principles and Commitments. Under the Medicare Agreement both levels of government will undertake to implement the Principles and Commitments.

The Commonwealth does not expect the States to implement the Principles and Commitments alone, but to recognise that both levels of government have an interest and duty to maintain our public hospital services and to ensure that public patients get the most comprehensive and fairest health service possible.

Part of this provision involves the delivery of information to eligible public patients. This is reflected in Commitment One which requires the joint Commonwealth and State development of a Public Patients' Hospital Charter. The Commonwealth's vision for such a charter is that it will be a `plain English' guide to what Australian residents can reasonably expect as a public hospital patient.

The Commonwealth does recognise that immediate passage of complementary State and Territory legislation may not be possible in some States, despite the best endeavours of governments. It is for this reason that the Bill allows some scope for definition in the Agreements of what constitutes reasonable efforts towards adoption of the Principles and Commitments in legislation.

Commitment Two encompasses efficiency and quality in public hospital service delivery. This is one of the priorities of the Bill and Medicare Agreements and will be supported by the incentive package reforms. These reforms include continuing the development and implementation of Casemix systems in hospital service delivery, ensuring elective surgery for public patients is organised efficiently and fairly, and investigating with the States and Territories better ways of developing capital strategic plans for hospitals and providing hospital services that meet local area needs.

We will not achieve this level of reform without the States and Territories. Improvement in our public hospital services involves Commonwealth and State and Territory commitment of effort and money. The Commonwealth is providing a funding increase of approximately seven percent over the base hospital funding grants to make our public hospital services more efficient and effective. This legislation will demonstrate to the Australian public that both levels of government are committed to excellence in health care.

At the same time, we recognise that circumstances differ in each State, and in the bilateral negotiations taking place, the outcome of which will be reflected in the Agreements, we are responding positively to the particular circumstances of each State, within the overall framework of the Principles and Commitments. The Bill provides for this flexibility. It allows for flexibility and consultation on the Agreement and it allows for consultation with the States and Territories on the timetable for implementing components of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

I am pleased to be able to speak in support of this legislation. The Bill before the Senate will provide a statutory basis to enhance the arrangements for Commonwealth involvement in activities and programs related to natural resources management. The primary objective of this Bill is to encourage the efficient, sustainable and equitable management of the nation's natural resources.

The Bill will bring within the one piece of legislation the authority for the Commonwealth to develop integrated approaches to land, water and associated vegetation management issues with community groups, the States and Territories and other organisations. In effect, this legislation captures, in many respects, the `putting into practice' of some central aspects of ecologically sustainable development.

The legislation is the means by which the Commonwealth will continue to provide funding for Australia's Landcare groups. The impressive growth of the Landcare movement, with the active support of both farm and conservation groups, is evidence of the increasing acceptance by members of local communities of their role in helping to overcome land degradation and to develop and adopt more sustainable resource management practices. Landcare groups now number over 1300, a dramatic rise from the 76 such groups in 1985. Estimated membership is now over 39,000 or about 30% of Australia's farm population. In recent years a growing proportion of Commonwealth funding has gone to support Landcare groups because we have recognised that community-based action by resource users is an increasingly important and effective means of dealing with land degradation problems.Since taking up the portfolio, the Minister has met many enthusiastic landcare group members from around Australia.

Last year when concerns were put to the Minister about the diversity and complexity of government programs, and their lack of integration, he decided to merge the Government's land, water and related vegetation programs administered by his Department. The Minister was concerned that individual programs did not recognise sufficiently the linkages between these resources and between the industries and communities that use and depend on them.

Accordingly the Minister circulated in April of this year a Discussion Paper outlining his proposals for the future direction of natural resource management programs and foreshadowing this legislation. This paper was circulated widely among key stakeholder groups and the comments received indicated wide support for a more integrated approach to natural resource management. The integration of these programs within a sustainable natural resources management package provides another element to the National Landcare Program that the Minister established earlier this year with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to improve access and assessment arrangements and bring a more integrated approach to land, water and vegetation management programs administered by their portfolios.

In addition, the Minister recently obtained the agreement of his State colleagues to amalgamate three Ministerial Councils, for Agriculture, Water Resources and Soil Conservation, to bring a more integrated focus to our consideration of policy issues.

This Government has demonstrated a major, long-term commitment to improvement in the management of the nation's natural resources. For example it has committed $320 million to landcare and related tree planting and remnant vegetation conservation during the Decade of Landcare. In this year's Budget the Minister obtained $77 million for landcare and related sustainable natural resource management activities including the Federal Water Resources Assistance Program.

This legislation will repeal two Acts under which financial assistance for soil conservation and water resource programs has been provided—the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 and the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978. The programs that were conducted under these Acts have made a significant contribution to the national soil conservation effort and improvement in the management of Australia's water resources.

In particular, the National Soil Conservation Program introduced by this Government in 1983 has been crucial to the successful growth of the Landcare movement and the bringing together of production and conservation interests to achieve more sustainable land use. Through the Federal Water Resources Assistance Program, we have shifted the emphasis from resource development towards resource management, focussing on issues such as more efficient use of water resources, comprehensive floodplain management and improved water quality.

This Bill will establish the authority for the Commonwealth to enter into agreements with the States and Territories and members of the community to pursue activities that can address the major issues such as land degradation and water quality that action under these Acts and programs sought to independently address.

This legislation will allow programs to be developed more in accordance with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. These have been enunciated by the Government, reported on by the Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) Working Groups and further publicised in the draft ESD National Strategy.

Agreements under the Bill between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories are to be developed as Partnership Agreements. These will constitute a formal expression of Commonwealth/ State/Territory agreements on a shared list of priority strategic outcomes and on the package of complementary initiatives to achieve them. The Agreements will include details of the manner in which assistance will be provided for community landcare projects in each State or Territory.

As well as establishing the objectives and intended outcomes of natural resource management strategies the agreements will set out the conditions of financial assistance and establish the respective contributions by the partners. These contributions may include commitments to joint funding of activities, contributions in kind and may extend to commitments to policy reform in areas such as institutional arrangements and resource pricing.

The Partnership Agreements will also establish monitoring, evaluation and review arrangements for agreed strategies. This is a significant aspect of the Partnership Agreement approach. It ensures strategies and programs of activities are assessed in terms of their effectiveness and against their strategic objectives. It also provides information on which future strategies and activities can be modelled.
It is intended that agreements negotiated under this legislation would commence in the 1993-94 financial year with the level of assistance determined in the Budget process for that year.

The Bill will also authorise agreements with other persons, bodies, authorities, institutions and organisations that would not be parties to Partnership Agreements with States but who have the capacity to develop and implement programs and projects to achieve natural resource management objectives. Organisations in this category could include research institutes, the CSIRO and other Commonwealth research bodies and major non government organisations undertaking projects of national significance.

Payments for activities conducted by these agencies are to be made from a Natural Resources Management Fund which will replace the National Soil Conservation Program Fund established under the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985. This will give the flexibility required to fund activities that for a variety of reasons, including financial or seasonal, do not coincide with the Commonwealth's Budget cycle.

The Bill establishes the basic conditions of financial assistance and the means by which the Commonwealth can ensure that financial assistance is used efficiently and for the intended purposes. Further details of financial assistance and how it is to be provided will be contained in agreements and include details of financial and project reporting and acquittal of advances.

The Bill will allow for the establishment of the National Landcare Advisory Committee to provide advice on national issues, strategic directions and policy priorities to be addressed in the National Landcare Program and provide the means through which community views on landcare related issues can be provided to Government.

Membership of the Committee will be comprised of community and government representatives. It is the intention of both the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and the Minister, as Ministers responsible for administration of the various components of the National Landcare Program, that non-government representatives including the Chairperson, will form the majority of the Committee's membership. This reflects the growing importance of community-based action for the successful implementation of many natural resource management and nature conservation programs and initiatives.

This arrangement is consistent with the general balance of representation on the State and Territory committees that have been assembled throughout Australia to provide initial assessment of projects for National Landcare Program assistance.

The intention is for the National Landcare Advisory Committee to be chaired by an independent person with standing in natural resources management or a related field. Other members of the Committee will be drawn from groups involved in or affected by natural resources management and will include representatives and individuals from the farming community, conservation organisations, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and other community-based representatives with experience in or knowledge of natural resources management and representatives from the three spheres of government. Because of the interest of my colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, in the activities of the National Landcare Advisory Committee, the Minister will consult with her on matters concerning the operation of the Committee.

The transitional provisions in the legislation are to ensure that reporting and auditing obligations to the Commonwealth for projects, entered into under agreements within the legislation to be repealed, are observed.

This legislation underlines the Government's continuing commitment to achieving better outcomes from the use of the nation's water, soil and related vegetation resources. It is a demonstration of the Government's commitment to the goals of ecologically sustainable development in trying to better integrate decision making and policies affecting not only Australia's agricultural sector but the natural resources related to that sector.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum.

para.tab:
That the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Medicare Agreements Bill 1992 be listed together on the
Notice Paper
as an order of the day.

debate.title:
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1992-93
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1992-93
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1992-93

para.tab:
Consideration resumed from 10 November, on motion by
Senator Robert Ray
:
That the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

talk.start.para: —When the Committee adjourned last night, it was considering a non-program specific item in relation to grants to the ACTU and so on.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen R.

talk.start.para:
—I refer to an item on the ACTU teaching program in China and the efforts of APHEDA to improve and assist the education programs in China. In relation to that, I ask Senator Evans whether he could tell us how, according to a newspaper report this morning, his efforts in a recent visit would assist the education programs in China and the relations between Australia and China. The report to which I am referring appeared this morning in the
Herald-Sun
and is headed, `Evans in a stew over puppies jibe'. The key items in the article read:

speech.para: The Foreign Affairs Minister, Senator Evans, last night moved to quell a potential diplomatic controversy over his comment that China's supreme leader "eats four puppies a day".

para.tab:
But yesterday's
South China Morning Post
reported Senator Evans lampooning elements of China's Government.
The paper also quoted Senator Evans as describing the British Governor in Hong Kong, Mr Chris Patten, as being pre-occupied with the loss of his dog.

Senator Evans was in Hong Kong for talks with Mr Patten at a time when tensions between British and Chinese authorities are high over the direction of the British territory which will be handed over to China in 1997.

speech.para: I should like Senator Evans to confirm whether this comment of his is correct:

para.tab: "The Governor's dog is probably a supreme delicacy," the newspaper quoted Senator Evans as telling reporters.
"They'll turn it into hors d'oeuvres for (China's supreme leader) Deng Xiaoping who, I'm told, eats four puppies a day."

speech.para: Could Senator Evans explain how that sort of comment appearing in the newspaper improves relations between Australia and China; how his rather tasteless jibe to Mr Patten improves relations between Australia and Britain; and whether he has decided to apologise to both those people who were the brunt of his rather tasteless sense of humour.

talk.start.para: —Before I call the Minister, I think that in a skilful way Senator Kemp may have wound this into the non-program specific item in front of us, but it will need a lot more skill to continue in that vein.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I heartily endorse that comment, Mr Chairman. It has absolutely nothing to do with anything in the Appropriations, but it will give me the opportunity to respond quickly to set this particular piece of nonsense at rest.

para.tab:
The story that came out from Hong Kong from the
South China Morning Post
was really a grotesque and irresponsible piece of misreporting. The conversation reported by the journalist was a totally off-the-record piece of banter exchanged with journalists in a drinks session following a press conference.

talk.start.para: —Oh!

—Let me explain the context. I noticed while we were engaged in this chatter that the journalist in question was holding out a tape recorder. I said to him directly and immediately, `For God's sake, this is just off-the-record banter. Under no circumstances should this be reported'. And he did that in a complete breach of faith.

para.tab: The situation, very simply, was this: I was most unhappy to hear from one of the Governor's staff members while I was waiting to go into the interview that a puppy belonging to the Governor's family had been lost the night before. A great deal of scouring of the neighbourhood had gone on to find it. The first thing I expressed to the Governor when I went in there, in a spirit of sympathetic solidarity—because I know very well what the impact of such a loss would be on my own family—was condolences about it. I did so again at the end of the meeting.

That was as far as my exchange with the Governor went. It is totally absurd to say that he was preoccupied with that to the extent of conducting the affairs of state or that this in any way dominated the conversation. That was the extent of the exchange with the Governor. I remain sympathetic to that. It is not an issue which any dog owner or dog lover or member of a family that has dogs that they cherish would treat in other than a sympathetic way.

When the conversation arose with the journalist in question, in the context which I have just described, I just happened to mention in passing that the Governor's dog had been lost and that it was creating something of a stir at Government House and that I had expressed sympathy to him towards it. Someone at that stage made a tasteless remark—to coin a phrase—about the likely attractiveness of the Governor's dog to those who might be minded to embark on some exercise in Cantonese cuisine as a result.

I responded to that particular sally by saying that in fact I had heard in gossip in Beijing that Deng Xiaoping, who is a Sichuanese and for whom dog is a delicacy, did have some culinary tastes of that kind. And that was a quick exchange of banter of that kind in a totally off-the-record context, and it is just absolutely outrageous that the thing should have been reported at all.

As soon as I heard about this late last night, I did immediately communicate with our Consul-General in Hong Kong and asked her to convey my concern to the Governor that the thing had been misrepresented in that way and my disgust at the irresponsible way in which the journalist had behaved.

talk.start.para: —Did you apologise to the Chinese?

—It is not a matter of apologising to the Chinese because nothing has been said by me in any context that justifies an apology. I welcome the opportunity to set the record straight on that one because it is just a classic example of the way in which a piece of outrageous misreporting can also take off.

para.tab: I might also say, while I am about it, that at one stage I used the expression `kicking against the pricks' to describe the approach of the present Chinese Government.

talk.start.para: —`Marxist pricks'.

—Let me clarify the record. In the open press conference at one stage I referred to the inevitability, in my judgment, of the achievement of political liberalisation following the economic liberalisation and the way in which Marxist ideology in fact would lead to that conclusion. And I suggested accordingly, in the context of that discussion, that it might be well for the present Chinese leadership to recognise that inevitability rather than, as I said, `kicking against the Marxist pricks'—referring, of course, to a very familiar piece of phraseology which had its first appearance, as I recall, in the
Bible
.
—I don't believe this! You're an embarrassment.
—No, I mention this because this is about to take off also. Acts, chapter 9, verse 5, says:

para.tab: And he said, Who art thou Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.

speech.para:
I say this because the journalist who wrote in the
Courier-Mail
this morning, clearly utterly unfamiliar with the expression or its origins in the
Bible
, wrote an article in that newspaper saying that I am referring to the Chinese as `Marxist pricks'. I take this as another illustration of the difficulties we all confront when dealing with thick-headed journalists who are irresponsible but determined nonetheless to make an issue of things that arise in this way. I hope Senator Kemp will exercise a little more responsibility than some members of the profession.

talk.start.para: —Order! That matter has nothing to do with the Estimates. I will not permit any further questions on that matter.
—Oh, Mr Chairman!
—It has nothing to do with the Estimates.
—You can't protect him like that; he's a gauche man.
—If there are any questions on the non-program specific item, as listed on the running sheet, I will take them.

—Mr Chairman, I still wish to refer to the education program in China. Senator Evans raised a couple of issues which I think clearly come under this particular rubric. I point out to you that the purpose of this education program in China is to improve relations between Australia and China. Senator Evans has apparently referred to an unnamed group of people publicly as Marxist pricks. Who are these people that Senator Evans was referring to?
—Order!
—This is clearly within—

—Order! This is nothing to do with the non-program specific matter which is listed in the Estimates. If Senator Kemp wishes to raise the matter later, he may be able to do so but certainly not here. Is there anything further in relation to non-program specific items?

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I hear your ruling, Mr Chairman, but I would very much like to pursue the matter further, particularly now that Senator Evans has blamed the journalist—the irresponsible journalist!—in circumstances where he has chosen to ridicule the paramount leader of China. One would have thought that was an irresponsible Foreign Minister, whether it was on the record or off the record. I wonder whether I might be permitted to pursue that subject further under the heading of China in the bilateral program, subprogram 1.1.
—That would be a much better place to pursue it.
—We finished subprogram 1.1 last night.
—Subprogram 1.1 has concluded.

—I ask that subprogram 1.1 be reconsidered, particularly in the light of Senator Evans's determination again to blame the messenger this morning, as we have heard. We have here a situation where the Foreign Minister has again embarrassed Australia. Astonishingly, he comes in and apparently says he is not prepared to apologise to China for this embarrassment. Instead, he blames the journalist. It was the journalist who was irresponsible for reporting the fact that Senator Evans was making fun of the paramount leader of China. The journalist, according to Senator Evans, should therefore be condemned.

para.tab: It seems to me that whatever Senator Evans says in China or Hong Kong, on the record or off the record, reflects upon Australians generally. It reflects upon us. It is not the first time that he has embarrassed Australia in this way. He embarrassed us in South Africa when he abused the officials who were provided for his own security. He embarrassed us when he attacked the Indian High Commissioner in Melbourne because that man happened to have a different view to his in a particular instance. He has embarrassed us in this chamber when he has sworn across the chamber in a way that no other senator has ever done. He clearly has a failing in this area. It would be one thing having a failing if it did not reflect upon Australia, but in the position of Foreign Minister it does reflect upon Australia.

Instead of coming in here and seeking to blame the journalist, he should be apologising to China for seeking to make fun of the paramount leader of China because he wishes to amuse some journalist in Hong Kong with a tale or two. That is apparently what it was all about. There is no suggestion that he was wishing to deliberately insult China. He was seeking to be funny for the benefit of some journalist; to impress these journalists with his level of humour. But the effect of it has been—that is what is important—to embarrass our country. As I said, he cannot use the excuse that it was off the record. The Foreign Minister of Australia, when dealing with the international press, simply does not make fun of the head of state of another country. I find it amazing that he is not even prepared to come in here and advise us that he has apologised to China for any embarrassment thereby caused.

It is a classic case, again, of double standards. A week or two ago the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) made a slip in relation to Mr Carr, for which he immediately apologised. In the view of the Labor Party that was a hanging offence. Do honourable senators remember what Mr Keating said? He said it demonstrated that Dr Hewson was not suited for government because he had slipped up in making a statement to which Mr Carr took offence. That is one standard. But when the Foreign Minister of this country, Senator Evans, goes to Hong Kong and ridicules the paramount leader of China in discussion with journalists, that is nothing. That is just a joke and it is irresponsible for the journalist to have reported it.

I do not think that the matter should rest at this stage. I think Senator Evans should go from this chamber and register an apology to China for the embarrassment he has caused Australia. At the very least, he should try to desist from this in the future but, looking at his record in this area, that is very unlikely to occur. I invite the Minister to indicate to the chamber now that he is prepared to apologise to China for any embarrassment caused by his flippant and very unwise comments in Hong Kong.

talk.start.para: —I intend to regularise part of the proceedings before we go any further. Are there any further comments in relation to the non-program specific item, as listed—Grants to the ACTU and affiliates?
—Mr Chairman, I want to raise a point of order.
—Order! Are you raising a matter under that particular heading?
—I am raising a matter which arises out of what Senator Evans said and what you have said, Mr Chairman.
—I am not going to permit discussion of that type under this particular heading.

—Mr Chairman, I ask you to ask Senator Evans to kindly table the biblical reference he made so that we can have that on the record. I find it absolutely an affront that he is attempting to use the
Bible
to justify his effrontery to the Chinese people. I want the reference. Can he give it forthwith?
—It is not up to me to ask him; it is up to the—
—Just give me the reference. That will do fine.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Senator Bishop will get what she gets, and she will have it on the terms in which I put it on the record. Those terms are these—
—You are a gauche man. Just give the reference.

—Behave yourself. The paragraph in question appears in a story on the front page of the
South China Morning Post
.
—I want the biblical reference.

—I will give you the biblical reference; just hold your horses. The writing of the paragraph in question is difficult, which is why I put it on the record; the fax is unclear. Firstly, I said on the record in the press conference:

speech.para: I always delight in reminding the Chinese that the political superstructure always follows from—and is determined by—the economic base, and that the process of political liberalisation is only a matter of time.

para.tab: It's historical inevitability that the political superstructure will respond accordingly, so why can't they get with the—

speech.para: in other words, why can they not accept—
historic deterministic inevitability rather than just kicking against the Marxist pricks?

I am saying that it is Marxist ideology and Marxist theology that there will be this relationship and the Chinese leadership ought to recognise that. I used the expression `kicking against the pricks' in that context, resisting something which is inevitable. As I have said, a journalist has reported this in Australia as a reference to pricks in another particular connotation of that word, which totally misses the point. My staff had to remind the journalist in question that the phrase `kicking against the pricks' is a well established phrase in the English language which had its origins, as I told the Senate a little earlier, in Acts, chapter 9, verse 5. I am perfectly happy to table that particular reference.

talk.start.para:
—Also the
South China Post
.
—Yes. Senator Bishop will get it. The reference says:

speech.para: I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.

With the utmost respect, I do not think that biblical connotation has any of the connotations that might otherwise be associated with those words. Certainly that is exactly the sense in which I was using the expression. I used this as a demonstration of just how easy it is for people to be misrepresented by those who are either stupidly or maliciously—as the honourable senator is—inclined to do so. So I table accordingly the bits of paper in question from which I have just read.

talk.start.para: —I rise briefly to speak to the same item that Senator Hill spoke to.
—I have ruled that that matter will not be discussed under the non-program specific item that we have in front of us. I am not too sure, but you might be able to raise the matter a little further on.
—Mr Chairman, I think this will be the end of the matter. I want to speak on the same matter that Senator Hill raised—that is, the bilateral relations between Australia and China.

para.tab: The Minister has not yet spoken in response to the measured, responsible words of Senator Hill on this matter. This Parliament, and I would hope this Government, does not wish to offend China or the supreme leader of China, Deng Xiaoping. Irrespective of whatever explanation the Minister gives for his irresponsible action, he now has put on the record a statement which he clarifies he did make and which, in a double-barrelled way, offends both the British Governor of Hong Kong and China.
It is not entirely trivial for us to overlook cultural problems or barriers between countries. I recall a very brief incident—

talk.start.para: —I think you are flouting my ruling, Senator Teague.

—I do not wish in any way to challenge your ruling, Mr Chairman. However, I believe it is important for me to say that 25 years ago when I was the leader of a student delegation to China—I was accompanied by Stephen FitzGerald, who four years later became our first ambassador to China—there was a similar incident about dogs. That incident prevented us, as a delegation of Australian students, from meeting with Chou En-lai, the then Premier. Called the Snoopy incident, it was about one of our undergraduate members foolishly drawing a picture of Snoopy saying `Long live Chairman Mao'. This piece of paper and the angry response in Shanghai was taken to Beijing.

para.tab: The delegation thought it was going to be thrown out of China because of the Chinese sensitivity to questions about dogs. Privately, I will explain to anyone who wants to ask how it was that Stephen FitzGerald, who was acting as my interpreter, and I, as leader of the delegation 25 years ago in Beijing, had a very serious incident on our hands. The Minister will remember that Deng Xiaoping was then a close colleague of the then Premier, Chou En-lai, in the leadership of China. I do not believe that this will be taken lightly. It is a mark against this Foreign Minister and Australia.

Mr Chairman, I conclude on this point: I wish to underline the request that was made by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and the shadow Foreign Minister, Senator Hill. In the best interests of this country, I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to apologise clearly for his irresponsible remark and make sure that this is the end of the matter.

talk.start.para: —As far as I am concerned, the comment to be made now by the Minister is the end of the matter under this specific heading.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Mr Chairman, let me simply say this: I had no intention whatsoever of causing offence to the Chinese or, for that matter, the Governor. I doubt very much that in the case of the Chinese any offence would have been taken.

para.tab: What people seem to fail to appreciate—and it is a demonstration of the sorts of cultural gaps that exist here—is that while it is a terrible insult in China to call someone a dog or to associate in some way an individual with a dog, which is part of the problem that existed in that incident years ago to which Senator Teague referred, it just happens to be the case by contrast that to say that someone eats dog is very likely to be regarded, particularly in Canton and Sichuan, as a compliment on that person's gourmet tastes. Dog happens to be a very sophisticated and highly regarded item of Chinese cuisine, whatever we might think about that. While it might be a terrible thing to say in the Australian context that someone eats dog, in itself it just does not have that kind of connotation.

As we all know, the Chinese have a marvellous sense of humour. It is a sense of humour that is very easily recognisable to Australians. It is one of the things that enable Australians and Chinese to get on so well. I am sure that the particular context in which this exchange occurred would be perfectly understood in China—that it was a bantering exchange. I find it impossible to believe that there would have been offence, but if there has been offence I can assure anyone listening to or reading this debate that no offence was intended.

My main concern was that an offence would be caused to the Governor because of the particular situation there, demonstrating total insensitivity to something that is a particularly serious thing for anyone with a family in that situation. I did convey an apology to the Governor that the matter had got into the public record in this way completely misrepresenting the context of what I had said and the substance of it. Mr Chairman, I hope that that will settle this rather absurd matter once and for all.

CHAIRMAN
—Are there any further matters in relation to the non-program specific items as listed on the running sheet?

talk.start.para: —As a tour de force, Senator Evans has not only insulted the Chinese and the British but also insulted hundreds of millions of Christians. Even for Senator Evans, that is a tour de force of some—

para.tab:
CHAIRMAN
—Senator Kemp—

talk.start.para: —Oh!
—Yes, he has. His mocking humour is a disgrace.
—Senator Kemp, take your seat.
—Don't be absurd. You are a halfwit.
—It is only early in the morning. Let us get a bit of order into this place.
—Mr Chairman—

—Order! The Chair is standing. Remain seated while the Chair is standing. Senator Kemp, I indicated that there would be no more discussion on that matter under this item. If you have any other matter to discuss under this item, please proceed.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I ask that you request the Minister to withdraw yet another of his offensive remarks, this time directed at Senator Kemp.
—If that is what we are going to do, I will firstly ask Senator Kemp to withdraw his remark `a disgrace'.
—Then rephrase it—he is disgraceful; his behaviour is disgraceful.
—At times it is better for the Chair to just let things flow rather than continually stopping to have words withdrawn.
—On the point of order—

—Senator Bishop should take her seat while I am speaking. I did not hear the word that was alleged to have been uttered by the Minister. But if he used a word that is unparliamentary, I am sure he will withdraw it. The word `disgrace' was used. The President has ruled on a number of occasions that that word is unparliamentary. I ask Senator Kemp to withdraw the word.
—I want to raise a point of order.
—No. I am speaking to Senator Kemp. After he has responded, you may raise a point of order.

—Except that the point of order is applicable to the ruling made in this place the other day where conveniently the Chair did not hear a Labor Party person call a Liberal Party person a disgrace, and said, `I only heard the word "disgraceful" used as an adjective'. We are in a curious situation here, Mr Chairman.
—There is no point of order. Senator Bishop, take your seat. Senator Kemp, withdraw the word.
—I will do it with more grace than the Minister did it last time. I withdraw the word.
—I used an unparliamentary expression, Mr Chairman, and I withdraw it accordingly.

—I refer to the amount of $11,638 on page 212 which was a grant to the Australian Teachers Union to facilitate teaching in China. Could the Minister please tell us precisely what was involved in that program and what it hoped to achieve.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The money in question was granted to the ATU to facilitate administration of the ATU's teaching English in China program. The money covered return airfares, overnight accommodation, travel insurance, visa costs, medical costs, and some books and equipment for participants.

para.tab: The context of the grant is as follows: in 1981 the governments of Australia and China signed an agreement on cultural cooperation with the aim of enhancing friendly relations and furthering mutual understanding by means of cultural exchange. That is how it was expressed. Every two years officials of both countries meet to negotiate an implementing program for cultural exchange under the agreement. Items are included in the program on the general basis of reciprocity and in April 1992 the teaching in China program was included under education.

The particular content of the program was as follows: four teachers taught English at the Shanghai University of Finance and Economics. Two of them will continue the program in Shanghai in 1992-93. The Shanghai University of Finance and Economics is one of the principal suppliers of economic personnel to Shanghai industry and government. Assisting the university to train personnel is a high priority, given the potential for trade with Shanghai, which is a major centre for industry and technology.

In 1991-92 two teachers taught English at the University of Science and Technology of China in Hefei, which is in Anhui Province. The University of Science and Technology is likewise important in training China's technical and managerial elite and is considered one of the top universities in China. The training assistance provided by Australia will obviously help to promote political and economic relations with China.

talk.start.para: —I refer to an item on the same page called trade union training. This is under Papua New Guinea and South Pacific. A quarter of a million dollars has apparently been provided under this item. I wonder whether Senator Evans could enlighten the Committee as to what was involved in that training scheme and which trade union officials took part in the scheme. Can he advise what they were paid out of that training grant?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I think it is all spelt out in the materials that were supplied to the honourable senator, as I recall. I have no more information in front of me or with me from advisers on the detailed content of that. We can supply the names of officials and so on who were involved in this. I presume it was a matter of bringing people down for courses at TUTA. I am told that that is essentially the case.

para.tab: It is obviously part of the general institution building programs in which we are involved in a number of different contexts and, beyond that, there is nothing I can sensibly add at this stage, but I will seek some further information.

talk.start.para: —Just as a guide and to see the direction in which we are heading, could the Minister tell us whether that money, or a significant proportion of that money, is paid to ATUTA. I am trying to work out whether this is just another way of funding trade union activities, or whether we are genuinely trying to help people in the region.

—Certainly the latter in this context. I think most of the money is for travel, living expenses and so on associated with this. Maybe it is a matter of paying some fees for the programs in question, particularly if they are specifically tailored, but again I will seek that information.

—I would like the information the Minister gives me to be broken down between the actual tutorial fees and other costs paid to ATUTA and the other sums which were paid to the individuals on this training scheme. I would like the names of the people who participated in this scheme and just how they were sponsored.

para.tab: As the Minister is aware, there is very great concern on this side of the chamber about moneys which have been paid to the industrial arm of the Labor Party. From the point of view of making the Government properly accountable for taxpayers' funds, this is an area in which we are particularly keen to get some clear answers.

Likewise, I turn to the next item, which is another major trade union activity. I can assure the taxpayers that when the government changes sooner or later—sooner this year or later next year—I will put a strong view to Senator Hill, who will be in charge of this, that he should look very closely at the way in which taxpayers' money is being given to the trade union movement. The trade union movement seems to have so much money to spend on strikes and attacking the Liberal Party, yet we seem to need to use taxpayers' funds to support these types of specific activities which are of interest to the Australian trade union movement, but not of great interest to the Australian taxpayer.

Can the Minister give us more information on the contribution to the core program activities of the Commonwealth Trade Union Council? What are these core program activities and how do they benefit the Australian taxpayer?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I do not have that information to hand at the moment, but we can certainly supply it. Again, it is part of the process of institution building. I know some institutions are less attractive to those opposite than others, but in terms of economic development programs in Commonwealth countries, developing a responsible and effective role for the trade movement is very much part of the process of nation building and consolidation, and we contribute accordingly.

para.tab: While I am on my feet, yesterday Senator Kemp asked me for further information about the grants which had been given to members of the Australian Journalists Association for visits to the region. I am happy to table the lists of winners of the awards for this travelling program in 1990-91 and 1991-92, together with a description of the particular fields of investigation or interest that the particular award winners were pursuing.

If Senator Kemp looks at this information in an objective spirit—of which I hope he is still capable on occasion—he will see that this fits wholly into a sensible Australian strategy for expanding our knowledge and understanding of the region so far as members of the media are concerned. It is a thoroughly worthwhile and effective program. I table those lists accordingly.

talk.start.para: —I wonder whether the Minister could read into the record the names of the journalists.

—Yes. In 1990-91 the winners were: Mr Simon Holt from the
Cairns Post
; Ms Rosemary West of the
Age
; Ms Cherie Beach of the
Northern Territory News
; James Beatson, who is the Australian correspondent for various British newspapers and a freelance contributor to Australian papers; Ms Barbara Alysen from SBS Television; and Ms Susan Aitkin of the
Canberra Times
. In 1991-92 the winners were: Evan Williams from ABC Radio; Peter Cerexhe of
Choice
magazine, whose program was to visit Indonesia and Japan to look at consumer protection in Asia and the Pacific—which I hope would be understood even by Senator Bishop as having relevance to Australia's trade with the region; Jim Della-Giecoma of the
Australian
; Sandy Scheltema and Caroline Milburn of the
Age
; Peter Hannemann, a freelancer from Victoria whose task was to prepare radio and print material on opportunities for Australian investment in Thailand and economic growth in Malaysia; Mike van Neikerk of the
West Australian
; and Mark Metherell of the
Age
in Canberra, whose task was to visit Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore to study economic, political and strategic relationships with Australia.

para.tab: I think it will be appreciated that all of these people are well-known, well-established, serious, working journalists and the program is one that is exactly as I have described it—designed to produce that result.
Consideration interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 11 a.m., I invite honourable senators to observe two minutes silence in remembrance of those who have fallen in defence of their country.

tab.emphasis: Honourable senators having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I thank honourable senators.

para.tab: Consideration resumed.

debate.title:
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1992-93
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1992-93
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1992-93

talk.start.para: —Is it open to all journalists to apply for these grants? How are the applications assessed?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the program is advertised nationally. People do have to apply. Awardees are selected by a panel comprising one representative of my Department, one representative of the MEAA, which is the Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance, Australian Journalists Association section, and a senior journalist.

—The MEAA has one of the votes on deciding who gets these quite valuable scholarships, I take it. On page 213 there are some items which relate to the moneys the taxpayer has contributed towards the ANC. My colleague Senator Bishop has said to me that she has some questions on this, but what is the total amount that APHEDA has given to the ANC this year? How does that relate to the total amount that this Government, through the Department of Foreign Affairs, has given to the ANC? I am after two overall figures—the overall contribution by the taxpayer to the ANC and the amount which has been given by APHEDA.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The Government has directly given only a very limited amount to the ANC. It was $80,000 in total. That was the subject of a lot of discussion 18 months or so ago. The particular context was clearly described at the time. It was to strengthen the economic department of the ANC to create within it a physical capacity to do the kind of economic planning that we all regard as a crucial element in the future of that country, acknowledging the role that, whichever way one looks at it, however much one might like it or not, the ANC is going to play in it. That was the sum of money then and it was the year before last that that money was given.

para.tab: The money that has gone through APHEDA has never, in my knowledge—I can certainly confirm this absolutely—been given directly to the ANC for any purpose. Quite a lot of it has involved utilisation for training programs of one kind or another which have been awarded to ANC members for reasons that again are squarely related to the future effective development of the country. I will certainly seek—I do not think we can do it on the basis of the figures that are here in the chamber at the moment—a precise compilation and total of the money in this year's program that has been utilised in that indirect way by ANC members, but I cannot do that right now.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Minister. I look forward to obtaining those figures. There are two other points that I would like the Minister to comment on. Could the Minister indicate what comments the Government has made in relation to the recent exposure of the ANC use of torture in its camps? I think for the public record it is important that we get the Minister's views on that issue.

para.tab: The Minister has probably heard the expression that people can do well by doing good. Could someone go through the total APHEDA budget, 91 per cent of which is paid by the taxpayer of Australia, and indicate what proportion of that money is actually paid to Australians, in particular trade union officials? Looking through this, it is very hard for me to evaluate all of these programs. I am sure that some are most worthy. This goes back to the accountability and the proper concerns that people on this side of the chamber have to make sure that taxpayers' funds are properly accounted for.

A lot of money has been given to the ACTU for its foreign aid purposes. The ACTU seems to have heaps of money for a whole host of political purposes, but it does not seem to give a very high priority to foreign aid activities except when those activities can be funded by the taxpayer. So I would like the Department in due course to provide me with the figures of just how much of this $3.4m is actually paid out to Australian trade union officials?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —We can certainly endeavour to produce those figures. The accounts that are before Senator Kemp indicate that the salaries component directly provided for in the income and expenditure accounts of 1991 was $199,000 and in 1992 it was $240,000 out of a total budget of $3m odd.
—But that is the salaries of head office. That is not the answer to the question.

—Salaries that are payable. My understanding is that only a very small amount of the APHEDA moneys is utilised for the payment of salaries and such like to Australians. That is a proper question to ask and we will seek the information and give it to Senator Kemp.
—The earlier part of my remarks was: what comments has the Minister made, if any, in relation to press reports and confirmation that the ANC has been involved in torture in some camps?

—I make the comment now that the information that has emerged is totally indefensible. My understanding is that that view was very clearly conveyed by our mission to the ANC. I think I was overseas at the time, as I have often been over the last four or five months, when the particular information came out, but I did see some talking points that were prepared, and I think I approved them, making very clear our distaste for the activities in question. Whether those talking points were actually utilised by the Acting Foreign Minister in my absence overseas as a result of a question in here or whatever I cannot say. But I am very clear in my own mind that it is, I repeat, absolutely indefensible. I have no difficulty at all about putting that on the record and being totally even handed and consistent in the way in which we react to material of this kind when it does come to light.
—Could the Minister tell us whether it will affect in any way the program of aid that we directly give to the ANC?
—No.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —I am interested to hear that the Minister's reaction to the fact that torture has been carried out by the ANC is to say that, firstly, it is indefensible; secondly, it is tasteless; and, thirdly, it will make no difference at all to the amount of money we will give the ANC. I find those three statements truly amazing. The Minister said a moment ago that only some $80,000 had been given to the ANC. I know that the Minister chooses to use the English language in a way that perhaps others of us do not. However, I would point out to him that, at page 213 of the additional information provided, under the heading Special Assistance Programs in Southern Africa, we have:

speech.para: ANC\MDM Planning Meeting $121,000
On-the-Job Training in Australia $26,000
ANC Donors Meeting $45,000
ANC Scholarships Training in
Tanzania $550,000
—this is all taxpayers' money, by the way—
Scholarships for Refugees
in Harare $180,500
—perhaps some of those were people who had been tortured—
Co-operative Management Training $66,000
Youth Skills Training $82,000
That comes to well over $1m of taxpayers' money going to the ANC whose practice of torture the Minister finds tasteless.

para.tab: We have criticised the Minister from this side of the chamber on many occasions for the fact that he has chosen a political party, a political organisation, the ANC, to be the sole recipient of funds from the Australian taxpayer and that he is picking winners as to who may be winning government after the next elections in South Africa.

Senator Kemp, Senator Hill, Mr Carlton from the other place and I had the opportunity to go to South Africa some two months ago as the guests of the Southern African Forum and to meet with leaders and people from all the political parties involved. That included meeting everyone—people from the PAC on the far left; officials from the ANC; people from Solidarity, the Indian party; people from the coloured party; people from Inkatha, including Chief Buthelezi, about whom I will have more to say in a moment; people from Helen Sussman's party and Helen Sussman herself; people generally who are concerned about the way in which the dilemma of South Africa is to be solved.

The one thing that became quite clear and apparent from these meetings was this: only the PAC and ANC want a unitary form of government. Everybody else wants power sharing and some form of federation or confederation. It is well to note that had South Africa not had a unitary form of government, apartheid would have been impossible to implement. Simply, if there is to be another unitary government to replace the current unitary government, then it will be winner take all and, in my view, an awful bloodbath could result. If, however, all the players are allowed to have a say and there is some form of power sharing—and already agreement has been reached in respect of nine economic regions, with one of them possibly being divided into two to provide two Xhosa states—we will find that having power sharing and stability in South Africa is possible. As I said, those opinions were gained from all the political players when we were there.
