We also had the opportunity to meet with Judge Goldstone of the Goldstone Commission, a most impressive man. We were there for the opening day's hearings into the Boipatong massacre. But we also learned something which we do not see in this paper and which the Minister has never drawn to the attention of this place or the Australian people, and that is that just as Boipatong was the most horrendous massacre—and we did indeed go to Boipatong and meet with people who had been assaulted, injured and hacked—there was an equivalent which the Commission was also investigating called Crossroads where it was exactly the reverse. In other words, the violence and the massacres that had been perpetrated were on both sides; they had been perpetrated by the ANC and they had been perpetrated by the Zulus and people who are members of Inkatha.

It was very important, I thought, that at the Goldstone Commission to hear the evidence was the former Chief Justice of India, for instance, sitting on the bench with the members of that Commission. It was, I think, most important that people were concerned to see that individual nations, such as ours, did not intervene, interfere or try to give our Government's imprimatur to one political player versus another.

I have said we met with Chief Buthelezi and we travelled to Kwa Zulu to do just that. When Chief Buthelezi and other Ministers who attended him at this meeting made a formal speech, of which I have a copy, he spoke about the way Minister Evans had personally treated him. He spoke about the way that he was interested in coming to Australia, particularly as he found the Australian Constitution a good model and one that could be useful in solving South Africa's problems. He explained that, although he had expressed his wish to the Minister, or through to the Minister, to be invited to Australia—just as Nelson Mandela had been invited to Australia—and have the opportunity to learn the things that perhaps we had to teach, the Minister simply refused to allow that to occur; the Minister deigned to allow him perhaps to have a visa and come.

The complaints that we hear loud and clear—and, if I might say, I have heard them in other parts of the world as well—are about the manner in which the Minister dealt with officials in a foreign country. This is apart from the incident of his throwing things and shouting; this is a complaint about the way individuals are treated in another nation. We have heard that the Minister has indeed—

Senator Faulkner interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Mr Chairman, was that a comment from the observers box of `Shame'?
—I did not hear it.

interject.speaker: Senator Gareth Evans

talk.start.para: —`The observers box of shame'. Can I seek the withdrawal of

interject.para: that particular totally offensive reference to public servants? A remark happened to be made by Senator Faulkner, not by public servants, but that is not the point. The point is Senator Bishop's incapacity to talk about public servants of this nation other than in tones of withering contempt, which is a demonstration of exactly what we have to put up with when we respond to her. I ask specifically for that reference, `the box of shame', to be withdrawn. I think that is just disgraceful.

talk.start.para: —It was a question of me, and I think the question has been answered.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. If that remark did come from Senator Faulkner, then it is a parliamentary comment.
—There is no question that it came from me.
—Then do you apologise?
—I asked the question of the Chairman. If it did not come from the box, yes, I withdraw the suggestion that it did.
—And do you apologise for the reference?
—Order!
—Mr Chairman!
—Order! No apology is necessary. Senator Bishop asked me a question; the question has been answered. Senator Bishop, could you continue?
—Thank you very much, Mr Chairman. To be hectored by a man who has embarrassed this country nationally, who is considered gauche, rude and an embarrassment, really is too much.

para.tab: I go back to the question of the ANC and the treatment that Senator Evans meted out to important people in a foreign country. It is simply unacceptable for this Government to choose to give taxpayers' money—not $80,000—to one political player and not to any of the others in a spirit of trying to find a solution with something like the Goldstone Commission. It is simply unacceptable for us as a nation to be putting all our bets for future relations with that nation on the ANC being successful with a unitary form of government and dominating that nation.

I ask the Minister again the question that Senator Kemp asked him. In general and in responding to my comments, I ask the Minister: in light of the evidence of torture being carried out by the ANC and the Minister's concern that it is tasteless and it is indefensible—

talk.start.para: —I didn't say `tasteless' in that context.
—Yes the Minister did; he can check the record. In light of that, will he kindly review the amount of money that he is giving to the ANC?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para:
—I would be very interested to see the
Hansard
. I made no reference that I can possibly recall to the evidence of torture and extreme violence being perpetrated by the ANC in those camps as being tasteless. That is an absurd reference to make in the context of allegations and evidence as serious that. I am sure I did not use the word. That is just another demonstration of the way in which Senator Bishop misuses language and expressions for her own purposes.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Any check of the
Hansard
will show that it was used. If the Minister can simply wait until we see the
Hansard
, we will deal with it then.

—It might be that today's
Hansard
is a best-seller tomorrow.

—I will be very interested to see it. I have responded to Senator Kemp on the question of grants to the ANC. I will provide him with further information about those grants to APHEDA which may be regarded as indirectly benefiting, through training programs and the like, particular members of the ANC. I will give the information about that. I have already mentioned in general terms the rationale for this.

para.tab:
This was the subject of a lot of debate in this place a couple of years ago. It is essentially a developmental rationale, bearing in mind the extraordinary character of this particular movement as representative of the overwhelming majority of black South Africans and a significant number of non-black South Africans as well. That point is well made; it is a unique situation and one that demands a unique approach.
As to the rest of Senator Bishop's contribution, I thank her for her analysis of the situation in South Africa and I will give it the attention I usually devote to her contributions.

talk.start.para: —One never expects that one could receive a civil answer from Senator Evans. I am afraid that when he gets a little rattled, as we have seen this morning, his logic becomes a little rattled also. I direct the question to the Minister again: has Chief Buthelezi expressed the wish that he be invited to Australia as a guest of government, as was Nelson Mandela?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —There is a great deal I could say about my encounter with Chief Buthelezi, but I do not think it would serve the cause of good relations with South Africa to put on record just how disgraceful the behaviour was that I experienced, under the purported guise of hospitality, from that gentleman and the claque of his Cabinet that accompanied him. It is a matter for—
—What was that adjective?

—The claque—C-L-A-Q-U-E; that is another word that people on the other side have not heard of. There was booing, jeering and hissing in the Cabinet room; I was asked to sit there and wait for half an hour and then was subjected to a 40-minute harangue before I could say anything. In response, I was again hissed and booed. Is that Senator Bishop's idea of the kind of hospitality that is appropriate to offer?

para.tab: It is the case that Chief Buthelezi expressed some indignation about the fact that he had not been formally invited to Australia. I made it clear that he would be a welcome visitor to Australia, should he choose to come, but we did not regard it as our responsibility to invite, as a guest of the Australian Government, anyone who chose to seek such an invitation. We make judgments about the representative character and significance of people in question. We have made some judgments in that respect about Chief Buthelezi and he did nothing to encourage any other judgment to be made by the nature of his performance during my visit.

talk.start.para: —I take it that he did express a wish and the Minister declined to invite him. Is that right? The Minister chose to invite only one political leader—Nelson Mandela—and, of course, Walter Sisulu has been here as well. The Minister deliberately chose to ask people from the ANC and not people from any other political movement in South Africa; is that correct?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —There have been others from other political movements in South Africa. I think Van Zyl Slabbert, from the moderate right grouping, is one example. It is a matter of case by case judgment of these things. There is no right or entitlement of anyone to be the recipient of taxpayer funded support of this particular kind. It is a matter of judgment in all the circumstances as to what such people can contribute to our understanding in an evolving situation and our judgment as to what kind of role such people are likely to play in a country's future. We will go on making those judgments to the best of our ability. I will not be dragooned into making any particular judgment about any particular individual as a result of Senator Bishop's blandishments.

—I think it is the best of the Minister's ability that concerns us, particularly after this morning's exchange on his ability to gratuitously insult, yet again, another nation. I ask the Minister whether he would supply to the Senate a list of all people who have been invited to Australia—that is, those who have had fares paid, accommodation paid and entertainment paid—and the party to which they belong, their political affiliation, in South Africa. I would like the complete list, including all those from the ANC and from any other group at all. It would be helpful if we could have that as quickly as possible.

para.tab: As well as that, I would like the Minister to confirm or deny for me a matter that was discussed on talkback radio in Sydney the other evening; that is, that Nelson Mandela, who has been the recipient of some of these funds, had in fact given a wedding for his daughter on which he spent some $450,000. Does the Minister have any knowledge of that? If not, could the Minister endeavour to find out, because it would be most important that we then understand the auditing processes that are gone through with money that we give by way of aid through APHEDA.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I have no intention whatsoever of exploring the budgetary circumstances of the wedding of Nelson Mandela's daughter. There is no conceivable connection with any Australian aid funding in this respect. The Indonesian Foreign Minister, my good friend Ali Alatas, had a wedding for his daughter last week at which there were, as I understand it, something like 5,000 guests. I do not think anyone, in the wildest stretch of imagination, would regard Australia's aid program to Indonesia as having any conceivable linkage with that; nor is there any conceivable foundation for a such a linkage on this occasion. It is just another example of tendentious trawling of the kind that has become all too tediously familiar from Senator Bishop.

—I do not think we need to make comparisons between a government which is in power and a political party, a political player, which the Minister has chosen to support. I go back to this question of APHEDA. Page 220 of the report of Estimates Committee B lists the following people as directors of APHEDA: Mr Cliff Dolan, a well-known trade union member; Mr Martin Ferguson, a well-known trade union member; Mr Frank Mossfield; Dr Rosemary Crowley, our own Senator Rosemary Crowley; Dr Ruth White, lecturer in Health Personal Education at the University of New South Wales; Dr John Toohey, occupational health and safety specialist; Richard Scott, National President of the Metal and Engineering Workers' Union; and Mr David Bell, the trade union training officer with the New South Wales Teachers Federation. As I understand it, the Labor Party in Australia still has the voting strength of the trade union movement as its base; is that correct?

—If Senator Bishop were to look at the latest
Australian
newspoll, I think she would appreciate that the support for the Australian Labor Party is rather more widely based than that.

—I was referring to those who vote to preselect candidates, particularly Kim Carr, who I recall was chosen ahead of Senator Evans. The point is that on the board of APHEDA are people who are either members of the Labor Party or who could reasonably be assumed to be members of the Labor Party.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I presume that Malcolm Fraser is still a member of the Liberal Party; certainly, as a former Liberal Prime Minister, he, as I understand it, is chairman of Care Australia—a major non-government aid organisation. That has not inhibited for a moment our willingness to devote funds to that organisation if it is doing an appropriate job in its area, as Care undoubtedly is and as APHEDA undoubtedly is. It is no secret that APHEDA is the aid affiliate of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. As a result, it is wholly unsurprising that it should have on its board of directors a number of people from the labour movement.

—For the Minister to try to compare the work of APHEDA with the work of Care Australia is another affront that he has gratuitously offered this morning. Six of the eight board members of APHEDA—which could be legitimately described as a front for the Labor Party—are members of the Labor Party, or could reasonably assumed to be members of the Labor Party.

para.tab: The Government has given them $3.4m to spend at will. What are the requirements for auditing and for the correct spending of that money? Where is the accountability back to this Parliament because, of course, it is taxpayers' money that is being spent and it is this Parliament which says the Government may appropriate money for expenditure. Where is the audit process?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —We have supplied, and they are in the documentation available to Senator Bishop, the audited accounts of APHEDA. If she had devoted half as much attention to looking at the detail as she has to working up her offensive rhetoric, she might have found the question she has just asked an unnecessary one.

para.tab: That goes to financial auditing. As to program evaluation, most of that is done through special allocation of 10 per cent of funds for monitoring and evaluation of AIDAB funded projects. In fact, it covers not only evaluation procedures, but their total administrative costs as well.

Aid NGOs, I am told, regard 10 to 15 per cent for administration costs to be a reasonable level, although many of them treat monitoring and evaluation as requiring extra funding allocations above that. This means that APHEDA is well at the bottom end of the range on administrative costs, but there is no ground for assuming, in our judgment, that its auditing and evaluation program review is anything other than appropriate and effective. That is the in-house evaluation procedure. There is also ad hoc monitoring and evaluation which is done by APHEDA itself.

Among other things, I am able to advise Senator Bishop that Ian Macphee, well and lovingly remembered on this side of the chamber if not on hers, has recently completed a review of NGO work in South Africa, including the work of APHEDA. That report will be available quite soon—I think, next week, in fact.

talk.start.para: —I have looked at the accounts as they are published here, and they give me no indication at all as to whether or not the moneys have been properly spent. They are merely perfunctory accounts—money in, money out—and in no way indicate whether or not the money has been properly spent. That is what accountability is all about.

para.tab: If the Minister is saying that the report that Mr Macphee has made with regard to work in South Africa deals in detail with the manner in which money has been expended by APHEDA, I will be most interested to read the report. If it is merely a global appraisal that this lot did well, or that lot have spent money here which seems to have been useful, I do not think that contributes to the debate at all.

My concern is that the Minister seems to give away with a great glad hand taxpayers' money which can be, and is, seemingly, used to further political purposes in which he, personally, seems to have an interest. If taxpayers' money is to be appropriated, which is supposed to be in the national interest—that is, the national interest of all Australians—then we need to see some proper appraisal of the manner in which this money is, in fact, spent and, to date, we do not have it. Does the Minister have any plans to let us have such an appraisal? Or can he confirm to me that Mr Macphee's report will deal in detail with the proper expenditure of this money appropriated through this program?

talk.start.para: —What was the last question? I missed it.

—I asked the Minister whether or not he planned to let us have a report which would give us the information for which I have asked, or whether he can assure us that the report that he mentioned that Mr Macphee is bringing down will do in detail an analysis of the manner in which this money has been expended to show that it is, in fact, properly expended in the national interest and not in a party political one.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —My understanding is that the Macphee report will deal in detail with an evaluation of the effectiveness of the programs in question. It will do so with a degree of information to allow judgment to be made about the kinds of matters that Senator Bishop is concerned about.

para.tab: I simply make the point again that South Africa is a unique situation in all sorts of ways. Eighty per cent of the population has, effectively, been denied, as a consequence of the appalling apartheid system of which those opposite were defenders for so long.

talk.start.para: —I beg your pardon?

—Senator Hill should ask his mate, Senator Bishop. I make no apology for that particular assertion. There is ample evidence on the record of that. Look at poor old Malcolm Fraser's fate when he chose to stand up for some decent values in this respect.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. That is a reflection upon senators on this side of the chamber, and I ask that you require him to withdraw.
—Senator Hill, you can imagine how little I heard of it and why. If there is a reflection, I will ask for it to be withdrawn.
—I referred to the party tradition of those opposite in supporting and defending the apartheid system in South Africa.
—You disgraceful man. You are absolutely disgraceful.
—Disgraceful man? I think that is a little out of order, is it not, Mr Chairman? Is `disgraceful' permissible parliamentary terminology?

—The Minister continually invites retorts of that nature not only through being out of order, but through being out of order in a disgraceful way. He should be required to withdraw his assertion that senators on this side were, or are, supporters of apartheid regimes.

—Mr Chairman, I accept that the collective expression is probably a little unjust because there have been one or two over the decades who have had a reasonable record on the subject. In those circumstances, I think the reference was inappropriate.
—I think it was, but I accept that you have withdrawn it.
—I conclude what I was saying—
—Withdraw unconditionally.
—It is the Chairman's responsibility to ask for that, much as Senator Bishop would like to be—
—I understand from the remarks that Senator Evans made that he has done that.

—On the same point of order, Mr Chairman, the
Hansard
record will show very clearly that he has not done that. I feel particularly offended, yet again, by Senator Evans's remarks. Senator Evans is funding the ANC. The ANC has indulged in torture. Does it follow from that, that Senator Evans is in favour of such activities? Of course it does not. I insist that Senator Evans has reflected on us all in this chamber, and he should withdraw.
—Senator Evans, have you withdrawn?

—I thought I had withdrawn, Mr Chairman—maybe in letter, if not in spirit. Yes, I withdraw, if it is your ruling that I should. I complete what I was saying in these terms. It is a unique and distinct situation that we confront in South Africa, namely, the effective denial of the overwhelming majority of the population to access to training, education and participation in the business of government at any level that would equip such people—
—Including Inkatha?

—They get access to the trappings of government in Kwa Zululand, as Senator Hill would probably appreciate, which has been denied hitherto to some people on the other side. The point is, without being drawn into any further exchanges, that the truth of the matter is that it is a developmental objective to try to help in ways that we possibly can to get funding into those areas which are going to be crucial for the effective future operation of a united South African government. There is an urgent need for economic training—training across the whole program of service delivery and social welfare. Every aspect of government is totally under-nourished so far as the capacity of the black community to contribute is concerned, as a result of those years of appalling neglect and appalling discrimination.

para.tab: We, in our own small way, have been trying to help that particular process, not least by identifying some streams of organisational authority within the country which are likely to be playing a significant role in the actual administration and governing of the country within a very short time. We make no apology whatsoever for that. It is a squarely developmental objective. It is not political in the partisan political sense of that expression, despite all the efforts to tar these programs with that brush. It is a legitimate approach that has been adopted by a number of countries around the world and it is totally defensible.

talk.start.para: —I have no more questions relating to APHEDA and South Africa. I am quite anxious to get on to the question of the three B ambassadors—Burke, Boucher and Butler. In the interests of those people who were offended by the biblical reference earlier, I would invite people to read on in Acts IX. It is indeed the story of Saul's challenge on the road to Damascus, the `pricks' referring to the pricks of light and, indeed, the fact that Saul became blind and was subsequently converted. I do think that those people who have a concern and interest that there is a spiritual sense in this place, as well as a secular sense, would indeed be affronted by Senator Evans's remark this morning.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para:
—Mr Chairman, can we be spared this sanctimony. The particular context of the exchange this morning was my use in Hong Kong in a press conference of the phrase `kick against the pricks'—a phrase which has been in common English usage for some centuries, certainly since the sixteenth century or the time of the writing of the King James version of the
Bible
, which is the origin of the phrase. I had not recalled when I used the expression that its origin was in fact biblical, but when I was confronted with the absurd story in an Australian paper this morning that I referred to senior Chinese leaders as `Marxist (expletive deleted)s' it became necessary for me to take an appropriate opportunity to correct the record. The context in which I was using the expression `kick against the pricks' was exactly the context which Senator Bishop has described—pricks in the sense not of the vulgar connotation but pricks in the sense of the pricks of life, against which sometimes it is pointless to rage; one has to accept the inevitability. That is the context of the phrase. I was simply describing the origins of that phrase as a well accepted and understood part of the English language, to make clear that the context was not an offensive context but on the contrary.

para.tab:
For that to be converted by Senator Bishop, and Senator Kemp before her, as some attempt to suggest that I am being otherwise than appropriately respectful or deferential to the language of the
Bible
or to Christian sentiment is so grotesque a travesty of the truth of this particular exchange that I really feel Senator Bishop should be called upon to apologise; but for me to do so would only set her off again, so I ask that we move on to some other heading for discussion.

talk.start.para: —I think it better if this particular religious lesson is allowed to lie.

—I simply invite anyone to read the
Hansard
and make their own judgment about the Minister and his behaviour in an international context, and I am sure Senator Harradine has something more useful to say to the Minister.

—If there are no further matters in relation to this non-program specific heading, I understand that Senator Harradine now wants to raise a matter a little out of order. Is that the situation, Senator Harradine?

—I am responding to divine impulse rather than kicking against it. I am sure that what I am proposing will be appreciated by everybody in the chamber. I have discussed the matter with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), and it will save officers of the Department hanging around for this particular reservation.

para.tab:
The Committee will see that I made a reservation in respect of the China country program. After discussion with the Minister, I think it is fair to say that I will pursue the area of poverty alleviation in China probably in a further briefing from the Department. At the Estimates Committee, the Minister incorporated a letter written to me in respect of the longstanding concerns that I have had about the coercive nature of the population control program in China and Australia's possible involvement in that area. It is my intention to respond to the Minister by letter and then to seek leave to have that letter incorporated in
Hansard
at an appropriate time and table a document indicating the attitude of AIDAB and the Minister to this matter from early 1988 to the current date.

I think that would be the most beneficial way of proceeding. Probably the academics, the Department and others can pick that up and analyse it and so on. I think that might be the best way of approaching this. I am still waiting for a full report—I understand it is coming—of the mission that went to China in the middle of this year. I have the executive report, but I do not have the full report yet.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I am very much indebted to Senator Harradine for proposing to treat these sensitive and difficult matters in this way. He and I have had longstanding differences of view about some aspects of aid administration in this respect. We have pursued them in a number of contexts and we will no doubt do so in a number of contexts in the future, but it is a difficult policy issue that is capable of being discussed in an intelligent and civilised way. I thank Senator Harradine for proposing to carry on the debate in the way that he has proposed. I think that will be particularly helpful.
—In that case, the Committee will proceed to program 2—Trade relations and economic issues—and subprogram 2.1. There being no matters there, we will proceed to program 5—Development cooperation.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —There are a number of matters that I wish to raise. I will not deal with them in any particular order; they are all development cooperation matters and all fairly arise out of the reservations. On evaluation processes, the Minister will remember that in the Senate we made reference to the Indonesian program evaluation which a year before was in a draft form. When we got to this year's Estimates, we found that it was still in a draft form, and the Minister said it would not be in a draft form within a month thereafter. I presume it has now been settled, and I ask whether we can now have a copy of that evaluation.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I am told that it is in its last stages of preparation. It will be available by the end of this week. I have not seen it yet myself.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —This really is a hopeless situation. We are interested in fair evaluations of performance of the aid programs. If it takes over a year for AIDAB to even decide within its own organisation what should be the assessment that it has put on the record, then it gives one little faith in that organisation. To give him credit, even the Minister seemed somewhat frustrated in the Estimates Committee to learn that it was still in its draft form, after having been promised to us a year ago. The Estimates Committee sat some six weeks ago. I therefore ask the Minister: what has gone wrong? Why has it taken a year for this draft to be considered and why is it still not in a settled form?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I am told that there have been divergences of opinion within the organisation about the content of the report. It has simply taken this long to resolve them. I do not regard that as especially satisfactory and I do not seek to defend the delay that is involved. I am sorry that the honourable senator will not get the report earlier, but there is nothing I can do about it except to make my views known, which I already have done.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Exploring it just a little further, could Senator Evans advise the Senate of the form of this evaluation. Who carried out the evaluation? Was it by a consultant? If so, who was the consultant and when was the consultant's report forwarded to AIDAB?
—We are still looking at the index. Can we go on to another question? Is that possible?

—Yes, we will come back to it. I understand that there is also a report and evaluation on food aid to Sri Lanka that we have been expecting for some time. I ask the Minister: what is the status of that report?
—It has just been completed and it will be circulated as soon as possible—I hope today.

—I am pleased that this procedure seems to have some effect in hastening the process to that extent, although I must say it is regrettable that the document is to be circulated after the consideration of these estimates. No doubt the Chairman will, therefore, cooperate if we want to revisit it later, seeing that it is apparently going to be provided to us later in the day. I ask: will the Minister table the Sri Lankan food aid report in here? What procedure is the Minister planning to adopt in relation to the Sri Lankan food aid report?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —We will distribute it, as we normally do, to interested parties, of which Senator Hill ranks as one in the light of his contribution. We will also make it available through the Committee secretariat to any other member of the Estimates Committee who wants to see it.
—Are we ready to revisit the Indonesian matter?
—The Indonesian report was essentially an in-house exercise assisted by two external consultants whose names we are getting. They are not readily to hand here at the moment.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Could the Minister explain to the Senate the form of this evaluation? How was it conducted? What was the task given to these consultants? Did they report? Did they report in writing? When did they report, if they reported in writing?
—I shall seek and make available to Senator Hill as soon as I possibly can later today those details.
—What are the areas of dispute in relation to the evaluation?
—I do not know. I will add that to the list of things on which we will give Senator Hill some appropriate response later in the day.
—Have the consultants been involved in the areas of dispute, or is this purely a dispute within the AIDAB structure—a dispute between officials?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I am sorry. I am simply not in a position to give Senator Hill further information about this, and it is a bit difficult to do so on the run. I will seek some further advice. If we are still going later in the day I will do my best to respond further on that, if Senator Hill can tell me what he wants to know. I think he has probably exhausted the list of questions by now regarding actual information.
—It is an incredibly mysterious set of circumstances.

—It is not mysterious for an organisation to get involved in an internal policy wrangle about how particular reports should be written, how particular programs should be characterised as to their effectiveness. Views can differ. I am sorry that this matter has taken so long. I apologise to the Estimates Committee about that. I had thought the review would be completed within the month or so that we indicated at the time. It has not been. The honourable senator will have it by the end of this week. In the meantime I will give him such information as I can about the mechanics of the report and why it has been delayed. But I cannot do that right now. I will have to do it after the lunch break.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Can I ask for copies of any consultants' reports that were provided to assist AIDAB in reaching its evaluation? Of course, the Minister understands the reasons for this concern, I presume. It is believed by many that in AIDAB's evaluation procedures what happens is that consultants are engaged, the consultants' advice is not that which AIDAB really wishes to see published and we find a long period of sanitising such information. In this situation, where AIDAB has been internally wrestling with how it should describe its assessment for a period of over a year, one is not unreasonably somewhat suspicious. That is why I would be interested to know what the outsiders thought of the program, rather than simply get the sanitised version that we would seem ultimately to be going to get.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I am told, to the extent that I am able to pick this up on the run, that it is not a matter of there being a written consultants' report which is the subject of contest. The consultants were engaged as part of a review team that produced a single document, but that document or the information which lay behind that document was itself inconclusive on particular subject areas because of differing evaluations or differing qualitative responses from particular groups in Indonesia which were the beneficiaries of the programs. Some took different views about the various projects and it was a matter of trying to reconcile those views and reach some common and credible judgment about them. I am told that is essentially what has taken the time. But beyond that I cannot comment because I am simply not familiar with the detail of this.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —On that basis, I will also ask for a copy of the report of the review team so that we can ultimately see the sanitised assessment of AIDAB in conjunction with the primary assessment of the review team, including the outside professionals who were engaged to give the public confidence in the aid program in Indonesia.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Subject to normal considerations of inter-governmental confidentiality and so on that apply to this, I see no difficulty about that. I just want to make clear that AIDAB is not in the business of sanitising evaluations. When projects go wrong, for whatever reason—and I am not suggesting that any of them have in this context, but others have in other contexts elsewhere; Margarini and so on in Africa is a good example—the object of the exercise is to scrutinise what went wrong minutely and to learn from the experience. I think AIDAB in recent years has had a pretty good track record in doing just that. It is in nobody's interests in terms of the longer term credibility of the organisation or of Australia internationally to try to conceal or paper over or whitewash things that may have gone wrong. That is the approach that is being adopted. It is one that I wholeheartedly commend. I do wish that this process of evaluation here had been rather speedier but I have responded as best I can on that.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —The third evaluation I wanted to raise was the assessment of the joint review of the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary development project dated 22 June 1992. I ask the Minister whether that report is available for public dissemination.

—That report can be made available, subject again to normal considerations of intergovernmental confidentiality which may be involved. I am not in a position to make a judgment about that, but we will look at it in that context.

—That seems to be a fairly big escape clause. When will that assessment be made? This is a report of June, so it has been about five months and the Minister is apparently unable to tell us whether an issue of intergovernmental sensitivity is involved. When are we likely to get an assessment of that? I take it, therefore, that assessment has not even been made. Is that the case?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The report in question has not previously been asked for to my knowledge. People have enough to do without rushing around making assessments of issues of that kind in a situation where nobody has sought it. Senator Hill, having sought the document, we will apply appropriate criteria to it and do the job as soon as possible. I do not know how long it will take; presumably not very long.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —The Minister will remember that he answered a question from Senator Bourne in relation to that report on 3 November this year. The question particularly related to the training of the PNG constabulary for services on Bougainville. I ask the Minister whether he has read that report.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I have not read the report. Mr Kerin has read it. He is the responsible Minister in this area and he is the one that was advised as to its content before approving the continuation of the project for its second phase. When the question was raised of him as to whether his advice was actually in accordance with the substance of the report itself, he went back and read, later that same day, I am told, the report itself in detail and was satisfied that he had been properly advised as to its contents, that they had given a complete picture of the flavour and substance of the report, and under those circumstances he did not feel it necessary in any way to revise the judgment he had made about the approval of the second phase.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —In answer to a question, the Minister said:

speech.para: . . . there has been no question of the Australian advisers, whether civilian policemen or military advisers, actively being involved in training people for the conditions they might confront on Bougainville.
Bearing in mind the Minister has not read the report, I ask him what the basis of his assertion was in his response to Senator Bourne's question.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The basis was the advice I received in the usual format supplemented by oral advice from the AIDAB officers concerned. In making that point, I stressed the word `for'. So it was a matter of saying they were not trained `for' Bougainville. In other words, they were not trained specifically to go over there and do an operational job. The training was not premised on that assumption.

para.tab: That is not to say—and I made this clear elsewhere in my answer—that some of the training they may have received for their ordinary special services division role may not itself have been useful for the job they were then called upon to play in Bougainville; but that is a different point. The point is that this special services division, or the so-called mobile squads, are essentially trained to deal with large scale, very violent civil disturbance—highland tribal fighting and matters of that kind. There is an obvious relevance to the kind of fieldcraft, weapons and bush skills that are associated with an ability to deal with that, and the situation confronted in Bougainville. But I have been very clearly advised that the notion of training people for Bougainville was not part of the repertoire.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I notice from the answer the Minister says that in fact Mr Kerin had been provided with a summary of the relevant part of the report, and it seems that he drew the conclusions on the basis of that summary. I ask the Minister whether the basis of his answer in the Senate was a preparation from the summary received by his staff or officers within the Department from the summary received by Mr Kerin or whether it was from the primary document, that is, the joint evaluation.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The briefing to me was a quite separate note prepared by the same officers with the same knowledge base. It is not a matter of someone down the line preparing a note which is itself a summary of a summary. It is a matter of going directly to the officers with the relevant expertise, the hands-on experience of the operation of this program, and seeking from them a capsule account of what actually happened.

para.tab: Mr Kerin was given a summary of the report. He was also provided at the time in that submission, he tells me, with the complete report itself. But, as so often in a ministerial office, one does not always have time to go back to the primary sources. One does rely on the summaries that are given, and he had put aside the full report to read at some later stage if circumstances arose. In fact, he ended up reading the full report later that night because a question was raised as to how accurate the advice he had been given was. He satisfied himself that the summary advice he received was very accurate.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Mr Kerin apparently satisfied himself that the summary advice reflected the detail of the report. I presume that the officers who prepared the briefing for Senator Evans—I am not too sure what they based their understanding on—took into account the detail of the report; in other words, they were familiar with the joint evaluation about which we are speaking.
—Yes.
—Is the Government satisfied that the report, as it sets out factual situations, is correct?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —This is a bit like a reference to the figure in the Weeties packet. There comes a point at which governments commission a report which addresses all the issues they want addressed, and there is no reason to doubt the conclusions of that report, so they accept it. One does not form an independent judgment by reference to some other source of information to second guess the report itself. But I can say that the report in question is a joint internal report which was prepared by both Papua New Guinea and Australian representatives on stage 1 of the police project. It is not a matter of both governments necessarily accepting every comment which appears in the body of the report because some were evaluations from one side and some from another side from the different perspectives. What is important is the basic conclusions and recommendations that flowed from that. As I understand it, those conclusions and recommendations were jointly written and tendered to the respective governments and there was unanimity.

para.tab: I am told that there was not necessarily agreement about each one of the conclusions and recommendations. It was essentially a document that contained within it a compilation of the perspectives of various people and it was used in the design of the second stage of the project. I have not seen it so I am not in a position to make an intelligent comment about what the report looks like. I know it is a large and detailed account of an extremely complex project—$30m was spent over a period of five years—which deals with a particularly sensitive subject matter.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I understand that the joint review body included police officers and others skilled in the gathering and evaluation of evidence. The Minister might confirm that. It is suggested that the report is in conflict with what the Minister said to the Senate. It is asserted within the report that these mobile forces had been trained by Australian officials specifically for Bougainville. I take it that the Minister was not aware that the report states that fact.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I said a moment ago that there were some statements in the report that were not accepted by respective governments. There were some Papua New Guinea sourced comments which we did not accept and some comments, evaluations and assessments made by our side which were not accepted by the other side. To the extent that there was anything in the report, language which addressed this issue in a way which suggested there was training with Bougainville deliberately in mind, in the sense I previously mentioned, we certainly do not accept that.

para.tab: My recollection is that I remember having my attention drawn to that part of the report with these particular statements in it and it being explained at the time that I answered these questions in the Senate that while this was someone's perception on the PNG side, it certainly was not ours. The training for Bougainville was not part of the terms of reference for the training team. The core subjects do not make any specific reference to Bougainville and that was not part of the process. There has been a lot of speculation. There have been press reports about people allegedly being trained in the use of M60s and so on by the squad. I am advised that there is simply no truth in that. They were not trained specifically in the use of that weapon. There is an explanation for all the other odd statements that have been made in this respect.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Either the report is wrong in fact—if that is what it states, which I understand it does and it now seems that the Minister is confirming it—or the Minister misled the Senate in his answer to a question from Senator Bourne. There now seems to be some confusion as to exactly what information base he was relying upon in his answer to Senator Bourne's question.

para.tab: Apart from the question of the Minister misleading the Senate, I want to explore further the basis on which he has determined that statements in the report that assert that Australian officials did train these mobile units specifically for work in Bougainville are wrong. Who has gone back and double-checked the source information and on what basis has that analysis been done?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I certainly know that among the checking that was done there was direct reference back to the AIDAB coordinator of the project in Port Moresby and also specifically to the defence adviser who was involved in the project and in respect of whom it had been suggested—not in this report but in some subsequent comment—that he had been involved in military training specifically for Bougainville. That was robustly denied, as I recall it, by the officer in question.

para.tab: It is not just a matter of relying on desk officers down here in Canberra when this issue arose; it was checked in the way in which I have described. There is some inherent ambiguity in the concept of training for Bougainville when we have a situation of these particular mobile squad personnel, two or three months after going through this particular training period, being deployed to Bougainville and utilising, as I have just said, some of the skills which they have been trained in. It may well be that it is just a matter of imprecision of language that produces these apparent inconsistencies. The Australians there are very conscious that we are not in the business of training people specifically for that particular situation. For us to be involved in that kind of exercise would raise extremely delicate questions and it is no part of the nature of this exercise.

There is also a press statement, which I have only just seen, dated 28 October from the PNG Police Commissioner, Mr Henry Tokam, describing the ABC radio report by two journalists that set this whole exercise in train, with their background briefing thing, as being `misinformed nonsense'. I seek leave to incorporate the full text of that statement in
Hansard
.
Leave granted.

speech.para: POLICE DEPARTMENT—MEDIA RELEASE—ROYAL PAPUA NEW GUINEA CONSTABULARY, PO BOX 85, KONEDOBU, NCD, PAPUA NEW GUINEA
Tuesday, 28 October, 1992
COMMISSIONER SLAMS AUSTRALIAN REPORTERS
PNG police commissioner, Mr Henry Tokam, has described an ABC radio report by two Australian journalists as "misinformed nonsense".

Mr Tokam was responding to claims made by journalists Stephen McDonell and Mathew Brown on the ABC's Sunday program, "Background Briefing" last weekend, when they alleged, amongst other things, that Australian aid funds were being used to train PNG police to fight on Bougainville.
He said that McDonell and Brown had proven their ability to mishandle the truth from the moment they stepped foot in Papua New Guinea.
"Both men breached PNG visa and immigration regulations when they entered the country posing as university students travelling on a tourist visa—that was their first line.
"They continued their deception on arrival in Mt Hagen when they approached members of the police service there, who accepted them on face value, taking them into their confidence.

Commissioner Tokam said that he is disgusted by the underhand, unethical approach used by the two journalists who throughout their interviews with PNG police, asked leading questions of them and even went as far as suggesting answers to their own questions when the desired reply was not forthcoming.
"They used their command of the English language to take full advantage of National PNG policemen to whom, English is a third or fourth language, effectively putting words into their mouths.
"They have attempted to weave a web of intrigue into the fact that PNG police receive what they term as `paramilitary' training.

"Police of the Special Services Division, as in other police forces, including some of those in Australia, receive this type of training to improve the level of command and control of the unit when deployed in rural situations, which may or may not, include service on Bougainville.
"There is nothing secret or sinister about it, the level of training would be about the equivalent to that taught to school cadets in Australia and in other parts of the world.
"With regard to firearms, this police service is not equipped with the M60 General Purpose Machine Gun, it never has been issued with them, nor will I condone the use of such a weapon by police.

Mr Tokam said that he fully supports the AIDAB-RPNGC Development Project which is providing useful infrastructure development and training for all of the 5000-strong Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary and not solely for the training of the Special Services Division which comprises only eight percent of the total force.
"What these two journalists so clumsily reported on is just a very small segment of the overall project.
"If they had the courtesy to properly identify themselves instead of resorting to subterfuge they could have been afforded the opportunity to report more widely and factually.
"As it is, their presentation is a lattice-work of lies, innuendoes and half-truths.

"One can only wonder at the hidden motive for the thrust of their report and their attempts to discredit the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary and the AIDAB Development Project, especially at a time when the current AIDAB Project Management Contract is under review and when the Bougainville situation is nearing resolution.

"These reporters are being prompted by someone, or some organisation, with a vested interest in the continuation or otherwise of the project, or with an interest in the allocation of the new management contract.
"Even BRA sympathisers cannot be discounted.
"This is yet another prime example of foreign journalists abusing PNG sovereignty and hospitality for their own ends to weave their web of deception," Mr Tokam concluded.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —If the journalists were relying on a joint review committee, which stated that the—
—No, they were not relying on a joint review committee so much as direct information they got from direct sources.
—In making the determination that the joint review committee was wrong in fact, did the AIDAB officials confer with the joint review committee and ask it for details of its source information?
—Yes, I am told they did.
—What was the source information?
—I ask Senator Hill, as I have been out of the chamber for a few minutes, whether this line of questioning is in relation to his reservation about AIDAB's evaluation process.
—Yes.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I am told that the comments about being trained for Bougainville, or language to that effect which appears in the report, were a function of the review team being told at one stage during its inquiry that officers who had been on this Australian course had gone very shortly thereafter to Bougainville and had utilised some of the skills that they had been taught. The review team chose to express that in the review report as implying that these particular people may accordingly have been trained for Bougainville, and led them to raise this question as to the appropriateness or constitutionality of that kind of exercise.

para.tab: AIDAB and my Department, having tracked back over the sequence of events and the basic information—namely, the comments and so on of the officers concerned which led the review team to draw that conclusion—have formed the view that that was a misperception by the review team of the state of play. It may be an understandable misperception for the reasons I have already put on the record—namely, the kinds of skills that people are being taught are to some extent relevant and applicable in the environment that they confronted on Bougainville. That is different from saying they were trained for Bougainville with a specifically Bougainville agenda in mind.

Moreover, I had understood that the time gap between this course and their going to Bougainville, such as it was, was longer than two weeks. But it may be that it was only two weeks. If it was as short as that, obviously it gives currency to this kind of interpretation.

The whole question of the role of the police and the constitutionality of it is clearly one for especially the Papua New Guinea authorities to resolve. It needs to be appreciated that the situation on Bougainville, although it has involved the military, still is, in a sense, a civil disturbance. As I have said in this place, it is not so much a matter of civilians giving aid and assistance to a military exercise, rather the converse of this being constitutionally described as an exercise in military assistance to the civil power to deal with a civil situation.

I just do not know how productive it is to speculate further on these things. It is not a matter of anyone misleading anyone either deliberately or inadvertently; it is just a matter of the different use of language. But we are conscious of the sensitivities involved in this matter. For that reason, in setting the terms of reference and approving the courses and so on, we tried to not in any way give rise to the suggestion that there is some nexus between this situation and the one in Bougainville.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I will not pursue it further at the moment, Mr Chairman. I will await a copy of the report, as I will await copies of the Indonesian evaluation and the Sri Lankan food aid evaluation. I would like one other evaluation—that of the National Institute for Economic Research on DIFF. I wonder whether that can be made available to me.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Again, in this case, subject to normal considerations of intergovernmental and, particularly in this context, commercial confidentiality, we can certainly do that. A significant amount of public monies are spent on DIFF. The effectiveness of that program is an entirely legitimate matter for public and parliamentary interest. But there may be some questions of confidentiality which we will just have to check. But, in principle, the answer is yes.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to hear that, because we have been seeking that document unsuccessfully. Yet I noted that its contents were relied upon in Mr Kerin's statement on aid yesterday. So the Government was clearly wanting to have it both ways: on the one hand not making public the information contained in the report, but yet asserting that the report reached certain conclusions that benefited the Government's purposes. So I look forward to receiving a copy of that report. That is the last of the evaluation matters that I want to raise.

para.tab: I want to deal with a couple of other aid matters—I will try to be brief—one of which is the telecommunications project in India. I raise that one, because we were told in the Estimates Committee—this one looks as though it fell foul of the new OECD restraints on mixed credit funding:

speech.para: As a grant project, we will be not be proceeding with it.

In further material provided after the Estimates Committee—the way I read that material—it looks as though AIDAB has changed its mind again. It now looks as though Australian funding of this will be proceeding. I therefore ask the Minister for an explanation.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I have no direct personal knowledge of this matter. All I can do is read to Senator Hill the briefing that I have in front of me. The agreement on development cooperation between India and Australia does specify telecommunications as a sector for cooperation following an official Indian Government request in October 1990 and the prolonged negotiation of terms of reference. AIDAB commissioned the feasibility study in March 1992 for a single telecommunications network management centre in India.

para.tab: Through that single centre, the aim is to transfer to the Indian department of telecommunications the key Australian developed software and, most importantly, the capacity to modify the software to suit its requirements. Such an exercise will make the Indians merely self-sufficient in their ability to acquire additional centres. Their only external requirement would be for some consultancy and implementation assistance.

A draft feasibility study report has been presented to AIDAB. An independent technical evaluation commission by AIDAB has also been completed. This independent technical study evaluated the proposal favourably upon receipt of the revised feasibility study from AOTC. The proposal will be fully appraised by AIDAB and a decision will be made on whether to proceed to implementation. Does that answer the question, or does Senator Hill want more information?

talk.start.para: —It does not tell me what happened between the Estimates Committee and the further consideration thereafter that changed the position as put to the Estimates Committee.
—What was the position that was put to the Estimates Committee?
—That it would not go ahead.

—I will read out the information from these last two paragraphs, because apparently there is some basis on which the thing might still be able to go ahead. A tender call by India in January 1992 was for the supply of hardware and off-the-shelf software for five regional network management centres. Therefore, it differs significantly from the AIDAB project in terms of the number of centres and the fact that it does not transfer the capability to modify the software. The tender is a simple procurement exercise without a development component. However, the tender does include the centre, which is the subject of the AIDAB project.

para.tab: Telecom Australia International advises that the aid project would provide ready access to the most senior Indian officials responsible for implementing India's five-year communications plan. Under the eighth five-year plan, the Indian Government intends to invest the equivalent of $20 billion in the telecommunications sector. If Australia is to secure a significant share of business, it will need to establish a suitable profile with the Department of Telecommunications. The AIDAB project provides the opportunity to establish such a profile and Australian credibility in this field. The potential revenues to Australia from identified opportunities are expected to exceed $2 billion over the next 10 years.

All that I can tell Senator Hill from all that is what he can hear himself. A component of this package is still aid related but is very much smaller than the total project, which is largely commercial in its focus. But there is still some rational basis for aid moneys being devoted to at least a small segment of the whole for the reasons I have just indicated.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I will look at that carefully. It seems to be a way of squeezing out of what has clearly become an embarrassing situation. Our qualified part of what now seems to be a commercial project is unlikely to be able to be exploited commercially. As I said, I will look at that material.

para.tab: One of the remaining items that I want to raise is the farce in relation to the supply of compactors to Mauritius. I raise it because the Minister would now have had time to consider the matter. He was clearly not as aware of the detail of it at the time of the Estimates Committee. He might now be able to explain to the Senate why AIDAB interfered in what was a commercial sale from Australia to Mauritius of compactors, in which one compactor had already been delivered, so as to provide further compactors at the expense of the Australian taxpayer.

In other words, why did the Australian business man, who had astutely identified this business opportunity and was exploiting that opportunity in the way that we wish to encourage Australian business, lose his business opportunities as a result of Australia so generously and suddenly deciding that, with taxpayers' funds, it would provide compactors to Mauritius?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —As always, the story of this is rather more complicated than the simplistic way in which it has been described by Senator Hill. As I recall, the matter of the supply of this group of garbage compactors was raised with me by the Mauritian Foreign Minister to emphasise the importance that Mauritius attached to this. It is something that was not initiated by us but came very much from the Mauritian side. AIDAB proceeded to supply 10 garbage compactors under the commodity assistance program, which provides for the supply of particular kinds of goods and equipment, because it was developmentally important for Mauritius and in Australia's commercial interests. Let me explain why.

para.tab: It was developmentally important because Mauritius has a chronic problem with urban solid waste collection and the supply of the compactors is regarded by them as a high priority to help them alleviate that problem. The supply of 10 units under the aid program would, in AIDAB's judgment, complement and support Australia's commercial interests in Mauritius by making Australia the preferred supplier of garbage compactors and accessories to that country through familiarity with and confidence in Australian equipment.

The Government of Mauritius had requested the supply of up to 30 such compactors, but it was decided to limit to 10 the number of AIDAB funded compactors to allow Australian companies to meet commercially the demand for the remaining 20. It was believed at the time that because Industrial Containers was the only Australia company that was in the Mauritius market, it would be in the strongest position to win the aid contract for the 10 compactors, not to mention any subsequent commercial tenders that might be called by the Government of Mauritius. In the event, it proved not to be the strongest contender for the first 10 compactors supplied by AIDAB. But, if Senator Hill chooses to listen, he will hear me say that other Australian contractors were successful beneficiaries of this.

There are six or more suppliers of this equipment in Australia who are interested in the supply of it. I do not think we should be in the business of seeking to protect some individual supplier. What is important is to try to attract the business for Australia. The first 10 garbage compactors provided by AIDAB have gone to an Australian contractor and the remaining 20 will be acquired, we very much hope and expect, commercially from the Australian market. It will be a matter of normal competitive pressures to determine who gets that contract.

This is the final and important point: if we had not proceeded with the supply of 10 compactors under the aid program, the Government of Mauritius would have approached other donors, for example, the French, for the supply of garbage compactors, because it is doubtful whether the Government of Mauritius is in a position to fund the commercial procurement of the whole of the estimated 30 compactors that were needed. That would have meant the loss of most, if not all, of the market to Australia. It has been a matter of fine judgment as to how best to get a toehold in the market that would secure the biggest return to Australia over the longest period of time with the maximum number of sales. That is the basis of it.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —With respect, Minister, that answer is absolute nonsense. What happened was that an Australian contractor had already supplied one compacter, had orders in writing for a further two compactors, and had verbal orders for a further six compactors, when the Australian taxpayer intervened and took away his market by our providing compactors free of charge to Mauritius. Now you come in here and say that it was done for the purposes of providing a market opportunity for Australia.

para.tab: I respectfully suggest that the Minister would have been better off coming in here and saying `Regrettably AIDAB got it wrong; regrettably, as a result of that, this particular Australian businessman lost the opportunity that he had to provide compactors to Mauritius, and I hope that there will be better communication between AIDAB and Australian business contractors in the future in order to avoid such embarrassments in the future'. The whole thing is just an astonishing saga.

The advertisement appeared in the
Age
, looking for compactors for Zimbabwe. I do not think there is much point in continuing because, as per usual, in answering, the Minister tried, in effect, to talk his way through what is obviously an embarrassing error. That does not give confidence to Australian producers, and it certainly does not give confidence to Australian taxpayers.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I have given you the advice that I have got. Officers of AIDAB have heard what Senator Hill has had to say. I will ask them to further investigate this money. I have just scribbled out two or three questions that I would like to get some further information on myself, but I do not think it is going to be possible to do that right now.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —While the Minister is getting further information on that, I also suggest that he gets a briefing on the supply of stainless steel tankers fitted to Mercedes Benz trucks for Mauritius. He might address himself to the question whether this is the best type of aid to be providing, but I guess that he and his advisers have decided that this is good quality aid for the scarce Australian dollar. But why the top of the market? Why Mercedes Benz trucks which cost $15,000 more than the Mitsubishi model that had been found to be quite satisfactory in the past? These are failings—and I am only using the Mauritius example.
—Are you referring to the garbage compactors?

—No. I am referring to the Mercedes Benz trucks and the stainless steel tankers that were fitted, which was a different project. The Minister might also ask: why did this not go out for tender as the total value for quotes for the tankers was over $132,000? Why was all this done on the quiet? As I said, why dismiss the Mitsubishi truck which was $15,000 less expensive when I understand that that model had already been provided and all the service facilities are in Mauritius for that model? Is this not part of the problem?

para.tab: I notice that, in reading between the lines of Minister Kerin's paper on aid, it seems that the commodities provision program to Africa is now in question. The part of this problem there is that agents are appointed by AIDAB for the recipient government to acquire these goods. Therefore, the link of accountability is lost. That is why it becomes a mystery to the Minister—I can understand that—particularly in circumstances where matters do not go to public tender. In fact, if it was not for an aggrieved supplier, we would not know about the matter at all. So I am not going to ask him to respond to that at the moment. But we will ask him at some time in the future. At the same time as he gets information from the Department on the compacter issue, I also ask that he gets information in relation to the supply of these stainless steel tankers to Mercedes Benz trucks.

talk.start.para: —If there are no further matters on program 5, we will move to subprogram 6.3.
—That one could take a little time, Mr Chairman. But there is one issue that I wanted to raise on post closures. It is under 6.3 but it might be one that we could get rid of easily.
—I would appreciate it if we could get rid of matters other than the Bs. I would appreciate it if we could get rid of them, too—from the agenda, let me hasten to clarify.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I have to concede that the one I wanted to raise was not the three that had just been made in the last Budget. It was in relation to Beirut. I understand the Government's explanation for not re-opening the mission in Beirut is a security one. I have a letter from the Minister saying that the matter is under review, but basically we remain concerned about the security situation. I have heard from other sources that there is a concern about the cost that would be involved. In fact, in his letter the Minister referred to the need for around-the-clock security for staff.

para.tab: Has the Minister a formal security assessment in relation to that issue upon which he is relying, that it would be unwise from a security point of view to reopen the post at present?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —When Senator Hill says, `formal security review', this is a matter of ongoing review by the Department. There is nothing I would rather do than re-establish the mission in Beirut, for all sorts of obvious reasons in terms of effective servicing of the very large number of Australians of Lebanese origin who would welcome the provision of that service, not to mention the Lebanese in Lebanon, of course.

para.tab: It is the security problem that has inhibited us. We make our judgment on a combination of readings through ordinary diplomatic methods of the overall security situation, and a judgment about the likelihood of the situation stabilising, whether or not the Taif accords are being successfully implemented and how successful the process of establishing a working and effective government is. We make all those sorts of judgments, combined with the assessments of our colleagues, in particular the British and French, who do have missions there on the ground and who have considerable day-to-day experience of the operating environment. We have been in close consultation with them.

We have established, to put it succinctly, that their perceived security needs continue to be huge in terms of guarding services, around-the-clock provision of bodyguards for senior people moving backwards and forwards, plus the guarding of buildings and so on. Although improved, it is still a very volatile environment that exists in Beirut and one could simply not responsibly put Australian officers in there in that environment without taking similar precautions proportionate to what would obviously be a much smaller mission.

That is where the matter rests. We had all hoped that the security situation would continue to rather rapidly improve in the latter part of this year with hopefully the withdrawal of Syrian forces, the stabilisation of government and hopefully the secession of hostilities in southern Lebanon and the role of the Hezbollah and so on, all of which contributes to the present uncertainties in Beirut itself. Unfortunately those things have not happened, but we are continuing to review it.

I have been in consultation with my colleague the Minister for Immigration about the possibility as a halfway house measure of putting in place a locally engaged officer, and a driver, who would be much less exposed to a security risk than an Australia-based person in the judgment of everyone involved, including the local personnel. An operation of that kind would operate as a servicing point for liaison with Damascus and so on. That is not yet finalised to the point of announcement. I hope it is able to be the subject of an announcement quite soon.

talk.start.para: —I read an announcement that it was a post-box mechanism, really.
—If it has not been announced, I am not going to announce it now. I do not want to steal my colleague's thunder.
—He has already done it, unless you are talking about something different.
—We are establishing a locally engaged person with a driver.
—He has announced it.

—Yes, and establishing it in a hotel environment. We have the post-box function. It has been the subject of consultation with the Lebanese community here and people in Lebanon and this is perceived as a helpful step forward in the establishment of an Australian presence, which may well stop people engaging in a number of unproductive visits to Damascus and so on. They often have to do two or three trips, because of some flaw in the paper work. Hopefully, we will at least get over that. Beyond that we are unable to go further at this stage. That is regrettable. It is very much something we would like to fix, but we cannot.

para.tab: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Now that the Government has had time to reflect upon the invitation of Dr Hewson, does not the Minister agree that the people are entitled to an election which is a referendum on the worst recession in 60 years; a million Australians unemployed; a youth unemployment rate of 35 per cent; a massive $185 billion foreign debt; record bankruptcies; record mortgage rates reaching as high as 17.5 per cent; one in four families without anyone in work; 600,000 children living below the poverty line; 70,000 homeless; an increased divide between the rich and poor, Labor's definition of social justice; and an unprecedented demand for help from St Vincent de Paul, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and other voluntary agencies—in short, the appalling record of Labor's economic mismanagement over the last 10 years?

—Of course a government's record is in part an issue in an election, but the major issue in the election is what sort of government the country will be offered for the future. I wish all the people on the front bench who are interjecting had a high television profile, because then people could see the alternative which is being offered to the people of Australia.

para.tab: It is all very well for Senator Hill to read out all of those things which may be issues with sections of the community and so on. But the question which will predominate in people's minds is whether the imposition of an additional tax on most people will do anything about any of those problems.
