That will be the major issue in the election. We look forward to a contest on the basis of that, and that will happen.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether he believes that the people should also take into account the thousands of Australians on hospital waiting lists, the tens of thousands of our young who have been locked out of tertiary education, the nearly a quarter of a million families and individuals waiting for public housing, the fact that the accord has delivered lower real wages, and Labor's mismanagement in the 1980s through South Australia Inc., Victoria Inc., Western Australia Inc. and such other aspects that reflect the total failure of Labor governments, federally and in the States around Australia, during the period of the last 10 years?

—Senator Hill reveals the absence of a plot or any guile behind this question when he says that the accord has delivered lower real wages. Does the Opposition say that, having regard to the circumstances of this country, that is a bad thing?
—You have admitted it and Cook never has. You have admitted lower real wages over 10 years.
—Order! Senator Kemp!

—Rumpole, really! Every wage increase in this country has been opposed by the Leader of those opposite, Dr Hewson. In Victoria we now have a Liberal Government that came into office promising that nobody would be disadvantaged as a result of the election of that Government—and look what has happened in Victoria. Senator Hill reveals that he is not about addressing the real issues; he is about all sorts of arguments—
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of statements made by the President of the Small Business Association, Mr Peter Boyle, where he described what would happen to workers trying to negotiate with their employer under a system of individual employment contracts? Is the Government considering adopting policies which would put workers in the position where they can be forced to accept substantial cuts in take home pay and working conditions on the threat of losing their jobs?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para:
—I have a transcript here from Monday's
Lateline
program, a transcript supplied by the Parliamentary Library. The subject of
Lateline
that night was the Kennett and coalition industrial relations policies. It was said in a revealing introduction to the interview with Mr Boyle that he was the only businessman who would agree to be interviewed on that subject. During the interview the interviewer asked Mr Boyle this question:

answer.para: If you had an employee that said, no, I won't work weekends and nights, unless you pay me penalties, what would you do?

That is a very fair question. The answer from Mr Boyle is extremely revealing when one considers that the Opposition's industrial relations policy and that of the Victorian Government is to force people onto individual work contracts and require them to be conducted in negotiations between the employer and the employee on their own. What did Mr Boyle say as the representative of the Small Business Association of Australia? He said:
Well, I would seek to strike an agreement with another person that was prepared to do that and if in fact, that was legal, and this legislation—
would make it so, and if I was successful, then I wouldn't need the services of that person that didn't want to work those times.
I mean, now beggars can't be choosers and I mean that in a business sense as well as an employment sense.

We now know that, at least in the eyes of Mr Boyle, workers who refuse to accept a cut in wages are to be regarded as beggars and they are not to be regarded as having rights to choose. That may well be a revealing insight into Mr Boyle's mentality.

para.tab: The other revealing insight is that Mr Boyle is saying exactly what we have said would apply under individual work contract type agreements that are to be introduced in Victoria and would be introduced if the Opposition's industrial relations policy were to be law in this country. In other words, the policy is: the contract or the sack. That is the policy and here is the evidence from a business quarter that that is the case.

I have to say immediately that not all business people are as unscrupulous as Mr Boyle, but if those who are honourable and want to do the right thing by their employees are in competition with the Mr Boyles of this world, they will find that they are undercut in the market and they will be forced to follow. This is a low wage policy and, when one considers the consumption tax and the effect on inflation, a high prices policy as well. People who are vulnerable in the work force—migrants, women and all workers—

talk.start.para: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The people of Australia have been informed of the Liberal and National parties' policies for recovery from the worst recession in 60 years. Can the Minister tell the people of Australia and the Senate when the Government is going to release the detail of its policies so that we know the directions it is going to be taking so that they too can be fully debated? Is the alternative that Australians can expect more of the same, with a million people unemployed, which means that 55 young people go on the dole every day and 38 businesses go broke every day, as has been the case in the Government's nearly 10 years in office? Can they just expect more of the same or will we actually be able to debate the Government's policies for the future along with ours?

—In terms of recovery from the recession, we announced in February this year in the One Nation statement and, again, in the Budget of this year, a number of measures which were designed to help recovery. I am surprised at the way in which Senator Knowles's question is couched. In this dreadful situation which Senator Knowles has described, the people have had the alternative of those opposite for 12 months now, and look at what they think about those opposite. It is quite extraordinary—12 months. People such as those opposite have not been able to articulate what they really stand for, just as they have not been able to do in Victoria. Those opposite have had 12 months. They are offering something different, and look at their position in the popularity poll; look at what a great success they are as an opposition at this stage after 12 months of the GST proposal and so on!

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Button still has not answered my question. This article says that the Government is starting to develop an agenda for a fifth term, Lord forbid. But where are the policies, when will we see them, or will we simply have more of the same? That is the question. Will there be alternative policies or more of the same? It has to be one or the other.

—That is not a supplementary question. The question originally was couched in terms of what the Government had announced about these matters in relation to recovery from the recession. I have told Senator Knowles what we have said about that. Of course, Senator Knowles, as is her wont, had to preface the question with a lengthy statement about the Opposition's particular policy virtues. The sad thing is that nobody sees them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Is the Minister aware of remarks made by the Prime Minister this morning at the national family summit concerning the issue of violence in movies and videos? If so, can the Minister indicate the Prime Minister's proposal in this area?

—I believe that Australians are aware, as a result of the remarks he made last week, of the Prime Minister's concern about violence on television. In fact, he reinforced in the Caucus only a few days ago the fact that very recently he, as a parent, had to turn off the television in his own household. When he found his daughters watching a movie at a reasonable time slot at night which he said was truly horrible, he exercised parental control and switched it off. The fact is that violent movies were being shown in that time slot. But it is not only a question of television; it is also a question of film and videos.

para.tab: This morning at the Ita Buttrose conference on the family the Prime Minister made clear that he had found from what he has seen and certainly from soundings in the community a lack of confidence in the community about the M category of films and videos. It is far too broad. It covers matters from very mild violence being portrayed to those situations in which a very dramatic and traumatic amount of violence is realistically depicted.

So there is quite clearly a need to have the M category revised, and the Prime Minister has made a suggestion as to how that might be done. Certainly the M category, which is supposedly unsuitable for children under 15 years of age, is too broad and I think most parents find that they cannot have any confidence in that category. It is an advisory category anyway. It may well be that there is a need to make the top end of the M category more regulatory so that cinema operators and video store retailers and hirers are penalised if they make these videos available to those who ought not to be viewing them or hiring them.

The Prime Minister is suggesting that this matter be put on the agenda of the next meeting of the Australian Government Council—a meeting of the Premiers, Chief Ministers and the Prime Minister, which will be held, I think, on 7 December in Perth—to ensure that there is widespread political support for changes to this category. This would enable parents and, indeed, those who want to attend cinemas or hire videos generally, to accept more confidently the M category in relation to the level of violence, coarse language or sex matters that might be portrayed. I believe that this is a very worthwhile move indeed.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer to reports that the Government has decided to delay or perhaps not present at all legislation that is designed to further regulate tobacco advertising. I ask the Minister: does the Government now not accept figures that show tobacco smoking is the largest single preventable cause of death and disease in Australia today and is estimated to have caused 20,000 deaths in 1991 alone? Does he reject findings that most people who smoke start between the ages of 12 and 16 and that advertising by tobacco companies, including sports sponsorship, is a factor that influences them? If the Government does recognise the social and economic costs of smoking, will the legislation proceed before Christmas? Finally, to allay concerns about sponsorship of sporting events, particularly in rural areas, will the Government consider setting up a national sponsorship system similar to Foundation South Australia so that finances can be provided without the link to tobacco products?

—The Federal Government is committed to introducing legislation that will prohibit the advertising of tobacco products—other than at point of sale which, of course, is a State government responsibility; but the commitment is still there—and to breaking the nexus between tobacco advertising and sport and cultural activities. The fact is that the smoking of tobacco products is manifestly a cause of great disease and death within the Australian community. Whether the numbers are precisely as Senator Lees has indicated, I am not sure. But I am sure that Senator Herron would agree with that particular proposition.

para.tab: The Government intends to proceed with legislation to achieve those objectives. At the moment there is a deferral to allow further consultation to take place. But the commitment is certainly there so far as the Federal Government is concerned; the legislation will proceed.

As to the final question about whether some sort of national sponsorship or foundation system might be established, I believe that the Government will be giving sufficient time to sporting organisations to make alternative arrangements. This will enable alternative sponsorship to be sought by sporting organisations rather than setting up a foundation along the lines of the Victorian or South Australian models.

talk.start.para: —I will not ask Senator Tate a question about the compulsory eating of mung beans and the like, but I will ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a question in the following terms: would the Minister inform the Senate about the role Australia will be playing in the preparations for the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the United Nations?

—As honourable senators will no doubt be aware, the UN will be celebrating its fiftieth anniversary in 1995. The UN has recently established a preparatory committee to oversee all the arrangements for that anniversary, and I am very pleased to advise the Senate that Australia's permanent representative to the UN, Ambassador Richard Butler, was elected unanimously to chair that preparatory committee for the fiftieth anniversary. That does reflect very highly not only on Australia's standing but on Ambassador Butler's personal standing in the United Nations as well as, of course, continuing the fine tradition that Australia has established in terms of its commitment to the UN, going all the way back to Doc Evatt in 1945.

para.tab: I think it is worth making the point that the fiftieth anniversary will not just be an occasion for celebrations—although it will certainly be that—but will provide a major focus for progress on key issues affecting the efficiency of the organisation, including placing the UN on a more secure financial footing; restructuring the membership and operation of the Security Council so that it does more accurately reflect present global power realities—not those of the post-World War II era; and ensuring that it is better able to avert human tragedies, such as those we have seen this year in Somalia and the Balkans.

It is clear that the UN, certainly in Australia's judgment, is going to have to develop a very considered rethinking of its position in the whole peace and security area, not only in terms of creating a capacity, where necessary, for collective intervention in extreme cases, not only for creating a more effective capacity for providing collective assistance by way of peacekeeping and so on for the many situations that, unhappily, are likely to arise in the future, but also—and this has been a particular Australian preoccupation—creating a better preventive capacity through the measures in the area of preventive diplomacy, or so-called peace-making, through an intensified effort on arms control and disarmament issues and also through much more concerted international action on non-military threats to security, such as famine, poverty, natural disasters and environmental degradation.

All of these areas—and this is the point of what I am saying—are likely to feature prominently in the agenda for the preparations for the fiftieth anniversary because many countries around the world are looking for major achievement in those areas and see the 1995 anniversary as being the target date for that. I am very confident that, as a result of Ambassador Butler's election to chair that preparatory committee, Australia will be in a particularly good position to continue the significant contribution we are already making to all those aspects of the UN's agenda, and it is a very important feather in Australia's cap for us to be playing this role.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Government endorse the proposals of the ACTU's Bill Kelty and the Victorian Trades Hall Council's secretary, John Halfpenny, for continued industrial disruption that they have signalled will plague Australia and Victoria for months to come, despite the fact that more than two-thirds of Australians surveyed in a poll this week strongly disapprove of such action?
—It is not, I believe, for the Government to endorse policies adopted by sections of the trade union movement in relation to particular circumstances which exist in the State of Victoria.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer, which seems to fly quite in the face of his Prime Minister's response to this matter when he endorsed the strike action yesterday. I ask: what effect will this industrial sabotage have on Victoria and on Australia's prospects for economic recovery? Can he advise the Senate of the costs of yesterday's strike in terms of lost production and lost employment and income to workers?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In light of the point of order consistently raised by Senator Alston, can I ask you to determine by what manner that is a supplementary question to either the question that was asked or the answer that was provided? It relates to neither.
—Order! The Leader of the Government was asked a question about industrial disruption. We have been very lenient in allowing supplementaries and therefore I will allow it.

—If Senator Short would like to construe what the Prime Minister did as an endorsement of yesterday's events in Victoria, I think that is a very loose interpretation. What the Prime Minister said was that he clearly understood why this series of events had happened. In regard to estimates of the cost of yesterday's industrial action and any other industrial action which Senator Short refers to—it may have been foreshadowed; that is uncertain—I suggest the honourable senator phone his friend the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett; he will have all the figures.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister able to advise the Senate on progress which has been made since his joint announcement with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade of the Federal Government's determination to help fund an international television service targeted at South East Asian regional centres?

—I thank Senator Loosley for his continuing interest in this matter. As I recently outlined to the Senate, the Government has agreed to provide the Australian Broadcasting Corporation with a one-off allocation of $5.4m towards the establishment of what will be known as the Australian Television International Service.

para.tab: I informed the Senate at the time that the service would be targeted at Asian regional countries and would be transmitted from Darwin via Indonesia's Palapa B2P satellite. I have now been advised by the ABC that it has signed a three-year lease for a transponder on the Palapa satellite which will begin on the date the new service begins. The ABC has been investigating a number of options regarding the satellite up-link facilities for the service. Originally, it thought it might be able to lease them.

I am now advised by the ABC that it has decided to construct its own up-link facilities on the ABC premises in Darwin at a cost of around $600,000. Construction work is expected to begin late next month. It is anticipated that the work will be completed by late January for a service launch in February next year. A staffing plan has also been developed for establishing the new service. The Television International complement will include 10 transmission and production staff operating the service out of Darwin.

In addition, an ATVI news unit is being set up in Darwin with five additional positions. These developments will significantly increase ABC television's function in Darwin. As I have said previously, the ABC's move into this area is in line with a number of key Federal Government decisions in respect of defence, foreign affairs and trade and tourism, which have been taken deliberately to cement Australia's closer economic and cultural relationships with Asia. It confirms the Federal Government's belief that Darwin, and the Northern Territory generally, is a primary contact point with Asia. In conclusion, I should point out that the service will be previewed at the Asia-Pacific broadcasting union conference in Bali later this month.

talk.start.para: —Are you going?

—That is a conference which I will not be attending; I will watch it on TV. The Corporation is planning to screen a preview tape on the new service, there are plans at this stage for a live cross from Australia and a 45-minute promotional tape will also be distributed.

question.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I ask whether the Minister is aware of a memorandum prepared by the National Companies and Securities Commission just prior to the freezing of the Estate Mortgage property trusts which states:

question.para: The banks are not helpful and appear willing to destroy the trusts.

The banks appear to be using the opportunity to rationalise their non-bank competition and are contributing to a depressed commercial property market by not lending to that sector. The NCSC has advised the Reserve Bank of the consequences of this action for this trust.

When was the Reserve Bank advised of this and who was present at the meeting? Was either the Treasurer or the Attorney-General notified of the NCSC's concerns? Why was it that the NCSC and the Reserve Bank allowed millions of investors' dollars to pour into Estate Mortgage at a time when both knew that it was hopelessly insolvent? I seek leave to table the memorandum and accompanying Reserve Bank document.

talk.start.para: —Is leave granted?
—It will be later when he shows it to us.

—This matter has been raised by Senator O'Chee before. I believe he did send to my office the National Companies and Securities Commission memorandum page—I think it was a single page excerpt from a memorandum. I have, of course, forwarded that to the relevant section within the Attorney-General's Department for advice. I have followed it up every day to see how that scrutiny is being undertaken and whether there is anything further I can add at this stage to help the honourable senator in answering his question.

para.tab: I am not aware of any Reserve Bank documentation which the honourable senator now seeks leave to table. If he does table it, of course, I will provide that to the Treasurer who is the responsible Minister. It needs to be emphasised again, though, that in so far as one is speaking of the National Companies and Securities Commission, one is speaking of a time when the Australian companies and securities industry was fragmented; a ministerial council was in some sort of supervisory capacity, overseeing the companies and securities area but, quite frankly, failing to do so with any vigour, primarily because there was no true political responsibility to one parliament and one Minister responsible to that parliament.

Hence, any activity of the National Companies and Securities Commission, either in direct communication with the Reserve Bank or in some other way over the matter that Senator O'Chee raised, would not have been a matter of which the National Companies and Securities Commission needed to make the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth aware in the sense of being the politically responsible Minister. However, I am having that matter checked and will be happy to provide an answer to the honourable senator as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, is he saying that the Reserve Bank of Australia could be told by Australia's largest and most important corporate watchdog that three of the four largest commercial banks in this country were attempting to destroy the unlisted property trust market and that nobody in the Reserve Bank would tell the Treasurer? Is he also saying that the NCSC could form this view and advise the Reserve Bank, yet nobody would even tell the Attorney-General? Is that what he is saying, because 52,000 Australian investors lost their money in that collapse? What would be different tomorrow? That is the big question the Government has to answer.

—Firstly, I am not responsible for the Reserve Bank; it is a matter for the Treasurer, and I will forward any documents that Senator O'Chee provides and tables today to the Treasurer for his seeking advice from the Reserve Bank. Secondly, whilst I have said that the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth was not politically responsible for the activities of the National Companies and Securities Commission—a ministerial council was; a weak, fragmented one—it may be that some information was given and I am having that matter checked out.

para.tab: Senator O'Chee asked what is different now. What is different now is that this Parliament has established the Australian Securities Commission. There is a parliamentary committee which supervises the implementation of the legislation passed by this Parliament. This Federal Parliament and Government have taken strong hold of the companies and securities area in order to reinvigorate investor confidence, both domestic and from overseas, in order to enable the wealth creating sector of the economy—the companies and securities area—to be supported by the investing community. That creation of wealth can then provide jobs and opportunities for Australians. That is the difference now.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's statement that in opposition the ALP would vote for the GST proposal of the coalition parties. I ask the Minister: as Dr Hewson has made tariff cuts—down to negligible levels for the car and TCF industries, and zero tariffs for all other industries by the year 2000—an integral feature of the GST and Fightback package, would an ALP opposition vote for these measures as well?

—I had better address some of the false assumptions and misrepresentations in that question. First of all, as Senator Spindler well knows, we have said that in the unhappy event of a coalition government being elected, we would not oppose the GST in the Senate. Senator Spindler shifts that to saying: does that mean that anything in Fightback will not be opposed?
—He would not obstruct the principal policy. That is what he said.
—He asked the question. I do not need any help from Senator Short. I am answering it.
—You sounded as though you needed it.

—One day, after Senator Short has been there for another 25 years, he might get an opportunity to answer a question. Let us be clear about the assumption in Senator Spindler's question. Senator Spindler raised the issue of what would happen in respect of tariffs. This Government has set the parameters for tariffs to the year 1996 and the year 2000. That is a policy which has been announced by us and which would be supported by us.

para.tab: While we are on the question of tariffs, I found Senator Spindler's press release the other day quite extraordinary. Senator Spindler put out a press release which has the remarkably fascinating information in it that, according to the Government's calculations, import penetration for clothing and footwear has risen from 18 per cent to 27 per cent since 1985-86. I do not know why Senator Spindler puts out press releases on this sort of stuff without understanding what the Government is saying. The point of all that is that that happened between 1985-86 and 1991, under a regime of very high protection. I do not know what Senator Spindler's argument is.

It is very important to get the essential questions right on tariff issues. What is the cause of that increased penetration of imports? The point which the Government has made in this document, which was distributed earlier this year, is that import penetration in these industries is low compared with many other major OECD countries.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has really not addressed the question. If I understood him correctly, and I would like him to confirm this, the ALP, if it were in opposition, would oppose any tariff cuts such as those foreshadowed in the Fightback package. Secondly, with reference to the statistics, they show quite clearly that at the end of the period of tariff cuts, the penetration has increased. I have no better authority for that than the TCF industry itself.
—Order! You have asked your supplementary question. You are making a statement.

—Let me make it quite clear on this issue: I am not allowing Senator Spindler, again, to get off the hook and trot around the country saying, `If the coalition were elected we, the Democrats, would stop tariff cuts'. That is what he seeks to do. He seeks to be able to say that and make assumptions about the policies of the ALP. As I said in answer to his main question, we have announced what we regard as an appropriate tariff regime for the rest of this decade. We will stick to that because we regard it as appropriate.
—You will vary it if a by-election comes up, won't you?

—Yes, of course. We are pragmatic about these matters, not ideological. That is the answer. The Democrats will not be able to trot around making good fellows of themselves at everybody else's expense in the next election. That is what it is all about, and that is what they are not going to be able to do.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is the Minister aware that a vaccination became available earlier this year for haemophilus influenza meningitis type B, which is one of the most common fatal infections in pre-school children and which leaves some 200 children with brain damage, deafness or paralysis each year? Why has the Government refused to subsidise this vaccine before July next year, despite the fact that 20 per cent of children carry the HIB virus in their throats? Does the Government concur with the claim by the Australian Medical Association that children could die waiting for the vaccination, given that it currently costs about $40 a child?

—I have no briefing on this matter. I regard it as a matter of great importance and concern. Naturally, the pharmaceutical benefits system is designed to help Australians secure those medicines and pharmaceuticals they need in order to either ward off disease or deal with life threatening or other diseases that are impairing their enjoyment of life. I will certainly get an answer for Senator Patterson as soon as possible—if not at the end of Question Time, some time during the course of the day.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism, Senator Collins. Is the Minister aware of claims made by Senator Macdonald in the Senate on 4 November 1992 that the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and its replacement by a goods and services tax—the so-called dead cat—would benefit the tourism industry? Are these claims accurate? Would the Government ever introduce such a tax policy?

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —Senator Macdonald has, indeed, been calling on the Government to adopt such a tax. We will not be. It would be utterly catastrophic for the tourist industry. Senator Macdonald appears to be ignoring tourist operators in his own backyard, particularly in his home base of Townsville.

para.tab: The facts are that the wholesale sales tax adds about 2 to 4 per cent to the costs of the tourism industry. The coalition would replace that tax, which adds between 2 and 4 per cent to costs, with an all-embracing, whopping 15 per cent Federal Government tax on all Australian travel products and services. Tourism would lose, and lose catastrophically, because travel products and services would no longer be exempt from taxation. Tourism would be subject to a 15 per cent tax on outputs instead of a 2 to 4 per cent tax on inputs.

I am aware that this issue has been analysed and a report produced by the highly regarded firm of Ernst and Young. This report was commissioned by the tourist industry itself—which Senator Macdonald seems set to ignore—to establish, in a careful and professional way, what the impact of this policy would be on the tourism industry. In doing so, Ernst and Young carefully assessed all of the offsets of the Opposition's policies—the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and petrol excise. Ernst and Young found that the bottom line was that accommodation prices would rise between 10 and 13 per cent. These are dramatic rises which would knock the stuffing out of the Australian tourism industry, but they are hardly surprising.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, on a point of order: it is amazing, in light of the Prime Minister's support for a goods and services tax in this country, that the Minister should be answering in these terms. But, as we have objected before, this is not the time for debating Opposition policy. I ask you to require the Minister to comply with the Standing Orders and, therefore, sit him down.
—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Macdonald himself has called on the Government to adopt this proposal. I am explaining why we will not.
—On the point of order, Mr President—
—Out, damned spot!

—Mr President, I would ask Senator Collins to withdraw his imputation upon me. Anyone who knows anything about Shakespeare will know that he has reflected on me poorly. I simply will not stand for it. I will not stand for it, Mr President.
—Order! I do not think it was unparliamentary, but continue with the point of order, Senator Bishop.
—On the contrary, Mr President, if you had a knowledge of Shakespeare you may well know it was.
—I have said I did not regard it as unparliamentary.
—The point I am making is that I am offended by it and as such under the Standing Orders I want it withdrawn.
—Order! I do not regard it as unparliamentary. However, I will ask the Minister whether he will withdraw it.
—Despite many attempts to get blood on her hands, Senator Bishop has never succeeded; so I am happy to withdraw it. But she is giving a wonderful impersonation of Lady Macbeth.

interject.speaker: Senator Bishop

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I simply want to refer you to a ruling on 19 February 1987 when the then Senator Chaney said:

interject.para: For a start, it is a question which directly relates to Opposition policy . . . Quite clearly this is not a matter of public affairs within the administration of this Minister, and I would suggest . . . the question is in general out of order.
on the basis that the Minister answers only that part of the question that dealt with her portfolio and the Government's policy.
I would ask you, Mr President, to similarly rule.

talk.start.para: —In reply to the point of order, the question referred to a statement by Senator Macdonald and asked whether the Government would introduce such a policy. I ask the Minister to deal with that part of the question and not to debate Opposition policies.

—Mr President, I understand why these facts are so profoundly disagreeable to the Opposition. Ernst and Young is confirming what everyone in the tourism industry already knows. For example, in October this year the Australian Federation of Travel Agents warned that such a proposal would add up to 12 per cent to the cost of domestic travel packages.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I draw your attention to standing order 73(4), which says that in answering a question a senator shall not debate it. Senator Collins is clearly debating it. You have asked him once to stop debating the question. He has completely ignored your ruling and I ask you to sit him down.

—Order! I asked Senator Collins not to debate Opposition policies. I think he was giving the reasons why the Government would not introduce it and he had not finished one sentence before the second point of order was taken.
—One of the most persuasive advocates for why we should not adopt this policy is in Townsville. Earlier this year one of Townsville's most respected tourism operators, Mr Mike Ball, said:

answer.para: I am really concerned about the GST because after doing the figures, we have found our company will be significantly disadvantaged. We feel in the long term, it is going to be far more damaging than the airline pilots dispute, or the Gulf war crisis.
Mr Ball's fears are real and legitimate. We will not be adopting a policy that will have such catastrophic impacts on the tourism industry of Australia.

talk.start.para:
—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to his response to Senator Parer's question on 4 November wherein he quoted an article from the
West Australian
and specifically a Mr Bill Johnson, the head of JLV, who had achieved a 25 per cent increase in productivity as a result of an enterprise deal. Does the Minister agree with ACTU boss Martin Ferguson that JLV was a testimony to what could be achieved under the current system? Is the Minister aware that JLV recently donated $5,000 to an ACTU fighting fund?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —It is a pity I do not have the quote from JLV, but the managing director of this company, as I recall, said that he had entered into a workplace agreement with his unions and that that agreement had resulted in a 25 per cent increase in productivity. As I recall, the article said that it had turned his cash flow around from about $6m to $16m or some such figure.

para.tab: This is graphic change because of a workplace agreement entered into under our system of industrial relations which fostered cooperation and teamwork and enabled people to work together to achieve the objective of the company and share the rewards equitably between them. So we have, with this company, a snapshot of what the cultural change in the Australian workplace is all about under our system. It stands in stark contrast to what the Opposition is proposing to visit upon Australia should it ever gain the treasury bench in this place.

I certainly agree with the remarks of the President of the ACTU that this is a good company. I would be surprised if a Western Australian company that is exporting conveyor belt parts or conveyor belts and achieving export income for Western Australia in manufacturing attracted Senator Campbell's condemnation. I would think Senator Campbell as a Western Australian senator would join with Martin Ferguson and myself in congratulating it on its economic performance and on the fact that it is a model.

I think Senator Campbell ought to go a bit further if he is in a generous frame of mind and also congratulate the company for donating to an ACTU fighting fund, because it has a keen perception, as does a lot of other Australian industry, that we are developing in Australia a climate of harmonious industrial relations.

Industrial disputes under us are 62 per cent lower than they were during the relevant Fraser period. In fact, in Victoria the figure is 74 per cent lower if the Labor period is compared with the Liberal period that went before it. We have reduced unit labour costs, increased productivity and, internationally, our trading partners increasingly regard us as a reliable supplier.

All that is at risk if the Opposition's industrial relations policy comes into being. It is not enterprise bargaining. It is individual work contracts, it is a low wage policy, it removes human and civil rights from the workplace; and it changes industrial law to common law. All those are reasons why a number of leading industrial people in this country are saying, `We do not want it. We would like to stick with the Government's policy'.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that Mr Johnson of JLV Industries is also the Mr Bill Johnson who was the head of JLV Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, JLV Constructors? Is the Minister also aware that these companies received millions of dollars in contracts from the Western Australian Government's Energy Commission during the 1980s? Is the Minister also aware that Mr Johnson's companies were placed in the hands of receivers and managers on 12 February 1988 and still owe creditors, many of them small businesses struggling to survive, in excess of $5.5m? Would the Minister understand that many of these creditors may not share his enthusiasm for Mr Johnson's management, his enthusiasm for the system and his generous philanthropic support for the ACTU?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —Here we have the peculiar circumstance of a Western Australian senator attacking a Western Australian company. There is no imputation here that these contracts were not won fairly and were not awarded on their merits. There is no imputation here either that none of the creditors would not welcome a turnaround in the company's fortunes: the creation of a more productive climate, the ability of the company to increase its profit level and thus repay debt where and if it has occurred. I would think all the creditors of this company would say, `Well done JLV, we will now get a return on our money', if the description we have been given of this company is true. I again enjoin Senator Campbell to congratulate the change in workplace attitude in this company that enables it to come out of the red into the black, increase employment and improve opportunities for its supporting companies.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In June this year there were press reports that Australia needed to import 2,000 Japanese tour guides to cater for the increasing numbers of Japanese tourists arriving in Australia. Concern was expressed that the Japanese tour guides would displace young Australian workers—it would not worry honourable senators opposite—particularly in areas of high unemployment like Cairns. What is the Government doing to train young Australians for this vital and growing industry?

—It is true that there was some suggestion that up to 2,000 Japanese tour guides might be imported into Australia in order to serve the tourist industry. That figure was never a realistic figure, and no applications for such a number of Japanese tour guides to enter Australia have been made. These matters have been the subject of the setting up of an authority to look at the whole question of the training of tour guide operators. It has been done in a way which I believe leads to the conclusion that there is a great capacity within Australian education institutions and training authorities to provide young Australians, in particular, with the opportunity to make themselves proficient enough in Japanese to provide a service to those Japanese tourists who come here in great numbers and help Australia to earn foreign exchange through the tourism industry.

para.tab: Only very recently the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Kim Beazley, was able to announce a scheme coming out of these discussions whereby, I think it was, some 90 Australians are to be provided with special training in order to provide this service to Japanese tour operators in Brisbane, Cairns and the Gold Coast, which indicates what can be done. If that is built on over succeeding years, I am quite confident that the sorts of visa applications which were foreshadowed and about which there were such grave misgivings will not come to pass and the Australian workers who are seeking employment in this area will find that with the combination of education, training and opportunity they will get the jobs in this sector which they deserve to hold down in order to provide this service.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, if he has recovered after having been clean-bowled by Senator Campbell. Does the Minister agree with the concession that Senator Button made earlier in Question Time that real earnings have fallen under the accord of the Labor Government? Does he accept figures prepared by the Parliamentary Library—the honourable senator quoted the Parliamentary Library earlier in Question Time—which show that average earnings in the nine years of the Labor Government have fallen by some $600 a year?

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para:
—There is a massive inability on the part of the Opposition to understand how incomes actually work in Australia. Incomes are not made up of wages exclusively. They are made up of the tax take out of those wages, the cost of goods and services and the social wage provided by the Government in terms of sending back to the taxpayer services paid for by taxation. I have a graph here on page 41 of a document my Department has released. The document is called
Best and fairest
. It talks about our industrial relations system as opposed to the coalition's. We want a best industrial relations system that provides economic efficiency for the country, but we also want a fair one that recognises that people in need need a hand and need some protection. I commend this document to Senator Kemp's reading.

para.tab: On page 41 of the document is a graph called `Real household disposable income rises'. The graph shows that from 1975-76 to 1982-83, the period of the Fraser Government, real household disposable income rose by 0.5 per cent. It also shows that from the period 1982-83 until now, real household disposable income—the true measure of the purchasing power of households—rose by 1.3 per cent, almost double the growth of the Fraser period.

The honourable senator opposite can talk about a decline in real wages. The decline in real wages represents a declining cost to employers of the hiring of labour and thus represents a shift in factor shares from wages to profits. That was one of the deliberate objectives of the accord—but not to make wage and salary earners worse off. We cut taxes, we introduced Medicare, we improved the value of the social wage and we did a number of other things so that real household disposable income—the true measure of the purchasing power of households—has improved. It is almost twice the level under us as it was under Fraser.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate that the Minister has conceded that average weekly earnings have fallen under the nine years of the accord. I point out to the Minister that household disposable income, of which I have a table here, has fallen over the last 2 1/2 years. I ask the Minister again to address the real issue. Is it fair that, under the nine years of the accord, real earnings have been cut and a million people have been thrown out of work? That is the issue which the Minister now has to answer.

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para:
—I did not say what the honourable senator said I said. He should go back to the
Hansard
and quote me accurately. I did not refer to average weekly earnings. Average weekly earnings have risen. But let us not trade technical jargon here. Let us deal with the plain facts of the matter. There are no wage pressures in the labour market at present. The surest sign of that is the level of inflation in this country and the fact that we have been able to run a wages policy, for the simple reason that we have one, that enables moderate wage outcomes but nonetheless protects household disposable income, which is the critical thing. What is the coalition's wages policy—to put everyone on individual work contracts, cut wages, provide no protection for penalty rates or annual leave loadings—

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I did not ask what our wages policy is because I happen to know what it is. I was asking why a Labor Government has cut the average earnings of ordinary Australian workers and thrown a million of them out of work. That is the question I asked.

—On the point of order: once again, this is not a point of order. This is a vexatious effort by Senator Kemp to recover the lost ground he has suffered by asking a stupid question. This is a pattern that we are now seeing from the Opposition. There ought to be some rule in here to sit people down when it is clear that they have no point of order but simply have the vexatious intent of delaying proceedings. I ask you to rule that way on this occasion.
—Order! I am not going to allow debates to take place over points of order. The point of order was about relevance. The time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. It relates to a reply to a previous question on the Prime Minister's idea that the M category should be split. Has the Minister seen that his OFLC Deputy Chairman Haines has been promoting this idea for 12 months and recommended this in the September ABT report, which recommended a system which splits the M classification into two categories, with milder material in the end M range being equated to the current AO classification and thus able to be shown from 8.30 p.m. and material in the M classification which includes stronger depictions of sex, violence or coarse language being restricted to broadcasting in the unmodified form only after 10.30 p.m.? Does the Minister agree with such a split, which will mean that material of concern to parents, including the PM, will still be able to be shown at 8.30 and worse material, now unsuitable for free-to-air television, will be shown after 10.30 p.m.?

—I do not make any particular conclusion as to the precise timing or the precise content of any particular category. I certainly agree with the Prime Minister, who has divined a very real concern in the community about the inadequacy of the present timeslots on television or the present categories, particularly, as Senator Harradine mentioned, the broadness of the M category, which goes from quite mild depictions of violence to quite graphic depictions of gross, violent activity.

para.tab:
The other difficulty is that television, film and video classifications are not coherent, they are not the same; they are two different systems. There may well need to be a comprehensive system of categories which embraces television, film and video so that one can have yet a clearer understanding within the community of what these categories contain.
That is certainly a matter which the Prime Minister, the Premiers and the Chief Ministers should discuss on 7 December in Perth, because the whole point is that there is a cloudiness, a misgiving, a complete lack of confidence in the categories and the timeslots. They need to be brought into harmony and they need to have a clearer content so that parents and others can be very confident of what they might find if they tune in, or hire or go to a cinema and watch films designated by a particular category type.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. This issue has been around for a long time. My question to Senator Tate is: why has he not done something about it before this, when recommendations have been made and surveys taken which show that there has been quite a deal of concern. I come back to the question though. The issue is that if this split occurs, the Prime Minister's concern about this material being shown at 8.30 p.m. will not be overcome, because, as this report says, the lower M classification will be equated to the current AO classification and, worse still, material which has stronger depictions of sex, violence and coarse language will be allowed after 10.30 p.m. when such material is not allowed under current standards.

—I have already indicated that there is a lot of merit in the idea—and it is to be commended—that the category M be divided into two different categories. I think that will be an extremely useful way to deal with this particular problem. As to why it has not been done before, probably the short and human answer is: it is a long time since there has been in the Lodge a Prime Minister who has a young family, who keeps an eye on their viewing, and who understands the sorts of concerns which have been expressed in the community over recent months over this issue, which have been well documented in the survey which has been published recently. I believe it is because of his real personal concern as a parent—
—You are a fraud. You are a fraud.
—that we will have a very sound foundation for this change in the categories.
—Order! Senator Newman! You consistently used unparliamentary language and I ask you to withdraw it.

—Mr President, I called the Minister a fraud because proposed legislation from the Opposition has not been adopted by this Government in the 10 years it has been put up. The Government has consistently refused to adopt it.
—Order! It has been ruled unparliamentary in the past and I ask you to withdraw it.
—In deference to you, I withdraw it.
—No, not in deference to me; I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw it.
—I call Senator Button.
—Mr President, he was not on his feet.
—Order! Senator Button stood previously when I gave the call to Senator Harradine for his supplementary, and that is correct.

—I know that some people want your job, Mr President, but I think you are doing it well, if I might say so with respect. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

answer.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, in the course of the debate on the Appropriation Bills in committee, Senator Herron asked me a question about the import of baby marche shoes imported by the Spina Bifida Association of Queensland. I have had this matter looked into, as I undertook to do.

para.tab: I am advised that the Australian Customs Service sought to have this matter dealt with through a submission to the Industry Commission inquiry into aids and appliances for people with disabilities. Unfortunately, the Commission report did not provide a solution to this particular problem. Following Senator Herron's raising of the question, I inquired of Customs and it is looking into this issue.

There appear to be two ways of ensuring that baby marche shoes imported for use by children with spina bifida can be brought in duty-free. The first is on the basis of the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Organisations defined in a particular way under that Act are eligible to import goods for people with disabilities when the goods are specifically designed for those people.
The second way is to deal with it through a policy by-law of Customs. My Department and Customs are currently exploring the possibility of duty-free admission for goods

answer.para: for individuals with disabilities of this kind. I should like to thank Senator Herron for bringing this matter to my attention, and I hope he will pass this answer on to the Spina Bifida Association and that we can produce a satisfactory result as soon as possible.

answer.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
answer.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talk.start.para: —During Question Time I answered a question from Senator Campbell about a Western Australian company, JLV, in which I gave indicative figures, indicating in my answer at the time they were not accurate but they did indicate the situation. I now give the accurate figures.

para.tab:
It is said in the report in the
West Australian
that JLV's turnover has risen from $6m to $14m in the past year. It credits that jump to the enterprise deal and the implementation of quality management programs.
Might I also add to my answer by saying that in the case of this company what has happened is really no different from what has happened in the case of another company that faced creditors—

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr President: I think it is time that this be considered. The Minister is now abusing a process that has been well established to add further information if it is necessary for the answer. But this Minister is not doing that. Through the guise of providing supplementary information, he is now seeking to debate the issue and provide more material to support his case.
—You indulge in taking note of answers every day.
—And we ask for leave. He did not even ask for leave. That is not what this process is supposed to be all about and I would ask you to bring him to order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I am simply adding to my answer, which is a well established practice in this place—Ministers do it all the time. I have made more accurate the figures I gave on a tentative basis before and there is one other element of fact that I think is worthwhile to round out the answer. Surely Ministers have a chance to do that.
—The practice in the past has been to allow Ministers to make a supplementary answer at the end of Question Time. I would remind Senator Cook not to make it too long.

—On that point of order, Mr President: the practice has been that where new information has come to light since the Minister has given his answer and it is important to the understanding of the answer given, the Minister is entitled to give that information. But if the Minister simply got his answer all mixed up and got it wrong and gave the wrong impression, he is not entitled to come back at the end of Question Time and say, `Oh look, I want to have a second go'. And that is exactly what this Minister is doing, and he must not be entitled to do it.
—Ministers have been allowed to correct answers that they have given and I believe that that is what Senator Cook is doing.

—On the point of order, Mr President: the information that Senator Cook is purporting to add to his answer was put down in
Hansard
in his answer to Senator Parer's question last week. He has not added anything at all to the sum total of knowledge on this issue.
—I am afraid that is not a point of order either.

—Thank you, Mr President. All I was saying was that I gave in my answer figures which, off the top of my head, were indicative of the situation. I have now corrected those figures with the accurate figures.
—Do you mean that you misled—again?

—I indicated in my answer that I was not giving accurate figures but indicating the difference as best I could recall it. It is my bounden duty, it seems to me, to this Senate to then render those figures accurate, which I have now done in this part of my answer, as soon as possible. But there is no question of misleading or anything like this. However, if I did not do it, I am pretty sure, given the track record in this place, that someone would jump up and say that I had misled the chamber, which would, of course, have been a pathetic effort, but we have seen such efforts before.

para.tab: The only other thing that I would propose to do is add one other salient piece of information to my answer—that is, what JLV has done in this case is get an enterprise agreement so it can turn its company's fortunes around. That is exactly the same as SPC. SPC is another example of a situation where there were creditors, they then entered an enterprise agreement, registered it with the Industrial Relations Commission under our system and turned the company from being in the red to being in the black. It is exactly the same situation here.

talk.start.para: —On 5 November Senator Crichton-Browne asked a question on huskies.
—A ripper, too.

—It was a ripper. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has now provided me with an answer and I seek leave to incorporate it in
Hansard
.
—Is leave granted?
—How long is it? If it is a short one, read it out.
—I will read it out. I did not want to provoke an attack. It is a very short answer.
—I take it leave is not granted. Read it, Minister.

—While there is no scientific evidence available on the impact of the Mawson husky dogs on the Antarctic environment and ecology, there have been numerous incidents of huskies killing penguins which have strayed too close to them or of the dogs breaking free and killing wildlife. However, the honourable senator should be aware that the dogs are being removed to meet the requirement of the Madrid protocol for the huskies to be removed from the Antarctic treaty area by 1 April 1994.

para.tab: While the protocol has not yet entered into force, all treaty parties have committed themselves to implementing its provisions as soon as possible. Argentina has advised that it has commenced removing its huskies and that all of its huskies will be removed from Antarctica by the end of this summer. While the United Kingdom has not yet removed its huskies, it has advised that it is fully committed to the implementation of the Madrid protocol. The United Kingdom has also said that it does not want to be inflexible on this matter of its dogs in Antarctica and will be reviewing its position before the 1994 deadline.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crichton-Browne on 5 November 1992 relating to the decision to remove huskies from Antarctica.

speech.para: The Minister's answer demonstrates the absurdity and the nonsense into which this Government has sunk in these matters. The truth is that those husky dogs have been at the Mawson base in Antarctica since 1911—80 years.

talk.start.para: —Not the same dogs, surely. They would be very old dogs.

—They might be their grandchildren. This breed of dogs has been there for 80 years, with absolutely no empirical or real evidence of any damage to the ecology or the environment. If it is being suggested they should be moved to Australia and then shipped off to the United States because some penguin came too close on one or two occasions, that demonstrates the nonsense.
—Are you suggesting that we should let sleeping dogs lie?

—Absolutely. The British have made it quite clear they have no intention of returning their dogs. Their dogs will be able to live out the rest of their lives in the Antarctic. The reason we have found ourselves in this nonsense is because the Americans were determined to punish us because of our inflexibility in respect of this regime. Mr President, you will know that there are thousands of Antarctic trippers and ex-workers around Australia who feel very emotional about this because of the intrinsic links that the husky dogs have had with the Antarctic, with the Mawson base and with the people who have been down there over very many years.

para.tab: In spite of requests that those dogs be allowed to live out the rest of their lives down there, as the British dogs are, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly—that intellectual genius in the other House—has deemed that they should be brought back on a ship this year and then shipped off to the United States for reasons only she will understand.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Campbell Sen I.G.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Campbell this day relating to industrial relations.

speech.para:
After Question Time the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, added to the answer he gave during Question Time. I was not going to take note of Senator Cook's answer, but I guess he has provoked me into doing so. The issue at stake—and it was not addressed by the Minister because it is not in his interests to do so—is that a week or so ago JLV, as seen in the
West Australian
, came out slamming the industrial relations reform package of the Opposition, supported by Martin Ferguson, who is obviously very close to Mr Bill Johnson of JLV. They are obviously mates.

para.tab: I would be interested to know whether Senator Cook knows Mr Bill Johnson, how well he knows him and how much knowledge the Minister had of Mr Johnson's donations to the ACTU, or at least this donation, and how many other donations there have been. I would also be interested to know whether this Minister or anyone in this Government had any information about the contracts that JLV received from the State Government's Energy Commission during the 1980s.

The most important fact—and the point I seek to make from the question to which I sought an answer—is that Mr Johnson may be deserving of congratulations on having achieved productivity increases, the sort of increases that I am sure all senators would like to see many manufacturing concerns and downstream processing concerns in Australia make. However, the point is that his work force might be doing well and his company might be doing well; the turnover is not an indication of how well one is doing. I am sure the Minister knows that. Indeed, Mr Johnson's company had very high turnover during the 1980s.

talk.start.para: —So did Mr Bond.

—As Senator Bishop says, so did Mr Bond; so did Mr Skase. They had very high turnovers but they did not make profits and clearly they were not very good managers of their work forces in the 1980s. That may have all changed.

para.tab: This company—totally associated with Mr Johnson, trading under the same name and still in the hands of receivers—owes the Minister's constituents in Western Australia between $5.5m and $8.5m. I have come across this information by making a few phone calls to a few people I know around Perth. They are probably people that the Minister knows, too. As soon as I mention the name JLV, they use words that I could not repeat in this Parliament because he has left a string of debts behind him. A lot of them are small businesses all the way from Kalgoorlie down to Harvey and right up to the north.

It is all very well for people to come out and criticise our policies or the Government's policies, but if someone leaves debts of between $5.5m and $8.5m—debts to many small businesses which would have had to put off employees of their own as a result of the actions of JLV during the 1980s, some small businesses, I have no doubt, which actually had to close down themselves because of having dealings with JLV—and then goes ahead and takes a high profile as some sort of successful entrepreneur, attacks the policies of the coalition and also makes a donation of $5,000 to the ACTU fighting fund while owing thousands of small business people around Western Australia over $5.5m, that represents the hypocrisy of the issue.

It is interesting to see that Senator Cook used this firm and Mr Bill Johnson as an example of the fine practices that his policy, in his words, creates. It is not a good example to use because this company has left a trail of destruction behind it. I think it is totally hypocritical. It is an insult to the people to whom it owes money to donate $5,000 to Senator Cook's friends in the ACTU before it pays off all of those other creditors. Let it donate as much as it wants but let us get it to pay that $5.5m back first.
(Time expired)

speech.ministerial: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT
speech.speaker: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

talker.name: Senator COOK
talker.role: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

talk.start.para: —Leaving aside the obvious envy that the Opposition feels that a company director may or may not be a close friend of Martin Ferguson, the President of the ACTU—as if that were a crime in this country—and leaving aside the issue that has been raised by inference that this company got contracts from the State Energy Commission in Western Australia, which was put blandly, but inviting us to draw the inference that maybe something wrong happened here when there is no such case or evidence to support it at all, and that there is no evidence to say anything else than that this company won contracts fairly in an open tender situation, let me turn to the point of the motion by Senator Campbell to take note of my answer. It is a quite extraordinary one. I added to my answer at the end of Question Time. I drew the parallel between SPC—the Shepparton Preserving Company—and this company, JLV. Let us go back and look at what happened in the case of the Shepparton Preserving Company, SPC.

para.tab: The situation was that the members of that company, a growers collective, found that its management, during the heady days of the stock market boom, had overspent the capital of the company. It faced creditors across the board and needed to close its doors; it was going to shut itself down. The shareholders of that company dismissed the management and appointed a new board. That board negotiated with its work force an enterprise agreement which was later registered under the Industrial Relations Act of the Commonwealth. It was a genuine workplace agreement. That meant that the company was able to grow its way, as a company, out of debt into profit, maintain its employment and continue to put its quality product on the market.

If I accept unchecked the word of Senator Campbell—and I say straight away that I have never found Senator Campbell to be someone who misleads in this place; I cannot say that that is unequivocally true of some of his colleagues, but in his case I can say it—there are creditors of this company worth between $5.5m and $8.5m in Western Australia. This Government does not support anyone—and nor do I—welshing on his or her obligations to suppliers of a particular company or avoiding obligations to creditors. Nothing in my answer suggests that we would or do. If there is any generosity or human spirit in this chamber, that will be freely recognised across the chamber.

This company, which is in a similar situation to SPC, has negotiated a workplace agreement with its work force. Productivity has grown by 25 per cent. It is now looking at a more buoyant future. That is exactly what SPC did. It put this company in a position where it can pay back the debt. I have no compunction in saying that that is what it should do if there are creditors of this order in the wings.

It is a matter for applause and approval that an Australian company, which is up against it while Australia is coming out of a recession, is negotiating with its work force, is getting a higher productivity environment and is growing the fortunes of the company and bringing itself out of the red into the black, can now pay back the debt. All those companies that Senator Campbell has referred to that may have been otherwise hurt will not be; they will be saved.

That is exactly what we are talking about with workplace reform. It is happening under our Government. The Opposition cannot understand—and John Howard will not even allow it—that these things do happen and that one does not need to go about cutting people's wages, denying them their industrial rights, cutting out their access to the Arbitration Commission and taking them off awards. If one works with people, one can achieve results. If one works against them, one will achieve confrontation.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Very simply, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is the Minister who has been trying to defend the indefensible. Senator Campbell made out a very simple and plain case. Firstly, the Minister chose to use this company to highlight a policy which he said was introduced by the Government to allow for the restructuring of companies. Secondly, he said that this company was attacking Liberal Party policy because our policy would be bad for the company. Thirdly, this is the company which made a donation of $5,000 to the Minister's mates in the ACTU. It is well to remember that the Minister is a former trade union official and is still a card carrying member of the BWIU. Fourthly, it has left behind a trail of $5.5m in debt and families who have had their lives destroyed.

para.tab: If the Minister had one ounce of decency in him, he would take the $5,000 from his mates at the ACTU and give it to some of the deserving families who have been ruined by the actions of the people in this company who the Minister tends to hold up and say, `Are they not a splendid lot'. The Minister will be judged by the company he keeps. Birds of a feather flock together.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Kemp this day relating to average weekly earnings.

speech.para: The answer that Senator Cook gave to my question goes to the nub of one, if not the, key element of the industrial relations debate in this country, which is: how can we best improve the living standards of ordinary Australians? How can we increase real earnings?

para.tab: Mr Acting Deputy President, you may recall before the last election that Mr Keating indulged in the politics of the big scare and the big lie that we have seen so often. Guess what was going to happen under the John Howard policy in the last election? Real wages were going to explode. That was the big scare tactic. Senator Evans, who is in the chamber, will well recall Mr Keating tramping the country saying, `Do not accept the industrial relations policy of the coalition because there will be a wage break-out'.

This time, the Government is running the reverse in the big scare program, which is, `Do not accept the IR policy of Mr Howard because it will lead to a cut in real wages'. To put all this in perspective, we now know after some 10 years the results of the much vaunted wages policy of the Keating Government. What sort of results does it return for ordinary Australian workers?

The debate between Senator Cook and myself has involved looking at what has happened to living standards under the Labor Government. We do not need to talk about what will happen in the future, because we have had a 10-year model to see just how effective the ACTU bosses and the senior Labor Ministers have been in protecting and building the real incomes of ordinary Australians.

The debate centres on two sets of figures: average weekly earnings and household disposable incomes. From time to time, Senator Cook has fluctuated between whether he prefers average weekly earnings or household disposable income as the best measure. In terms of cutting real wages and what will be done to award wages and the earnings of people, average weekly earnings is the central figure.

There is no doubt that the figures produced by the Parliamentary Library show that in the nine to 10 years of the Labor Government, a government whose major aim was to improve the living standards of ordinary Australians, real earnings have fallen. The union bosses conspired with Labor Ministers and worked out this great thing called the accord. The accord is essentially a mechanism to keep trade unions in power and privilege. It is not—and the results show this—to increase the living standards of ordinary Australians. The figures that have been produced by the Parliamentary Library show that average weekly earnings have fallen.

Household disposable incomes have also fallen since December 1989. These are more complex figures. They include welfare payments, whether wives are working, part time workers in the household and a whole host of other factors. It is certainly one way of measuring living standards. When talking about the industrial system as distinct from the welfare system, one has to look at average weekly earnings. We have seen the record of the Keating Government and Senator Cook. They have not only cut the average earnings of ordinary Australians; as a result of their policies, they have also thrown one million Australians out of work. So we have seen the results of their IR policies. They have failed.
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Macdonald Sen I.D.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Maguire this day relating to the tourism industry.

speech.para: Senator Collins's administration of the waterfront reform portfolio was abysmal, as was his administration of the northern Australian portfolio. He is now obviously threatened by Senator Schacht in the communications portfolio, so he is trying to make some sort of a name for himself in the tourism area. Unfortunately, his answers today show that he is again abysmally informed in that area as well.

para.tab: He quoted at some length a report from Ernst and Young on the tourism industry. What he did not choose to tell the Senate—which is pretty typical of the Labor Party; it only quotes bits of things—is this:

speech.para: This report does no more than analyse the impact of the indirect tax component on the Fightback package. It does not take into account many of the other parts of the package, notably changes to the industrial system, the effect of the open skies policy and the impact of income tax cuts.
If one takes those into account—which Ernst and Young did not choose to do—one finds that the tourist industry will do very well out of the Fightback package.

para.tab: Senator Collins also chose to ignore the fact that from now on, under a Hewson government, people will be prepared to take holidays again. First of all, those who are still in jobs will have more money in their pockets and will be able to afford holidays again. They will not be worried about losing their jobs while they are on holidays. And as the one million unemployed go back to work and start earning some money, they will be able to take holidays again.

I point out that people on the average earnings of $25,000 with a couple of kids and a non-working spouse will have $38 more in their pockets each week after Fightback, even after they have paid for any GST on anything they buy. That $38 per week, or some $2,000 per annum, will allow them to take the holidays which they are denied under this Government.

Senator Watson interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —As my colleague Senator Watson said, most of them would drive cars to their holiday destinations and, with petrol 19c a litre cheaper for a private motorist, they will be able to afford to take those holidays.

para.tab: My time is very short, but for Senator Collins's benefit, I point out just some of the benefits of the Fightback package for tourism. First of all, seven taxes will be abolished, including sales tax, petrol tax, payroll tax and the training guarantee levy. The Federal Treasury has estimated that there are savings of over $1 billion for key sectors of the tourism industry through the abolition of indirect taxes. These include air transport at $376m, entertainment at $361m and restaurants at $318m. There are others but I will run out of time.

In relation to Mr Mike Ball whom Senator Collins quoted, Dr Hewson asked Mike Ball on 1 September to supply his figures if he thought he would be worse off under the Fightback package.
