Until now Mr Ball has refused to do so. He says that he will be worse off, but he will not produce his figures. He will not let Dr Hewson or me go through those figures with him to show him where he would be better off.

To me that shows at very best a lack of any genuineness about his claim. If he had no problem with his claim, why would he not let us have his figures? I am pursuing that and some assessment will be done. Like most others in the tourist industry, Mr Ball will benefit substantially.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have just come into the chamber, but I would like to take up this issue which is being discussed by Senator Macdonald. Clearly, he is referring to Mr Mike Ball and his major tourist business in Townsville. A challenge has been issued and Senator Macdonald has refused to accept that challenge on the basis of an independent assessment of the figures.
—I have refused to take a bet for a thousand dollars; I do not get into that sort of cheap rubbish. It is not very cheap, either.
—I thought that the intention was that there be a independent analysis.
—Read the paper and see what is happening.
—I have read the paper.
—Then withdraw what you have just said.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)
—Order! Interjections are disorderly.

talk.start.para: —Mike Ball has offered an independent assessment. It seems to me that what is needed, not just for Mike Ball but for tourist industries around this country, is an independent assessment of the impact of a GST on their businesses. It does not surprise me that Senator Macdonald is nervous about it. Quite clearly the issue is an independent assessment. No-one would want to just hand over figures to one side or the other.

para.tab: There should be an independent assessment of what a GST would do to the tourist industry in all areas of Australia, but particularly the north where there are problems because of distance. So many domestic tourists will face the choice of paying a GST in Australia when they fly north, or flying further to Bali or Fiji and not having to pay the GST. That is the issue that is so concerning the northern tourist industry. I have picked up Senator Macdonald's speech—and I am sorry if I sound a little unprepared—but I cannot understand why—

talk.start.para: —You are not only unprepared; you are wrong on the facts.
—Will you accept independent assessment or not?
—Order! Senator Reynolds should address her remarks through the Chair.
—I will withdraw any way in which I have misled the chamber in regard to anything I have said, if Senator Macdonald will tell me why he will not accept an independent assessment of Mike Ball's—
—Do you want me to accept a bet of one thousand dollars?
—What is wrong with independence?
—A thousand dollar bet?
—You will not accept an independent assessment?
—I won't accept a thousand dollar bet.
—Order! The procedure allows senators to rise to speak for up to five minutes and Senator Reynolds has the call. I ask her again to address her remarks to the Chair.

—I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for your patience. The issue has gone way beyond debate in this chamber and I simply conclude by saying that really the issue is not about a bet as such. It is about whether or not an independent assessment could be done, not relating just to Townsville or Cairns but to anywhere around Australia. I believe that independent assessments should be done and then we will find out the truth of the matter in relation to the impact of a GST on tourism.

—I would like to place on the record my concern at what Senator Reynolds had to say. To me she appeared to be promoting illegal gambling. I think that is highly improper for a senator in this place to be doing. At some stage in the future she might like to reconsider her position. To say that a senator in this place is not carrying out his duties because he will not enter into an illegal wager for a thousand dollars is really a bit over the top.
—I rise to a point of order. I claim to have been misrepresented.
—At the end of the 30 minutes devoted for this procedure, I will give Senator Reynolds the call.

—I want to reiterate the point that this whole debate by Senator Reynolds emphasises only one part of the Fightback package, namely the GST component. One must look at the whole package and the whole benefits, including the ramifications of depreciation and other features.

para.tab: If there has been any criticism whatsoever, it is interesting to trace where it has come from. Essentially it has come from those international chains which are expecting Australia to provide something that other countries with a value added tax do not themselves generally provide.

The question is: why should Australian revenue be deprived of taxes that other countries which have a value added system seek to derive through such a tax? It is unfair, unreasonable and un-Australian. As my colleague, Senator Macdonald mentioned, 86 per cent of Australian travellers will get tremendous benefits by virtue of the 19c a litre saving in fuel excise taxes. The figures demonstrate the success of a GST.

The experience in New Zealand should be remembered. Two-thirds of people were against a GST before it came in, but within one month the figure was turned around and two-thirds were in favour of it. That is testimony to the value and success of a GST. It should be remembered that in New Zealand they did not have all the benefits and compensations provided by the Fightback package. They are all a bonus as far as Australians are concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of an answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day relating to television broadcasting classifications.

speech.para: I rise simply because it may have been thought from my question that I was not commending the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for his concern about material shown on television. I certainly did not mean that at all. I have had the opportunity to look at his address to the Family Summit this morning. What I am concerned about, however, is that a number of people around the place in the Film Censorship Board for a number of years have done certain things which have meant worse material going into particular categories, and that is the problem.

para.tab: I assume the Prime Minister is no fool, but if he continues in the way he is going—it seems to be the way he is going—the material which he has complained about in the AO category will still be able to be shown at 8.30 p.m. and even worse material, material that is not even allowed on television now, theoretically, will be shown after 10.30 p.m. That is all I am raising.

I notice that in his address he has picked up the issue that not only violent films but also films that relate to coarse language, depictions of sex, drug use, et cetera in the M category should be tightened up. I concede that and I encourage him and commend him in his efforts.

I have been in this situation for a long time and I warn that the OFLC and the Deputy Chairman of the OFLC are the problem. He has been around too long—12 years in that particular job. He has clearly become desensitised from the information we have on the committees and I simply warn in that regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —At Question Time I sought leave to table two documents in relation to Estate Mortgage. I understand that Senator Tate is agreeable to my tabling them now upon my providing information as to their source.

para.tab:
The first document is a briefing memorandum produced by the National Companies and Securities Commission entitled
Estate Mortgage Managers Ltd
which was provided to me by Mr Tony Hartnell and which I understand was prepared on either 10 or 11 April 1990. The second document is a list of other documents maintained by the Reserve Bank of Australia which was provided to me by the Reserve Bank pursuant to a freedom of information application on 26 October this year. I seek leave to table those documents.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Some senators were asking questions earlier about our procedure. I remind all senators that the time allocated for seeking leave to move motions to take note of answers given to questions that day is 30 minutes. Once a senator has the call to seek leave to move such a motion, that motion is before the Chair. After the expiration of five minutes, any senator may rise and that senator subsequently speaking does not need leave, but speaks to the motion before the Chair for up to five minutes.

speech.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I rise to speak on this report to express my outrage and disappointment at AOTC with regard to an undertaking it gave to the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies. The Senate Committee was formed after representations from members of the public concerned about access to and advertising of pornography by 0055 service calls.

para.tab: The Committee, at the end of its deliberations, made 12 recommendations. These recommendations included that AOTC adopt a code of conduct that service providers will not provide knowingly, or negligently, information on any 0055 service number which in any way may be interpreted as indecent, obscene, offensive or sexually titillating or denote sexual suggestion. AOTC was to ensure that all 0055 services that were in breach of this code of conduct would be transferred to the opt-in 0051 closed user service or discontinued. AOTC was not to allow the provision or advertising of any 0055 service which could be described or interpreted as the equivalent of R or X film or video classifications. AOTC was to undertake the introduction of immediate random monitoring to ensure contractual compliance of the message content on both 0051 and 0055 with the code of conduct.

We were assured in the Committee that AOTC agreed with us and that our recommendations would be adopted. On page 40 of this annual report, AOTC welcomes the outcomes of the Senate inquiry and states that it is adopting specific recommendations towards more stringent controls. Unfortunately, I must inform the Senate that this is totally untrue. AOTC is simply paying lip service to the Australian Senate, and this is something which all senators should find unacceptable.

I have here a page from
People
magazine, a magazine freely available to any minor. The pages are from the edition of 4 November 1992 and they contain nothing but advertisements for 0055 services which are clearly in breach of the Committee's key first recommendation and almost every other recommendation made by the Committee. I seek leave to table these pages.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —These advertisements denote sexual suggestion and they offer free PIN number access to 0051 services by ringing an advertised 0055 number. They offer `hot adult' services on 0051, which is clearly in breach of the recommendation of the Senate Committee with regard to message content and advertised standards. I would also like AOTC to report on whether or not it has commenced random monitoring of 0055 and 0051 services in accordance with recommendation No. 6 of the Committee. If so, I would like to know what the results of this random monitoring have been.

para.tab: It is equally disappointing that the Government has not seen fit to respond to the Committee's final report, tabled six months ago. It has responded to the interim report and I quote the words of the then Minister for Transport and Communications. He said:

speech.para: The Government shares the concerns of the Committee that there should be appropriate standards and enforcement of those standards. . . The Government will monitor the industry closely and if there is evidence—
and I have provided evidence—
that the system of self-regulation is not working, the Government will take appropriate action.

The evidence is there for all to see and I now call on the Government to take the appropriate action as promised. In light of the deceit involved with AOTC's treatment of the Senate Committee's recommendations, I believe that the Senate should condemn the AOTC for its obvious lack of action.

speech.speaker: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

talk.start.para: —I would like to endorse some of the comments that Senator Tierney has made, though not all of them. I think he said that the Government had not responded to the final report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies. I think Senator Tierney said that that was six months ago.
—Our report.
—I think our report was tabled in June. So although it is not yet six months, I think it is timely to remind the Government that it is time that we received a reply.

para.tab:
In regard to the general issue that Senator Tierney has raised—he has already raised it with the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies—we are in the process of sending a letter to Mr Holmes, the Secretary of AOTC, expressing our concern. I have a copy of the amended letter and, with the Senate's permission, I would like to read it into
Hansard
. The letter reads:

speech.para: Dear Mr Holmes,
The Committee is concerned about a reported breach of your standards with regard to 0055 and 0051 telephone messages.

One 0055 number advertised on late night television in Melbourne was apparently used by the service provider to hook customers into 0051 services. This was done by a series of women who started titillating comments on a particular theme and then invited listeners to call a series of 0051 numbers for `better' versions of the same themes. Advice was also given on how to `short cut' the processes set up for becoming 0051 subscribers.
This is in clear breach of the recommendations that our Committee made, and I thank Senator Tierney for bringing this to our attention. It continues:

Other 0055 numbers currently available apparently offer `your own tape' of adult themes, or linked to so-called `X-rated' 0051 numbers (despite this Committee's recommendations that 0051 services not provide X-rated material).
The Committee members would like to assess the transcripts of the following telephone messages:

In view of some of the material that Senator Tierney has just handed to me and which I believe has been tabled, clearly this practice is much wider than we perhaps had first thought. Therefore we need to call on AOTC to take action urgently. My letter concluded:
We need to expedite this matter in time for our next meeting at the end of November.

We will then be discussing this in detail. I hope we will get very firm answers from the Chairman of Telecom. I hope we will be told that Telecom will stop this practice, whatever it is and however prevalent it is, immediately. Telecom has given the Committee assurances. As Senator Tierney pointed out, Telecom in its annual report has said, `Look, this was a problem, we have fixed it, don't worry'. Yet today we have the same old story with a magazine and the same old problem on which our Committee worked for more than 12 months. Members of the Committee are very disturbed about this matter and I thank Senator Tierney for raising it. The Government has a little more time to respond officially within the time limit.

talk.start.para: —I rise to join my colleagues Senator Tierney and Senator Reynolds on this issue. Although they are members of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies and I am not, I am incensed to see that the Committee's recommendations are being so flagrantly flouted. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you know, I was very heavily involved in petitions being brought to this chamber by citizens who were concerned about the 0055 sex lines.

para.tab: I know that there is widespread concern about this issue. That concern is not held by just one political group or one ideological group in this community. I would have expected that the recommendations that that all-party committee came to would have been respected by a body like AOTC, which deals with the 0055 and 0051 telephone numbers. In my view, it is totally unacceptable, anyway, for a public utility, as that body still is, to be indulging in making these sex lines available.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is talking about violence against women. Here is a golden opportunity for him to demonstrate that he is prepared to take strong action. It is within his ability to deal with AOTC. The Government has allowed this issue to drag on for far too long. When I first raised the 0055 telephone issue, neither Mr Beazley, the then Minister for telecommunications, nor Ms Fatin, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, took the slightest notice of it. It was only after they started to realise there was widespread concern in the community that eventually we started to get ministerial letters which reflected some interest in the matter.

The Senate Committee has done a great job. It just makes me so mad to think that its recommendations, firstly, have not been answered speedily by the Government and, secondly, have been so widely flouted by the AOTC.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I would like to add a few words as a member of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies and as the senator who moved the amendment to the telecommunications legislation relating to this issue when it was previously before the Senate. At that time a decision was taken to establish the Committee. The Committee took evidence over some time—I cannot remember; I think probably over six months at least—and it came up with, as has been said, a recommendation supported by all parties and Independents. I will put it this way: it was a bipartisan recommendation. It was clearly the intention of Mr Holmes from the AOTC to ensure that these recommendations were carried out. I am sure that that was his view, and I am sure that it was AOTC's view.

para.tab: Now the official annual report, signed by the Chairman of AOTC, Mr David Hoare, has been tabled in the Parliament. This important document reports to Parliament. What does that document say? It says:

speech.para: The Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies delivered its final report in May 1992 in relation to recorded telephone information services.
We welcomed the outcomes of this inquiry, and are adopting specific recommendations towards more stringent controls on message content and advertising standards for both the 0055 and 0051. . .

Clearly, that is not the case. I believe that this is bordering on a question of privilege, because this is a Senate select committee. It is very serious if an authority such as this says one thing in its annual report and does something else. I hope that it is just a matter of some breakdown in communications somewhere around the place.

para.tab: I believe that thousands and thousands of members of the public were very relieved when the Senate Committee came down with its recommendations. They were very relieved and appreciative when the AOTC adopted those recommendations. There was a lot of goodwill towards AOTC—not least, I might mention, amongst employees of AOTC who were rather concerned about this situation. I hope that that goodwill is not destroyed by AOTC not implementing our recommendations.

I do hope and expect that AOTC will make good what it has said in its report and what it said to the Committee about intending to take this action. Of course, as has been said, government and the Parliament can adopt alternative measures. But I believe it is in AOTC's best interests to honour its commitment and ensure that the recommendations of the Committee are properly and fully carried out.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

speech.speaker: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: This is one of the saddest and most melancholy duties I have had to perform in 14 years in the Parliament. The loss of the Air Force Boeing 707 two weeks and a year ago in Bass Strait cost this country five fine lives; five families suffered the grievous loss of losing a husband or a father in the prime of their life. At a lesser level, we lost an aircraft, and the RAAF, which has enjoyed a very high professional reputation as a professional air force for the last 30 or 40 years, has suffered quite a blow to its reputation.

para.tab: It is very painful for me to say this, but it must be said: this was an accident that should never have happened. The RAAF document is only a summary of the inquiry into the accident. There is a great deal in that summary of interest to the Parliament. Paragraph 2 on the first page states that the pilot in command was demonstrating a flight sequence `which he had personally devised'. On page 2, under the heading `Causes', it states:

speech.para: The inquiry process concluded that the two principal causes of the accident were that:

a.the instructor and captain of the aircraft devised a demonstration of asymmetric flight which . . . was inherently dangerous and which was certain to lead to a sudden departure from controlled flight, and he did so without appreciating that central fact; and
b.the demonstration having been conducted and the aircraft having suddenly departed controlled flight, the crew failed to recover the aircraft before it crashed into the sea.
Further on, the summary makes reference to:

. . . deficiencies in the acquisition and documentation of B707 operational knowledge and the absence of effective mechanisms to prevent the erosion of corporate B707 operational knowledge during periods of high pilot resignation. . .

Briefly, what happened is that the pilot closed down two engines on the one side, allowed the air speed to decay and it is alleged—although it is not mentioned in this summary—that there was a probable lack of rudder authority because the rudder boost was not in and the pilot could not counteract the yaw of the two engines operating on one side. The airspeed decayed and the aeroplane then went into a flick roll. If anyone has ever been in a flick roll manoeuvre, they would know that they just happen automatically and with great rapidity. In that flick roll, which occurred at a very low level of 5,000 feet, there would not have been time to recover, even had the pilot been able to, and very probably the aircraft suffered structural damage in the flick roll, which is quite a violent manoeuvre.

para.tab: I can remember in 1959 when the first Boeing 707 came to Europe. It was a Pan Am aircraft and was demonstrating stalls over France; it threw an engine off. It was not unusual that No. 1 engine was thrown off by accident. Years ago, when the KC135s—which are basically very similar to the 707—were introduced into the United States Air Force service, there was a series of fatal accidents through precisely the same causes: asymmetric flight, decaying airspeed. That was 30 years ago; the same accident was repeated a year ago, and it is absolutely inexcusable.
The conclusions contained in the summary state that the accident was the result of the actions of the aircraft captain. That is qualified later on when it is stated that:

speech.para: . . . the general circumstances relating to the causes of the accident mitigate the degree of responsibility for the accident attributable to the captain.

That is rightly so; the captain was never provided with the training, the manuals and the documentation for the endorsement he was doing. That is absolutely inexcusable. It is very wrong to see this accident, as the summary does, as a failing of the pilot in command alone. The real reason for the accident, as the summary states on the top of page 3, is the relatively high resignation rates of the mid-1980s which took so many experienced pilots out of the Air Force. We have some experienced pilots left, but we do not have enough. We have a degradation in capability. I disagree very much with clause 10(f) in the summary, which states:
. . . while many persons contributed unwittingly to the general circumstances relating to primary and contributory causes, none was negligent.

That is not true; the senior officers who did know better must accept the responsibility for the degradation in training procedures which let this accident come about. One can hide accidents in the Army and Navy, but one cannot hide them in the Air Force where a very high level of technical skill is involved. This is a consequence of the reduction in the Defence Department vote, and the Government and the Ministers ought to think about that because it could well have been the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in that aircraft or senior members of the Cabinet. This accident exposes very serious deficiencies in the Air Force training procedures. It is a tragedy that it has happened; let us learn from it and let us take immediate action to correct it.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak briefly on this summary of the inquiry into the accident involving No. 33 Squadron. Senator MacGibbon has gone through in some detail the matters spelt out in this desperately sad summary of the inquiry into the accident of the Boeing 707 near East Sale on 29 October last year. As he said, it would appear to be suggesting that we should be looking at pilot error as the cause of this accident. The principal causes are deemed to be that the instructor devised a demonstration which was inherently dangerous and did so without appreciating that central fact, and that the crew failed to recover the aircraft before it crashed into the sea. Under the heading `General Circumstances' in this summary, it states that:

speech.para: . . . the existence of several factors which heightened the possibility of an accident or serious incident arising from inadequate professional knowledge . . .

You, as a doctor, Madam Acting Deputy President, can be struck off the roll for inadequate professional knowledge, but you would expect your instructors in your medical school to have provided you with professional knowledge that was adequate to protect your patients. As Senator MacGibbon just said, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country could indeed have been a victim of this inadequate professional knowledge. There are a number of other detailed matters in the summary which suggest that there is a need for improvement in the preparation of crews training on B707s.

para.tab: On a number of occasions in recent years, senior Air Force officers have expressed to me their worries about the training of 707 pilots, mainly because they claimed that people were being posted to these positions too early in their professional lives; they had not yet had sufficient professional experience in order to undertake the training. This was a direct cause of the heavy wastage during the 1980s of which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would be well aware and about which Mr Manfred Cross's committee reported in such detail.

None is deemed to have been negligent. I would say the Federal Government stands condemned for negligence because the accident has to be directly related to the amount of training time given to these people who are promoted, perhaps, into these positions earlier than they otherwise might have been because of the wastage rates. The Federal Government has to be condemned for the reduction in flying time, as it is for the reduction in exercise time and steaming time for the other two services.

More extensive education of all RAAF multi-engine pilots is one of the recommendations contained in this summary. But does that really mean that it is finally acknowledging on paper, in a very oblique way, that there should be more training hours? Why is that not spelt out? We know that there is this gap in experience level in all three Services after the massive wastage in the 1980s. Why is the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) not here to make a statement about this very important summary? I wrote to the Minister on 13 November about the accidents that were happening in the Air Force and the Army expressing my concern, stating:

speech.para: It is of great concern to me as to whether these accidents are found to be due to human error either on the land or in the air and if so, how much they might be due to the long term effects of wastage of personnel which we have suffered over recent years. There is still cause for concern that as a result of that wastage some people may have been posted to positions for which they didn't have the necessary experience.
The Minister responded in December, saying:

. . . it is fair to say, at this stage, that the general lowering of experience levels amongst aircrews in the late eighties has not been established as a significant factor in the majority of the accidents experienced over the last two years.

Is he prepared to acknowledge now that these people were being put into jobs for which they did not have enough background and for which they were being given too little training? I asked him a question on notice on 12 December 1991 about these accidents, and he said:

Air Force has suffered some increase in accident rate, but investigations into the accidents have shown no causal link between them and any reduction in training allocation. The Services indicate strongly that any reduction in training allocation has not been allowed to compromise safety standards during or after training.

What a hollow answer that has to be. We know that there has been a cut in the Budget because of Mr Beazley's misallocation of Budget resources. That is why the Opposition is determined that there will be a change, and that there will be increased expenditure on training, and opportunities for people for flying hours, steaming hours and exercise time. It is to save lives.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)
—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:
Audit Report No. 5 1992-93 Project Audit Australian Taxation Office—Electronic Lodgment Service
.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: The electronic lodgment is a further extension of the self-assessment system, a process that relieves the Australian Taxation Office of re-processing information from hard copy to its computers for the purpose of producing an assessment or a refund. The report before the Senate, Audit Report No. 5, is the first evaluation by the Australian National Audit Office of the new electronic lodgment service. We have to acknowledge that it has been a successful innovation.

para.tab: Furthermore, it is pleasing to note that not only was there a high degree of cooperation with the audit team, headed by Margaret Innes, but also the outcome was praiseworthy of the Taxation Office's implementation of the electronic lodgment facility. I believe that the degree of cooperation evident here in this particular project audit will erase some of the memory from earlier this year when there appeared to be a reluctance by the head of the Tax Office, Mr Boucher, to be subject to an audit at that time by the Australian National Audit Office. Due to tremendous pressure, that decision was reversed.

The electronic lodgment service enables taxpayers to transmit tax returns as electronic records to the Tax Office for processing on its own computers. The main purpose of electronic lodgment is to expedite the Tax Office's processing of returns. In the 1991-92 processing year, 4.7 million individual tax returns were received through this medium, with approximately 95 per cent of refunds being made within 14 days.

However, not surprisingly, I wish to take this opportunity to raise some questions. Fundamental questions of privacy need to be addressed. The tax agent and the Tax Office are both agents of the taxpayer in respect of the one transaction, which seems to contradict fundamental principal and agents arrangements. There is no uniform system within the Tax Office of checking across what is a very decentralised office system nowadays. Indeed, the Audit Office recommended that there be a national audit and checking of standards to ensure consistency, and to ensure that tax returns held by tax agents do match the records submitted through the ELS. It was indicated that this checking should be done on a sample basis at least.

A further problem is that not all taxpayers are necessarily aware of the conditions under which their tax returns are being processed, and the mechanism that is put in place to protect the privacy of the personal and taxation information recorded on the returns. There is a further deficiency in that the Tax Office software does not at the present time detect internal inconsistencies, omissions or certain inaccuracies. We are told that the cross-check process is still at least two years down the track. Another problem is that assessments can be issued under this medium without a signed return.

Finally, a further problem is that the medium is so limited as to provide very little information to tax auditors to meet their requirements for audit. Generally, additional supplementary information must be obtained from the tax agent and the taxpayer. It is part of this process of removing responsibility and work from the Tax Office to the individual taxpayers.

As with all automated systems, data inaccuracies can occur as a result of incorrect data input, deliberate or inadvertent modification of the data and systems failure. The Australian National Audit Office found no indication that data processed through the ELS will be less reliable than data processed by taxation officers from paper tax return documents.

The Australian National Audit Office has concluded that the ELS works effectively as a processing system, and has been a successful development for the Taxation Office in terms of staff savings, increased speed of processing and acceptance by taxpayers. However, no evaluation seems to have been made of the cash flow consequences of this new service. I would imagine that tax agents will tend initially to put through the ELS system those returns that will have a refund, but delay returns where further payments are required by taxpayers to the end.

I wish to record my satisfaction that the Tax Office has finally restricted the service to registered tax agents and Australia Post in order to preserve a greater degree of privacy and uphold the provisions of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. We all know that computer bureau networks are not governed to the same degree by privacy legislation.

It is important for listeners to this broadcast to be aware that the Tax Office does not contend that the electronic record is the legal tax document; it is merely the electronic record of the legal document which is held by the tax agent. Tax agents transmit the tax return information to the Tax Office, rather than an officer of the Tax Office keying in the information from hard copy received from the taxpayers or through their tax agents. Legally, the print-out held by the tax agent will, therefore, be the document which may be subject to penalty or litigation. In fact, the Australian Government Solicitor has advised that the tax agent is the registered Commissioner's authorised agent for this purpose.

There are a number of legal issues, which no doubt my colleague Senator Bronwyn Bishop will wish to explore, regarding the legality of some of those arrangements, because they are somewhat unusual and have yet to be tested in the courts. This whole arrangement is one of facilitating and reducing costs to the Tax Office and putting further responsibilities onto the taxpayer and the tax agent. The real problem of tax uncertainty in this country lies not necessarily with tax administration, although in some areas there are some unfortunate flaws, but with the law itself.

We have too many tax laws which are incapable of consistent interpretation. I suppose the worst area for this is capital gains. There are too many tax laws which create excessive compliance issues. This Senate is about to consider further complications relating to car parking. People will just have to go out and physically measure how far their office or building is from the nearest car park.

What about the problems of people with disabilities—they are not taken into account—who park behind the office building? What about the problem of whether it is the nearest route to drive or walk? What about the problem of one-way streets? What about the problem of a building being on one side of the street and the car park on the other?

There are also difficulties with case law precedent. Judges, of course, must rely on lawyers' arguments. We have seen difficulties with the Tax Office not necessarily accepting what is recognised in the trade as accepted precedent, the Taxation Commissioner believing that, in many cases, the situations are not identical. How closely are we going to require this concept of identical or non-identical situations to upset the precedent of case law?

There is also the difficulty of what I call establishing the changing mood of the court itself—particularly the High Court, where we have seen a very different High Court in the 1970s from the High Court we see today. Then there is the inconsistency of tax rulings with a slant towards revenue protection—almost as a reflex revenue approach. Forward sales tend to be acceptable but not, for example, as I have repeatedly said, swap receipts and payments. There is a dreadful inconsistency there. There is then the unreasonable threat of part IVA. If all else fails, of course, part IVA tends to come back.

talk.start.para: —What's this got to do with electronic lodgment?

—Above all, there is a perceived necessity to protect the revenue base; but the real problem is with the law itself. Obviously Senator Tate is becoming increasingly embarrassed because this report before the Senate today is but another reflection—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I am not embarrassed; I am just asking whether we are wandering away from the point of electronic lodgment in the Auditor-General's report. I am simply looking for relevance to electronic lodgment.
—There is no point of order.

—As I was indicating, this process of electronic lodgment is a further extension of a system of self-assessment, and self-assessment requires certainty before the law. Certainty before the law is not possible because of all the issues that I have just enumerated and to which Senator Tate was not prepared to listen.

para.tab: I do not have anything against the philosophy of the modernisation program of self-assessment, but its implementation often leaves a lot to be desired. I did say, and Senator Tate was not listening, that this report marks somewhat of a change in the attitude of the Tax Office to audit compared with what we have seen in the past.

I indicated very clearly that this is a welcome move and one that we would support. However, we do require some attention to be given by the Government to some of the other deficiencies which I believe it is our responsibility in this chamber to outline to the Australian people and for the Government to take up. It is just not good enough to try to draw red herrings on issues that are of such fundamental concern to Australian taxpayers and which are repeatedly ignored by Senator Tate's Government. It is up to the Government to improve the system.

I put on record my appreciation of the high degree of professionalism that was demonstrated by the participants in this audit team. It was headed by Mr Maxwell Shanahan and the on-the-spot work was carried out by Margaret Innes, who is an expert in computer applications, Greig Watts and Brian McIntosh.

These project audits conducted by the Australian National Audit Office, regularly presented to this Parliament, provide a very essential link in the accountability chain of the Executive to this Parliament. I have much pleasure in supporting this report and commending those who were involved in it.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to this most important Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 5 of 1992-93 into the Australian Taxation Office, Electronic Lodgment Service, I would like to endorse the remarks that have been made by my colleague Senator Watson, as together, from the time that self-assessment was introduced into our taxation system, he and I have said consistently that what we have done is to impose a self-assessment system upon a legislative framework which was designed for assessment; and the problems that flow from that are really quite extraordinary.

para.tab: The Auditor-General, in the report, highlights one of the most important facts that flows from the way in which this adhockery has been pursued as a method of implementing the new system. On page x of the report, in the section headed `Legal basis for Electronic Tax Returns', the Auditor-General says:
The ANAO noted that the ELS is defined by the ATO as a temporary system supporting a permanent function.

speech.para: Interesting. He continues:

The arrangements supporting the interim paperless option, whereby the tax agent acts as an agent of the Commissioner for Taxation as well as an agent for the taxpayer, have likewise been described as an interim measure. The ANAO has recommended that definitive legal arrangements be put in place as soon as possible to remove the uncertainties regarding the determination of lodgment, prosecution action and recovery of penalties.
That is a most serious point. In other words, the Government has still not addressed the legal and legislative framework in which this changed system is operating.

para.tab: Several other aspects of grave concern that relate to these matters have come out of the inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office being conducted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Among the things that have come to our attention is that the Commissioner now has the power to make a public ruling which becomes binding. Indeed, in evidence before the Committee the Commissioner admitted that if he attended a lunch in Gulargambone and made a speech that speech could be interpreted as a ruling.

My colleague Senator Watson made the point that, if the law is to be respected and enforced, it must be certain. To have that particular circumstance acknowledged by the Tax Office and then to say, `Oh, but we would not do it' is not acceptable.

talk.start.para: —It is just another extension of uncertainty.

—As my colleague says, it is another extension of uncertainty; but I would say that it is another extension of ad hockery. Since this Government has been in office, I understand that we have added to the tax law something like 18,000 pages of tax legislation. Most of it is incomprehensible to ordinary Australians. Yet ordinary Australians are subject to a strict liability rule. That means that if they make a mistake they are liable to the penalty regime, irrespective of whether they deliberately made the mistake or whether it was just a genuine accident or mistake that occurred. No differentiation is made at all; strict liability applies. Indeed, from a public ruling that has just been made, the Commissioner has decided that he will retrospectively apply increased pensions, which again is unacceptable.

para.tab: This, in turn, raises another interesting question, relating to the idea that the Commissioner can make rulings which are binding—that means which have the full force of the law. In more than one forum I have floated the idea, and I have asked for it to be investigated, that rulings of the Commissioner should be done by way of regulation and should be subject to tabling and disallowance in this Parliament because they are secondary legislation and they do have the force of law. It is an idea, I must say, which has been met with some favour. Many people are interested in the concept.

The other thing that has come out of the unwillingness of the Australian Taxation Office to submit to audit is that this is the first time together with the Public Accounts Committee inquiry that the Tax Office has really been subject to full accountability. We are finding that the Tax Office demands and penalises ordinary taxpayers according to a standard which is very high, and higher than the standard it applies to itself. The Auditor-General has criticised the Tax Office for its failure to keep records properly and yet the Australian Taxation Office has the audacity to make a statement that small business does not keep its records properly.

In this report, the recommendations all go to areas where there is a need for additional attention to administrative matters. Yet, last year the Australian Taxation Office converted $61m for administrative function to salary function because it has 1,000 people on the payroll who are now surplus to its needs but who cannot be put off the payroll and made compulsorily redundant simply because of the Public Sector Union agreement. So we have had the spectacle of the Government having to bail out the Tax Office with an additional grant of $114m. If anyone wants to read the last of the Estimates hearings concerning Treasury, they will see that as we went through the Commissioner's strategy which was adopted by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) three weeks after the Budget to fill the hole that was found in the Budget, as we went through each section, which would say `There is $350m to be added to the revenue here', none of the officers were able to substantiate how and why that money was to be raised. The definitive question is: if the Commissioner was able to identify $1.7 billion of revenue that was not being collected, why was he not busy collecting it and why is he not going to do it until the year after next?

Another point was very significant. If honourable senators read the
Hansard,
they will see the admission on the part of the officers that that entire strategy was done in less than three weeks. Two senior officers—Mr Carmody, who was to be the replacement Commissioner of Taxation, and Mr Highfield—were asked to commence work on that strategy about one week after the Budget. The whole document was concluded by 16 September. To say that the work that was necessary to project those figures could be done in that time is ludicrous. Part of the statement of the so-called strategy said that it was essential to purchase additional information technology in accordance with the modernisation program. Mr Seymour, who was in charge of doing all the research work to solve the technology problems, had not been involved in any way in identifying the problem which was supposed to be identified in the strategy. He could merely say that, once they had discovered the problem, he was sure that the market could provide an answer. I am sure that the market can provide an answer, too. But if one is going to say that one needs to bring down money from the modernisation program and that that was not needed from the strategy document because the Tax Office has the right to draw down against money appropriated for the modernisation program at any time, then it was not necessary for it to be in that strategy document. Yet it was there to try to bolster the figures. It is a sad and sorry tale.

So I am not surprised that, when the first of these audits comes out of the Tax Office, the Auditor-General makes a range of recommendations regarding areas that need attention in order to protect both taxpayers and their privacy and to ensure that a proper system is working. But, most importantly, the legal framework in which the entire system operates is extraordinarily important. It is an indictment of the Tax Office that here we are in 1992—this system has been in place since 1990—and there has been no attempt to solve the problem to date.

So we are most indebted to the Auditor-General. It will be most interesting to see his full report on the Tax Office when it comes down. As Senator Watson reminded the Senate, the Tax Office rigorously resisted the right of the Auditor-General to come in and conduct the audit, saying, `Our records are not yet in order'. I do not think that the tax man would ever accept that excuse from a taxpayer. After much pressure from the Estimates Committee, the Tax Office succumbed and the Auditor-General began his audit. It will be due soon. We will be waiting with bated breath to see what he has to say.

As I said, I would like to join in the remarks of Senator Watson and congratulate those people from the National Audit Office who were associated with the conduct of the audit. We are very fortunate to have such a strong Auditor-General and team on which our whole system of scrutiny depends. If the Auditor-General were ever to let us down, the whole system would break down. So when we see the calibre of the work that he brings out, we should pay heed to what he has to say.

It is up to us, as members of the Public Accounts Committee, to oversee the implementation of his reports and to follow up on the matters that he raises. That, fellow senators and Madam Acting Deputy President, is what accountability is all about—through the Parliament to the people to ensure that we do not have a cosying up between the Executive and the bureaucracy of the sort described so eloquently by the royal commissioners in Western Australia. They said that the system broke down because the Parliament did not do its job. Here in this Parliament we take it very seriously. It is part of our job to speak on this report today. I join with my colleague Senator Watson in saying, `Well done, Auditor-General and your team—and Australian Tax Office, lift your game'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Beahan, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee F.

—I present the sixteenth report of 1992 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills
Alert Digest

debate.sub1.title: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para:
—I present the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled
Review of determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Privacy Commissioner
, together with the transcript of evidence.

para.tab: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: As the title indicates, this report is a review of the determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and of the Privacy Commissioner. It deals with the way that decisions of those two bodies are to be enforced, if at all. The reason for bringing this report in now is that events, to some extent, were about to overtake the Committee in that on 3 November 1992 the Prime Minister introduced the Sex Discrimination and Other Legislation Amendment Bill into the House of Representatives to alter the procedures in respect of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

para.tab: The Committee divided equally, in the sense that four people said that there ought to be an ability to have the decisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and of the Privacy Commissioner enforced through the Federal Court. That is the general thrust of what the Prime Minister's legislation will do, although the mechanism is a little different in each case.

The Prime Minister wants any decision of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to be directly taken to the Federal Court and registered as an order, whereas the majority's position—and it was only a majority by dint of the fact that I, as Chair, exercised a casting vote in favour of that position—is that the decisions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and those of the Privacy Commissioner which are not obeyed should be taken to the Federal Court and registered if the parties so desire, and, if they are not complied with within 30 days, then there ought to be a hearing. As I said, the Prime Minister has a system which does not leave that up to the discretion of the parties but has it immediately registered in the court.

The minority report says that there should be no ability on the part of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or of the Privacy Commissioner to make decisions at all, and that their functions should be left to carrying out conciliation. So the difference between the majority and the minority is as to whether there ought to be enforceability in terms of whatever decisions the Commission and the Commissioner make. As I said, the majority say they ought to be able to make decisions and those decisions ought to be enforceable. The minority says that they ought not to be able to make decisions, and that, even if they were, such decisions should not be enforceable, and that the function of those two bodies—the Commission and the Commissioner—should be left to simply conciliating between the parties.

We are short of time in the legislative program. I do not want to make any further remarks, although I understand that Senator Walsh, who formed one of the minority four—a minority by dint of the fact that the majority was made a majority by my casting vote—has something to say about the report.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

talk.start.para: —I strongly disagree with the recommendation of the majority that determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission should have force of law unless successfully appealed to the Federal Court. From Senator Cooney's remarks, I think the idea could have been gained that determinations are not presently enforceable. I am sure Senator Cooney did not intend to mislead anyone, but determinations are presently enforceable if they are taken to the Federal Court by the complainant. But they ought not automatically to have the force of law as is proposed by the recommendation of the majority report.
—After 28 days; it is not automatic.

—After 28 days, yes. I accept that correction. In most cases, this means that there will be an effective reversal of the onus of proof; that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, or more specifically, I expect, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, will be invested with punitive powers after following procedures which do not have any real rules of evidence, and do not provide the right of cross-examination or any real burden of proof.

para.tab: Indeed, when I put to one of the journalist supporters of this recommendation, a few weeks ago, that this was a reversal of the onus of proof, she said, `What's wrong with that?'. I said, `Well, if that's your attitude, why don't we go right back to the dark ages and reintroduce trial by ordeal, under which witches would have stones tied around their necks and be thrown into the village pond. If they drowned, they were pronounced innocent. If they survived after about five minutes in the pond, they were deemed to be witches and were burnt at the stake instead'. Heads you lose; tails you lose as well.

It is true, as Senator Cooney has said, that the recommendation provides the right of appeal to the Federal Court by the person against whom the complaint is made. That needs the very heavy qualification: if you have the money and the determination to do so.

A friend of mine—the husband of the electorate secretary of one of my colleagues—was a victim of Western Australian sexual harassment legislation which has similar provisions to those that are proposed in the Committee's majority report. He appealed to the Supreme Court ultimately, and the Supreme Court threw out the determination of the Western Australian Equal Opportunity Commissioner. On the way through, he paid almost $30,000 in legal fees, for which he has not yet been reimbursed. How many people have $30,000 to pay to lawyers to take this action in the courts? How many people, even if they have it or can raise it, will risk losing that amount of money if the court judgment ultimately goes against them?

In this case my friend was advised not to pursue the appeal to the Supreme Court but to pay up. A monetary award was given by the determination of the Equal Opportunity Commission. My friend was advised to pay up—`Don't take it to the Supreme Court'. He rejected that advice and ultimately won. But to allow that sort of procedure really amounts to statutory sanction blackmail. Do we really want that?

Regrettably, as Senator Cooney has said—and he also corrected me—the Government has adopted, in a somewhat harsher fashion, the de facto reversal of the onus of proof. It has proposed amendments, moreover, which enhance the dangers in the reversal of the onus of proof. As the Prime Minister said in his second reading speech on 3 November:

speech.para: . . . this Bill will amend the definition of sexual harassment to remove the requirement that the complainant demonstrate disadvantage.

para.tab: Under the new definition, the test will be satisfied if the complainant felt offended, humiliated or intimidated by unwelcome conduct . . .

speech.para: Offence, humiliation and intimidation are extraordinarily subjective concepts. When coupled with the de facto reversal of the onus of proof, who is going to prove the complainant was not offended or humiliated? How would one even begin to prove that a complainant was not offended or humiliated? The alternatives proposed by this recommendation are that offence, humiliation and intimidation would be determined without the rules of evidence, et cetera, as I said before, by a person who would have punitive powers. The Prime Minister's speech went on:

The test also requires an objective element: that is, a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated that the complainant would be offended, humiliated or intimidated. . .

A reasonable person having regard to all the circumstances—what is objective about that test? Somebody makes a guess or a judgment about whether a reasonable person would be intimidated, offended or humiliated. I know that provisions like that are applied to a great deal of law. Such provisions may be necessary. Under some circumstances they may even be good, but they are not objective. Either the author of that second reading speech—of course, it would not have been the Prime Minister himself—does not understand what objectivity is or is consciously debasing the language to facilitate his or her social engineering objectives. It could be argued that it shows us something about the mind-set of the authors of this legislation if they think the test of the reasonable person is an objective test.

para.tab: When someone—in this case, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner—has subjective or even arbitrary authority to impose penalties, the attitudes and beliefs of the incumbent in that position are highly relevant. The incumbent now is Quentin Bryce, who a couple of weeks ago was ordered by the Federal Court to redo two complaints which she had previously rejected and refused to investigate on the grounds that they were frivolous. One was a complaint about the fact that a Brisbane disco charges men a $2 higher admission fee than it does women. One would have thought that if words mean anything—to social engineers, words are things of convenience rather than meaning—that would have had to be an open and shut case of sex discrimination. It was thrown out arbitrarily by Quentin Bryce on the grounds that it was frivolous and she was not going to investigate it. She has, as I said, since been ordered by the Federal Court to do so.

The question of whether the state ought to be interfering with the admission charges for men and women by some disco in Brisbane is a different question. The fact is that the state has so legislated but the law is, not just because of my say-so but because of the say-so of the Federal Court, not being implemented properly by Quentin Bryce, who has displayed the most blatant bias in the administration of the existing Act. What I regard as bad proposed law will be made worse by the administration of Quentin Bryce.

The policy announced by the Government last week is taken principally from the recommendations of the Lavarch report. A letter from the honourable member for Fisher, Mr Lavarch, was published in the
Australian Financial Review
two days ago, the essential silliness of which was exceeded only by its rabid intellectual dishonesty. But I do not propose to deal with that any more here. I will deal with that in another forum.

I implore the Government—particularly because I know how Cabinets operate: the majority of members of the Cabinet do have some commonsense but have not really thought about this because so much legislation goes through Cabinet—to reconsider its attitude to this question and either drastically amend or not proceed with the Bill that was introduced into the Parliament last week. Failing that, I believe it should at least be sent off to an inquiry by a Senate committee, if it gets as far as the Senate.

I also hope interest of people outside the Parliament will be aroused by this issue. Those journalists who are not intimidated by political correctness have a critical role to play in making the public in general aware of what is proposed by the majority recommendation of the Senate Committee report and which has essentially been taken up by the Government.

talk.start.para: —I think it is significant that the dissenting senators to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs were Senator Vanstone, Senator Kemp, Senator O'Chee and Senator Walsh. Not having been aware of the contents of the report, I can only say that I found Senator Walsh's speech most illuminating. It is very important to alert people to the concerns that ought to be properly addressed when one tries to turn an administrative function into a judicial function. I simply thank Senator Walsh, without necessarily endorsing all his remarks, particularly regarding personalities, for the speech.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in
