para.tab: Leave granted.

The speeches read as follows
—

speech.para: RURAL ADJUSTMENT BILL 1992

The Rural Adjustment Bill 1992 provides for changes in the Rural Adjustment Scheme. The revised Scheme is a cornerstone of the Government's overall rural policy approach for achieving a more sustainable, productive and profitable farm sector. The Government's vision is a farm sector which is able to thrive in a highly variable economic and natural resource environment, without relying on government assistance for survival and growth.

The Government sees its role largely as a facilitator of a rural sector that is industry and community driven. We will ensure that the operating environment within which farmers work is conducive to sound business decision making, and that the messages farmers are receiving from us are consistent, with an emphasis on self reliance and risk management. We will encourage farm business managers to equip themselves with the necessary skills and training to make the most of their opportunities and we will ensure that the Government's rural policies and programs, such as the National Drought Policy, the Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme and the Rural Adjustment Scheme, function in an integrated way and encourage good management practices.

This Bill will have, over the remainder of this decade, a significant impact on the development of a stronger, more resilient and more competitive farm sector. It will drive the process of structural adjustment necessary to address the formidable economic and environmental problems facing the sector. In achieving this, the Government recognises the need to balance structural change and social justice. For this reason, the Bill is complemented by the Farm Household Support Bill 1992 which, in addition to assistance under the Rural Adjustment Scheme, provides the means for farmers with no future prospects in farming to leave with dignity.

Mr President, the Government has taken into account criticisms of the existing Rural Adjustment Scheme, which was introduced in 1988, in making the changes to the Scheme that are presented in this Bill.

The 1988 Scheme contained more devolved arrangements than previous Rural Adjustment Schemes. This had the advantage of greater flexibility and it allowed the State Rural Adjustment Authorities to respond to local conditions and local needs. The Scheme also provided an avenue to respond to drought and downturn through measures such as the Debt Reconstruction with Interest Subsidy and the Crop Planting Scheme. Although this flexibility has been very valuable and has allowed the Government to respond quickly to the needs of the farm sector as they have arisen, successive amendments to the 1988 Scheme have increased the emphasis on assistance rather than structural adjustment.

The changes to the Scheme outlined in this Bill will restore a strong structural adjustment focus. They follow a comprehensive review by independent consultants and extensive consultations with the States and the farm sector.

The new arrangements will be introduced on 1 January 1993. There will be a focus on improved farm productivity, profitability and sustainability through structural adjustment and more effective management of the farm business. The new Scheme will still allow the Government to respond to crises, but in a consistent, structured way rather than through ad hoc policy changes. The provisions for exceptional circumstances will allow us to respond quickly and appropriately to severe downturns without undermining the direction and purpose of the Scheme as a whole.

It is intended that the Rural Adjustment Scheme should support the commercial financial system rather than act to usurp or compete with commercial institutions. The Government's expectation is that State Rural Adjustment Authorities will work in cooperation with farmers, their financial advisers and financiers, and rural counsellors in the assessment of the financial situation of farmers, and in the provision of appropriate financial packages.

In normal circumstances, eligible farmers will be able to obtain interest rate subsidies of up to 50 per cent on commercial finance, to enhance the productivity, sustainability and profitability of their businesses. Farmers will also be able to obtain grants to improve their skills and to assist with the cost of obtaining financial, planning and other advice relating to their farm business. Such financial assistance will be funded on the basis of the Commonwealth contributing 90 per cent of the assistance and the States contributing ten per cent. This funding arrangement will also apply to agreed State administration costs.

Where exceptional circumstances such as severe drought or substantial commodity price downturns are found to exist, interest subsidies may be extended beyond 50 per cent, with the Commonwealth and the States sharing the costs of the assistance above 50 per cent equally.

In the operation of the Scheme, the Commonwealth will provide sufficient funds as working capital to those States which do not have adequate reserves. Thereafter, payment to the States will be on a quarterly acquittals basis. This will ensure greater accountability of Commonwealth funds.

As indicated, the States have the important role of administering the Scheme and this is appropriate because of their knowledge of their farmers' circumstances and requirements. In their administration, they will need to be aware of the objectives of the Rural Adjustment Scheme as spelt out in this Bill. The Minister will also be negotiating an agreement with the States on the operation of the Scheme, and they will be required to administer it within policy guidelines that the Commonwealth will develop in consultation with the States.

In order to continue to improve the effectiveness of the Rural Adjustment Scheme, the Government believes it is necessary for there to be strategic oversight of the Scheme and its operations. This will allow the Scheme to be adjusted according to changing circumstances and ensure that it addresses national objectives.

A Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council will be established to provide advice to the Minister on the operations of the Scheme from a national and strategic perspective. It will recommend to the Minister an on-going three-year strategic plan and a proposed annual program for the Rural Adjustment Scheme. The Council will also provide advice to the Minister on the appropriate level of funding for the Scheme and the appropriate level of funding as between States under the Scheme.

A significant function of the Council will be to provide advice to the Minister, on request, as to whether exceptional circumstances are affecting farmers and whether additional support is required in those circumstances. This would include advice on the types and terms of support which should be provided.
In undertaking its functions, the Council will consult with interested parties, including the States. It will be able to establish specialist sub-committees to assist in its work.

The Council will be required to submit an annual report to the Minister on its operations. This report is to include information on the operations of the Rural Adjustment Scheme and will be tabled in Parliament.

The Council will consist of up to eight Ministerial appointees. The members will include a representative of the National Farmers' Federation, a representative of the Commonwealth, at least one representative of the States, and up to three persons selected for their expertise in farm management, financial administration, training, economics and sustainable agriculture. The Minister will consult with the States regarding their representation on the Council.

Mr President, the new Rural Adjustment Scheme will support those farmers with good prospects for long-term profitability to increase their productivity and sustainability. In a competitive environment where farmers are faced with the challenge of constantly improving productivity, the Government believes that taxpayers' money is best invested in those farmers who have the capacity to make the most of Government financial support and to become independent of that support within a reasonable time.

For those farmers without future prospects in farming, enhanced farm exit provisions will be introduced. These include an increased re-establishment grant of $45,000 under the Rural Adjustment Scheme for eligible farmers who decide to leave the sector. The grant is available subject to an assets test on the sale of their productive assets.

The Farm Household Support Scheme, which I mentioned earlier, will replace the household support provisions of Part C of the existing Rural Adjustment Scheme and will provide support for farmers who are unable to access commercial finance to meet daily family requirements.

Mr President, it is intended that the Scheme will be reviewed after four years and will come to an end after eight years. This will provide time for farmers to adjust to the requirements of individual risk management and increased self reliance which will be the hallmarks of the successful farmer in the 1990s and beyond.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
STATES GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The Bill amends several provisions of the current Rural Adjustment Scheme, which was introduced in January 1989.

The Rural Adjustment Scheme as it operates at present provides financial support to farmers for a range of purposes, including the purchase of land and equipment, as well as through carry on finance for farmers in short term financial difficulties.

Mr President, we are all aware that a large number of farmers are suffering from severe and prolonged drought, particularly in the western districts of New South Wales and south western Queensland. However, the carry on finance available under Part B of the current Rural Adjustment Scheme has not proved sufficient to meet the needs of these farmers. With this in mind, the Government allocated 14 million dollars in the Budget to support these drought stricken farmers.

To enable immediate access to this assistance, the provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme Agreement have been amended by agreement between the relevant State and Territory Ministers and the Commonwealth. The New South Wales and Queensland Ministers of Agriculture have agreed to all three amendments, and as from 1 September 1992 the Rural Adjustment Scheme Authorities in each State began assessing applications for this assistance and advancing grants.
It is now appropriate to bring these amendments before the Commonwealth Parliament.

These amendments to the Agreement specify that finance shall be made available so that farmers may acquire livestock, restructure debt, improve productivity and for carry on purposes. Commonwealth funds may be used to pay no more than 75 per cent of interest subsidies, but each State may choose to pay the remaining 25 per cent to provide for a subsidy to cover the whole interest bill of the farmer.

On 21 September 1992 the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announced a new set of farm adjustment and assistance measures that promote a more productive and profitable farm sector and provide improved assistance to farm families suffering hardship. These measures will be incorporated in the new Rural Adjustment Scheme which will be introduced on 1 January 1993.

The drought assistance measures I have announced today will contribute significantly to the effectiveness of the current Rural Adjustment Scheme and they will reappear in the new Rural Adjustment Scheme in a broader format. Exceptional circumstances, not just drought conditions, will be provided for, removing the need for ad hoc responses to particular circumstances and ensuring that any assistance provided is consistent with the Government's overall rural policy approach.

The new Rural Adjustment Scheme will address the pressure exerted by a range of circumstances such as drought, flood and economic downturn that cause particular hardship. This will be done in a consistent manner and one that has been agreed beforehand with State governments. As well as responding to the plight of farmers in New South Wales and Queensland, the assistance provided through these amendments will provide a demonstration of how the new National Drought Policy will operate, through the Rural Adjustment Scheme.
I commend the Bill to the Honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT BILL 1992

Mr President, the Government has recognised the problems in the rural sector associated with structural adjustment and to address these, we have refocussed the Rural Adjustment Scheme on productivity improvement, and long term sustainable profitability.

We also recognise that there are a number of farmers who have no long term prospects in farming, and consequently have not been able to obtain commercial carry on finance. Many need support simply to put food on the table.

The new Farm Household Support scheme is therefore targeted at providing support to this group of farmers who are unable to access carry on finance and require assistance in meeting the day-to-day living expenses of the farm family.

While the Rural Adjustment Scheme is concerned with the farm as a business enterprise and is focused on productivity and profitability, the Farm Household Support Scheme is concerned with the welfare of the family. The Government recognises that, although it has a responsibility to facilitate the adjustment of the farm sector and improve productivity, it also has a responsibility to the people engaged in farming as families and individuals.

We do not want to see needy farmers or their families suffer because they miss out on standard welfare payments because of the size of their asset bases. Standard assets tests as applied to other welfare payments are not appropriate for a number of reasons and this is one of the issues addressed by the introduction of Farm Household Support.

The new scheme will ensure that the revised Rural Adjustment Scheme with its sharper adjustment and productivity focus is complemented by a more generous and broader household support component. This means that the support requirements of all farmers will be met. Farm Household Support replaces the Household Support provision of Part C of the old RAS.

The legislation is within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio and will be administered by the Department of Social Security (DSS) on an agency basis. Administration by DSS has the advantage of a network of established offices throughout rural Australia at which the farmer will be able to apply for Farm Household Support. To facilitate the smooth operation of the new scheme, Farm Household Support has been designed to be administratively as close as possible to schemes with which DSS officers are already familiar.
The Farm Household Support payment will be income tested to ensure that it is targeted at those in genuine financial hardship and a non-farm assets test will also be applied.

We have excluded farm assets from the assets test in recognition of the asset-rich/income-poor status of many farmers. Our concern with assets is simply to ensure that we are not providing support to families who have significant off-farm assets and are able to support themselves independently.
The Farm Household Support Scheme will fulfil the family support needs of two groups who are unable to access commercial finance:
.those who have taken the decision to leave the sector will receive support while they sell the property; and
.those who believe they have a future in the industry and wish to obtain carry on finance to help them weather a bad patch.

In both situations, Farm Household Support will be available as a loan for up to two years. To assist those who take the often difficult decision to leave in that two year period, the first nine months of Farm Household Support received will be converted to a grant. They may also be eligible for the re-establishment grant through the Rural Adjustment Scheme.
Farmers will not need to offer their property for sale in order to receive Farm Household Support. However, special incentives are available for farmers to sell quickly and leave.

We wish to encourage those who cannot exist on their farm without government help to seriously consider leaving farming. To increase the incentive to leave quickly the full nine month grant is cashed out if the farmer leaves in under that time. That is, farmers who complete the sale of their property within the grant period of 9 months will receive the balance of the grant amount as a lump sum. The cash out will be provided at the maximum payable Jobsearch Allowance rate to increase the incentive to sell within the nine month period.

Farmers who do not leave at the end of two years, whether through a return to profitability or reluctance to leave, will not qualify for the grant period and will have to repay all of the Farm Household Support received.

Farmers will only be required to submit an application for Farm Household Support with the Department of Social Security every six months and the rate of Farm Household Support set at that visit will be current until the next six monthly review. However, the rate will not be set in concrete. Farm Household Support recipients can seek a reassessment of their entitlement at any time due to changed circumstances, such as a greatly reduced income.

Farm Household Support will be available at the equivalent of the Jobsearch Allowance to which the farmer would be entitled, taking into account their income and off-farm assets. However, as Farm Household Support is a loan after the first nine months, individual farmers will have the flexibility to nominate how much of the allowance, up to this entitlement level, they feel they need or wish to take on as new debt.

The Jobsearch Allowance will still be available to farmers and their spouses under the normal and hardship provisions. Some families will find themselves eligible for both schemes and will need to decide whether they wish to access Farm Household Support or Jobsearch Allowance. Farm families who choose to access Jobsearch Allowance will lose their access to the Rural Adjustment Scheme re-establishment grant once the farmer or his or her spouse has received nine months of Jobsearch Allowance payments. This nine month period will be calculated from the introduction of the Farm Household Support scheme.

With the introduction of Farm Household Support, the modified provisions of the Jobsearch Allowance which were introduced for farmers on 1 December 1991 will no longer be available to new applicants. Those already on modified Jobsearch Allowance will continue to receive their allowance until they are no longer eligible or until the modified Jobsearch Allowance is sunsetted in December 1993. They will have the option of transferring to Farm Household Support.

An extensive publicity campaign will be run by my Department in the lead up to the introduction of Farm Household Support to ensure that farmers are aware of their options and of the implications of selecting Farm Household Support or Jobsearch Allowance or transferring between the two.

Current recipients of household assistance under Part C of the old Rural Adjustment Scheme will be transferred automatically to Farm Household Support when it is introduced, but they will be treated as a separate category to ensure that they are not disadvantaged by the transfer. In fact, this group will be receiving a bonus three month grant period over that offered to them under the present Part C.

If Part C recipients wish to access the flexibility under Farm Household Support of determining the rate at which they wish to be paid, they can opt to transfer to Farm Household Support, in which case they will be treated as new Farm Household Support applicants. Time spent on Part C will be subtracted from the two year period available under Farm Household Support.

Mr President, Farm Household Support presents the soft edge of the changes to the Rural Adjustment Scheme. It provides a safety net for those farmers who are unable to access commercial finance or Rural Adjustment Scheme support and need help in meeting their daily living expenses. At the same time it does not undermine the achievement of our goal of a productive and sustainable farm sector. Farm Household Support will provide farmers who have an uncertain future with a breathing space in which to consider their options. If they decide to sell and leave farming there is a generous package of support available, up to $55,000 in grants for farmers eligible for the re-establishment grant.
The cost of Farm Household Support will be met from within the forward estimates for the Rural Adjustment Scheme.

The combination of Farm Household Support and the Rural Adjustment Scheme ensure that the support needs of all groups of Australian farmers will be met while the sector adjusts to the challenges of improving productivity in the face of declining terms of trade and corrupt world markets.
I commend the Bill to the honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
INCOME EQUALISATION DEPOSITS LAWS AMENDMENTS BILL 1992
This Bill amends several provisions of the current Income Equalisation Deposit (IED) Scheme which was introduced in July 1989. These amendments follow a review undertaken by the Government.

The Government is encouraging the adoption of sustainable development principles in farm management. This will involve producers improving their financial planning and risk management skills, including managing for drought. To assist them, the Government has introduced improvements in its policies and in the links between its policies. These changes include an improved Income Equalisation Deposit Scheme. There are also important links with the new Rural Adjustment Scheme, the National Drought Policy and National Landcare program.
What we are doing here is going further down the track of assisting farmers to fend for themselves by building cash reserves. In achieving this, we must equip farmers with the necessary tools.

I believe that an attractive IED scheme can go a long way towards assisting and encouraging farmers to build cash reserves for use during downturns. The improved IED scheme including the new Farm Management Bond, will play a key role in doing this by assisting farmers with their management of financial risk.

The minimum amount that can be deposited has been reduced from $5,000 to $1,000. This will allow the small to medium farmer to put aside a small amount frequently, rather than wait until he or she is able to put together what would be, for some, a relatively large amount. It could be regarded as similar to making a deposit in a saving account—making a provision for the future.

The maximum amount that can be held in IEDs has been increased to $300,000 from $250,000. The figure of $250,000 applied when the current Scheme was introduced in July 1989. The increase to $300,000 will enable farmers to maintain deposits in real terms. In the main, the large farmer has the resources to make provision for downturns without Government assistance and, of course, many of them do so. However, deposits of $300,000 will provide a valuable reserve for all farmers.

As a further encouragement for farmers to increase their reserves, depositors will be able, if they wish, to reinvest interest earned on deposits. The option to reinvest interest is a standard practice in the commercial sector and I believe that farmers should be able to take advantage of this in respect of IEDs.

IEDs are deductible from taxable primary production income, but are included in taxable income when they are withdrawn. In the current situation, when funds are withdrawn a withholding tax of 29 per cent is applied unless the depositor self assesses otherwise. My view is that farmers would, on average, be in a lower tax bracket than 29 per cent as they would be more likely to be withdrawing funds during times of hardship and low incomes. This would, in particular, be the case in respect of farm management bonds as they can only be drawn on in times of hardship. Accordingly, the withholding rate has been reduced to 20 per cent. The withholding tax rate is changed by regulation.

As part of the new IED scheme, we have provided for the introduction of Farm Management Bonds (FMBs). These bonds will provide additional encouragement for genuine farmers to build cash reserves for use during contingencies such as drought.

Interest is paid on the investment component of the deposit. For ordinary IEDs this is deemed to be 61 per cent, however, for the new FMB the investment component will be 80 per cent. The improved return on FMBs is intended to encourage farmers to build reserves for use during hardship arising from natural events such as drought, fire, flood, etc, and hardship arising from significant falls in commodity prices.

There is a need to ensure that FMBs are used for the purpose that is intended. In order to achieve this, farmers, when applying to withdraw funds from FMBs will have to provide evidence in support of the grounds on which they wish to do so. However, they will still be able to withdraw funds even if the circumstances I have previously mentioned do not apply, but the deposit in respect of the amount they wish to withdraw will be regarded to have been an ordinary IED from the date of deposit. The implications of this are that interest will be paid on 61 per cent and not 80 per cent of the deposit and excess interest paid or reinvested will have to be repaid or deducted from the funds returned to the farmer.

In respect to commodity prices, a request for withdrawal must be accompanied by evidence of prices received for sales of commodities comprising the major part of the depositors income for the last four years. In determining whether or not a significant fall in prices has occurred, there is an assumption that unless special circumstances apply, a significant price fall occurs when the average of prices received in the year of application is at least 25 per cent lower than the average of the prices received for the previous three years. However, this will not restrict the evidence, information or the considerations to be taken into account when deciding if a depositor is suffering hardship arising from a significant fall in commodity prices.

The existing legislation contains a provision whereby depositors, when requesting a withdrawal on grounds of financial hardship within 12 months of deposit, can appeal against a determination to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This will be extended to determinations made in respect of requests for withdrawals of FMBs made on the ground of natural events, significant falls in commodity prices and financial hardship caused by other factors.

The existing legislation also provides that additional information may be sought within one month of the date of receipt of the request to assist in a decision being taken and this will also be extended to FMBs. There is an additional provision that a decision must be taken within a month of receipt of the further information or within two months of the original request to withdraw, whichever is the sooner, irrespective of whether or not the additional information has been received. In order to correct this anomaly, the provision will be altered so that a decision does not have to be taken until the additional information has been supplied. This will have the effect of preventing an Administrative Appeals Tribunal review taking place before the additional information has been supplied.

As I have already mentioned, only genuine farmers will be able to make deposits in FMBs. This will mean that only those with taxable non-farm income of less than $50,000 will be able to deposit funds in FMBs.

The farm sector faces certain risks that other sectors of the economy are not exposed to and I believe it is appropriate that farmers should be assisted in managing those risks. A limit of $80,000 on the amount that can be deposited in FMBs will be sufficient to allow farmers to do this.

Some 3,500 farmers have funds in IEDs. They will be able to directly transfer them into FMBs at any time provided they meet the eligibility requirements of FMBs. This will ensure that existing owners of IEDs are not disadvantaged.

Mr President, the changes to the IED scheme provided for in this Bill are part of an integrated set of policies, including changes to the Rural Adjustment Scheme, the National Drought Policy, the Farm Household Support Scheme and others which the Government has put in place to build a more resilient, sustainable, self reliant and internationally competitive rural sector.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, in accordance with agreed triennial funding arrangements and to reflect changed funding arrangements agreed between the Commonwealth, States and higher education institutions which will have the effect of increasing the autonomy and flexibility of higher education institutions.

The present Act provides for Commonwealth higher education funding to be provided to universities through payments made to State Governments. In the context of the 1991 review of Commonwealth-State relations, all Governments agreed that the funding mechanism for higher education should reflect the reality, that universities are part of a national system of higher education and the Commonwealth has primary responsibility for the public funding of that system. There was agreement that direct funding from the Commonwealth to higher education institutions is appropriate, to improve the accountability and transparency of the Commonwealth to the electorate. The Bill puts this change into effect. From 1993, higher education institutions will be paid direct by the Commonwealth, and institutions rather than the States will be directly accountable to the Commonwealth for the expenditure of grants.

To complement these arrangements and to assist in the accountability process, the Bill includes a statement of the Commonwealth's objectives in higher education. The Bill also provides for payment of higher education funds in limited instances to bodies other than higher education institutions where this best meets the objectives of the legislation.

These new arrangements for direct funding of higher education institutions are accompanied by improved consultative processes so that consideration of State needs and strategies becomes an integral part of the triennial planning cycle.

In accordance with these established triennial planning and funding processes, the Bill provides funds for higher education for 1995, the third year of the new funding triennium. In total, the Commonwealth has committed $4.7 billion to higher education in 1995. This amount takes into account the Government's decisions which I have just announced to provide, in 1995, some $23.6 million for additional student intakes and $274 million for capital purposes, as well as the $252 million for research programs already committed. Provision is also made within the 1993-95 funding triennium for a $12 million increase in research grants funding in 1994.

As the Government announced in the 1992-93 Budget, from 1994 higher education capital grants are to be incorporated into institutions' general operating grants rather than allocated on a project by project basis. The Bill provides for this decision, as well as for the increased resources available in 1993 and 1994, announced in the Budget, to address higher education building infrastructure needs. The roll-in of capital funds will provide flexibility, financial stability and continuity for universities in their capital planning; students should benefit from improved capital facilities as universities are able to manage their resources more effectively.

The needs of institutions which are growing at extraordinary rates or which are experiencing significant development and need funds, for example, for new campuses are taken into account in a separate fund for special capital projects. This discretionary pool of funds will be available for allocation by the Commonwealth following consultation with the States and institutions.

The Bill also reflects other Government decisions on higher education funding announced in its 1992 Budget, in particular the decision to support the establishment of a new open learning program in 1993. This program will open the door to tertiary education for many people currently without access through traditional arrangements. The program will have major advantages for people in rural and remote areas as well as for people with work or family commitments or disabilities which make access to on-campus courses difficult. Arrangements for the operation of this program are well under way and are designed to ensure the quality of open learning provision.

The Bill also provides for an increase in the number of Australian Postgraduate Research Awards available to students annually from 1993, as announced in the Budget. This increase acknowledges that skilled personnel are critical to Australia's research and development efforts and responds to growing demand for awards.

Some minor changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) are included in the Bill, in particular the increased discount for up-front payment of HECS to apply from 1993, some additional exemptions from HECS so that student places funded by employers are put on the same footing as State-funded places, and some rationalisation of the Scheme to ensure that Australian tax-payers do not have to meet the higher education costs of certain groups of students who may never earn an income in Australia.

The Bill also includes protection for the rights and responsibilities of higher education institutions to make their own decisions, independent of Government interference, on the provision of services and amenities for their students. Student organisations, which provide a wide range of services to their members—counselling, sporting, health and careers services, for example—are funded mainly by a services and amenities fee collected from students by institutions on behalf of organisations representing the interests of students generally. In the past, some States have interfered with the rights of institutions to make their own decisions about imposing or collecting these fees. The Bill provides an avenue for the Commonwealth to make up any shortfall in revenue experienced by an institution as a result of a decision of this kind by a State. Consequential amendment of the States Grants (General Purposes) legislation will be required at a later date to ensure that the Commonwealth can subsequently recover this money from a State if necessary.

The Bill also includes routine cost supplementation for Commonwealth grants to higher education. In total, the Commonwealth is committed to spending some $13.6 billion on higher education over the 1993-95 triennium. This level of funding and the improved funding arrangements put in place represent a major commitment to the enhancement Australia's higher education system in the interests of present and prospective students and the nation as a whole.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
This Bill proposes to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 to provide for supplementation of funds appropriated for schools programs for 1992.

The Bill extends eligibility for the English as a Second Language Program to dependants of certain categories of temporary entry permit holders who are in Australia on visas rather than on temporary entry permits.

The Bill provides for additional funds under the Award Restructuring Assistance Program in 1992 to meet the Commonwealth's share of additional costs associated with the increase in the salary benchmark for 4 year trained teachers to $38,000 per year and with the introduction of Advanced Skills Teacher positions.

The Bill appropriates additional funds for schools programs for 1992 in line with current supplementation arrangements. Total funding for schools programs for 1992 is estimated to be $2,662.5 million, comprising $2,082.8 million for general recurrent grants, $307.4 million for capital grants and $272.3 million for targeted and joint programs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1992

Recognising this Government's responsibility for all Australians, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1992 continues this Government's commitment to equity, quality and excellence in primary and secondary education in Australia. It secures funding for these purposes for the next funding period, 1993 to 1996, and provides for substantial increases in funding in 1993.

The Commonwealth shares responsibility with the States for the quality of public education and is a partner with the States and parents in supporting private education. In both relationships it is concerned with improving educational outcomes so that young Australians can adapt better to changing economic, industrial and social circumstances.

The Bill supersedes the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 which authorised funding for the 1989 to 1992 funding period. The new title of the Bill more accurately reflects the Commonwealth's leadership role in primary and secondary education and its interest in educational activities that support improved outcomes, regardless of where they take place.
The Bill also gives effect to a number of measures announced in the context of, and subsequent to, the 1992-93 Budget.

In the area of general recurrent funding, it provides for increases in per capita grant levels for all schools arising from the rollback of the Award Restructuring Assistance Program into general recurrent grants from 1993; for additional real increases in per capita grant levels for non-government schools in categories 5 to 12 in each year from 1993 to 1996 (guaranteed in legislation); and for maintenance in real terms of per capita grant levels for non-government schools in categories 1 to 4 and for government schools over the period 1993 to 1996 (also guaranteed in legislation).

From 1993, Average Government School Recurrent Costs will replace the Community Standard as the benchmark for general recurrent funding levels. Supplementation arrangements, formalised in legislation for the first time in 1993, will also reflect this change with all recurrent programs to be supplemented annually for the full annual movement in latest known Average Government School Recurrent Costs.

Changes to be introduced through the Revised New Schools Policy will reduce the level of regulation of established non-government schools to allow these schools greater flexibility to plan their own development. The assessment provisions applying to new schools and schools undertaking certain changes in operation are to be strengthened.

The Bill provides some $60 million in 1993 in additional capital grants for the refurbishment of government secondary schools and some $45 million in additional capital grants for non-government schools, with additional funds to be provided for non-government schools in subsequent years.

These changes to general recurrent and capital funding will ensure that non-government schools will enjoy stability and security of funding over the next eight years, from a substantially increased funding base. This will enable schools to continue to respond to the growth in participation, to the agreed national curriculum framework and to the challenges emerging from recent reports on post compulsory education. The certainty of funding which the non-government sector has enjoyed over the past eight years, certainty which is now critical to the survival and success of a substantial non-government system, will continue.

The Bill embodies the Government's belief that education is not a toy to be played with at the whim of political ideologues. Education is too important to be the victim of misguided, free market ideology. Freedom of conscience is the issue here. This Bill will provide increased educational opportunities for millions of young Australians, within a funding framework which guarantees stability, security and certainty for government and non-government schools through to the next century.

The Bill also establishes the framework for the new National Equity Program for Schools. The proposed new broadbanding arrangements endorsed recently by the Australian Education Council and to be introduced from 1994 will provide for financial assistance under four elements focused on access, equity, incentives and national priorities. Subject to agreement with school authorities, new provisions giving effect to broadbanding from 1994 will be introduced in the 1993 Budget Session of Parliament.

In the interim, in 1993 the provisions relating to education in English as a second language, special education, education in disadvantaged schools and schools in country areas, for students with disabilities and for projects enhancing literacy and learning have been grouped together under Part 6 of the Bill to reflect this new structure.

As part of the National Equity Program for Schools from 1993 the Government will also introduce grants for national projects to assist gifted and talented students and to improve the learning experiences of girls. The Students at Risk Program will continue in 1993 and will be extended to the non-government sector.

Funds appropriated by the Bill for the 1993 program year are estimated to total some $2,873.2 million, comprising some $2,180.0 million for general recurrent grants to government and non-government schools, $400.2 million for capital grants for government and non-government schools, $271.7 million for national equity programs, $16.5 million for the School Language Program and $4.8 million for other joint programs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.para:
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The speech read as follows
—

speech.para: This Bill will make amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 to ensure that all persons working in the offshore petroleum industry in Commonwealth waters are protected by occupational health and safety legislation.

Currently persons working in the industry offshore Western Australia and Queensland are not covered by occupational health and safety provisions. The Bill rectifies that situation. However, the provisions of the Bill will cease to apply once the relevant States move to extend the coverage of their occupational health and safety legislation.

The occupational health and safety provisions in the Bill reflect similar provisions found in most State legislation and closely follow those in the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. The occupational health and safety provisions in the Commonwealth OH&S Act are modelled on existing State/Territory legislation. The Bill places a general duty of care on employers and employees alike to protect the health and safety of all those working in the offshore petroleum industry. It provides a framework within which employers and employees may co-operate to address health and safety issues in the workplace.

The amendments will provide a framework at the workplace for the selection of employee health and safety representatives and the establishment of health and safety committees with employer and employee representation to facilitate co-operation in the protection of the health and safety of employees at work.

Standards on specific hazards may be included in regulations and codes of practice may be approved by the Designated Authority for the relevant adjacent area to give guidance to the industry on meeting obligations made by the occupational health and safety provisions.
The provisions will be administered by the Designated Authority for the relevant adjacent area.

It is indisputable that there is a need for a framework within which employers and employees co-operate to protect the health and safety of all those working in a potentially hazardous industry such as the offshore petroleum industry. The need was heightened by the major disaster which occurred on the Piper Alpha production platform in the UK sector of the North Sea in 1988. 167 lives were lost.

The Australian Government has responded comprehensively to this disaster and set up the Consultative Committee on Safety in the Offshore Petroleum Industry (COSOP). COSOP, consisting of State and Commonwealth government, union and industry representatives, was charged with assessing the findings from the UK inquiries and advising the Government on the future direction of offshore safety in Australia.
COSOP's principal recommendations were:
the adoption of the "Safety Case" approach to offshore safety together with the progressive introduction of objective setting regulations to replace prescriptive requirements wherever possible;

the extension of occupational health and safety coverage, based on the relevant provisions of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act, to those offshore areas where no occupational health and safety provisions currently apply;

the establishment of a single point of contact and responsibility for offshore occupational health and safety matters in each State/NT; the adequate resourcing and training of authorities to enable them to effectively administer the new regime; and
the establishment of a national incident data base.
These recommendations have been accepted by the Commonwealth and State/NT Governments, the petroleum industry and the unions.

The first element, the adoption of the "Safety Case" approach to offshore safety is already being implemented. Companies operating in Australian waters are now required by the offshore petroleum legislation to prepare Safety Cases for all platforms and floating production facilities for which either design commences or which commence operating after 1 July this year.

The Safety Case is a concept new to Australia for the management of hazardous industries. The principle has also been adopted in a draft Standard prepared by Worksafe for adoption by all jurisdictions by the end of 1993.
The extension of occupational health and safety coverage to all offshore areas, which will be implemented by this Bill, is the second element of the Government's response.

Further elements of COSOP's recommendations will be implemented over the next 12 to 24 months. The Government has made available in the Budget $379,000 in 1992-93, with further sums in the following financial years to ensure implementation.

The implementation of COSOP's recommendations represents a substantial change in approach to the management of safety in the offshore petroleum industry. They are designed to diminish the situations and conditions that can lead to accidents occurring and will result in improved safety conditions for all employees on Australia's offshore petroleum installations.
They will also demonstrate the way in which governments, unions and industry can work together to further the national interest.
None of the amendments in this Bill have any significant financial impact.
I commend the Bill Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —I am happy to make a short statement. This morning, I said that I was interested to hear the reaction of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) to the report that the ANC, to which the Government gives taxpayers' money, had been guilty of torture. I said that I was interested to hear that his reaction was:

speech.para: firstly, it is indefensible; secondly, it is tasteless; and, thirdly, it will make no difference at all to the amount of money we will give to the ANC.

I simply want to correct the use of the word `tasteless'. The Minister sent me a note saying that he would like me to apologise. I am delighted to correct the record, because what he actually said was that he had a distaste for torture. I said that he had said it was tasteless. His words were: `distaste for the activities in question'.

para.tab: I will correct the record to read: I am interested to hear that the Minister's reaction to the fact that torture has been carried out by the ANC is, firstly, indefensible; secondly, that the Minister has a distaste for torture; and, thirdly, that it will make no difference whatsoever to the amount of taxpayers' money he continues to give that political organisation. I am quite pleased to see the record changed.
As for the apology, I expect an apology from the Minister to the Chinese people for saying:
"The Governor's dog is probably a supreme delicacy", the newspaper quoted Senator Evans as telling reporters.
"They'll turn it into hors d'oeuvres for China's supreme leader, Deng Xiaoping who, I'm told, eats four puppies a day.

speech.para: I ask the Minister to apologise to the Chinese people here and now. Perhaps that is also distasteful.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —We dealt at some length with the China matter this morning. I do not think that there is any necessity to go over that ground. I simply make the point that the contest this morning was an assertion by Senator Bishop that I had used a particular word. I responded with some vigour that I did not use that word. I said that it was an absurd reference to make in the context of allegations and evidence as serious as that, and that I was sure that I did not use that word. Senator Bishop said:

speech.para:
Any check of the
Hansard
will show that it was used.

There are a number of references of that kind. It is obvious what the word `distaste' means, particularly in the context in which I used it, having referred in a sentence before to the behaviour in question being totally indefensible and having referred to it again two sentences later, where I said:
But I am very clear in my own mind that it is, I repeat, absolutely indefensible.
In reference to some talking points, I said in the middle of the same paragraph:
. . . I did see some talking points that were prepared, and I think I approved them, making very clear our distaste for the activities in question.

It is obvious that `distaste' used in that context means something very much more than `the behaviour in question is not tasteful'. Any reading of any dictionary will demonstrate that. It implies repugnance, repellence and language of that kind. That is the nature of the expression that I used.

para.tab:
I am indebted to Senator Bishop for acknowledging that the record is different from that which was asserted. She had no choice in the matter because
Hansard
proves that beyond doubt. However, I am not indebted to her for failing to apologise for what was a very clear misrepresentation of my position and one which, moreover, she has only made worse by the vehemence with which she continues to assert her position. Getting Senator Bishop to change her spots is a labour of Hercules and not one that I am inclined to attempt on this occasion. Perhaps we can now move on.

talk.start.para: —This is a very good time to have a look at subprogram 6.3. Are there any matters in relation to it?

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Before lunch, I was asking some questions in relation to the Embassy in Beirut. The Minister said basically, as I understood him, that on a general assessment, taking into account advice from Britain and Canada, those involved felt there was not a level of security which would allow the Australian Embassy to be reopened at this time but that that had not been a decision made on the basis of any specific security assessment.

para.tab: Following down that line, it appeared that the Minister was basically saying that security could be reasonably assured but that it would be at some considerable cost because of the need for around-the-clock surveillance, et cetera. Has the Minister and the Government assessed what the cost of reopening that mission would be, particularly in terms of additional security?

Bearing in mind that it would be principally manned by officials who are currently based in Damascus, as its principal role would be an immigration one, I presume that there would not be a great increase in overall cost as far as personnel is concerned in reopening the Embassy in Beirut, other than costs that would be associated with the security aspect. That is why I am asking the Minister whether an assessment has been made of what additional costs would be incurred in putting in place a regime offering satisfactory security.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I am able to confirm that we did announce through Mr Hand on 1 October a proposal to establish an informal Australian Government office in Beirut to assist with immigration and consular services in Lebanon of the kind I mentioned earlier. The premises are presently being negotiated. They will involve three interconnected rooms at a hotel. A lease is being drawn up in relation to that.

para.tab: Duty statements are being prepared and we hope that that will be established as soon as possible with the opening of the office early next year. I am told that the exercise has been welcomed by the Lebanese authorities, although obviously we would all prefer to be able to regularise the status of that office and have a proper full scale mission.

The problem does continue to be the security one. It is not quite true to say there has been no assessment of the security. The security has not been assessed by sending someone especially over from AFP or otherwise, but a judgment has been made about the security situation. Certainly, a lot of discussions have been held with the United States, and Britain and France as well, on security matters.

As a demonstration of the kind of costs that can be involved in this, the United States mission has presently 23 US-based personnel and 435 locally engaged staff, of whom approximately 300 are security personnel. Of course, it may well be thought that the United States is more comparatively vulnerable than an Australian presence would be, but nonetheless, on any view, it would be an extremely expensive business to provide the around-the-clock guards and other security of living places, travel and so on that in our judgment would be necessary to protect A-based staff.

I am not sure that any precise calculation has been made. I can check that and, depending on the assumptions one makes about ratio of security staff to particular personnel, all I can say is that the sum involved was manifestly larger than we could afford within the present budgetary constraints we are operating under so far as posts are concerned.

It is a matter of weighing cost against the security factor. One takes into account the security issue in its own right, because one does not want to put unnecessarily Australian personnel at risk, but also very much part of the calculation is the financial cost involved of producing an acceptable level of security for such personnel. That cost, as I have explained to the Lebanese Government and the Lebanese community in Australia, is simply not one that we can be reasonably expected to bear at this stage.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to spend excess time on it, but I am now a little more confused. I thought the Minister said that the costs had not been calculated and then he said—
—They have not been.
—Do not just scoff. Have they been assessed or not?

—Hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars are involved in this in a post that has not previously cost us anything like that in personnel terms. The figures are around somewhere of the individual components. I have already said that I will seek to get them out. It is a matter of a prima facie assumption being made that a level of security of anything like that which would be needed, even if not the same ratios as for the United States, would nonetheless simply be unmanageable within present budgetary constraints. It is a self-evident proposition. Once one reaches a certain cost level, it is pointless worrying about how much more than that it might involve. A certain minimum is too much.
—Any further matters on subprogram 6.3?

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I think we were going to suggest that we might deal with the matter of Mr Butler next, if Senator Bishop is happy with that. It will allow me to dart away for a minute to do a quick job before I return to engage the Minister for a short while in relation to his friend Mr Burke.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —This is the first of the three ambassadors `B', ambassadors Burke, Butler and Boucher, and there are questions that relate to all three of them of various magnitude. But the one thing they all have in common is that they all seem to have a theme of mateship, either first-hand or second-hand.

para.tab: I might say the information provided by the Department relating to the questions asked in hearings was tabled here in the Senate only 48 hours ago. I am looking at the material on page 75. That is the first of a series of questions, and the questions that were taken on notice related to the employment of a Thai national, married to an Australian, who had lodged a complaint for sexual harassment against the head of mission, Ambassador Butler. This matter had come to our attention because it seemed that the matter was being swept under the carpet.

Information was brought to me from a number of sources. At no stage have we identified the woman concerned. That would be totally unfair, and the only reason Ambassador Butler is identified is that he chose to go on the record. That is the reason his name is on the record; he put it there. Many questions were asked about this because of the strange occurrence that the husband of the woman who made the complaint was shipped home. It is my understanding that he was not given the reasons for his shipment home, other than to go home for consultation, until he arrived in Australia.

The second part of my question—and in just a moment I will deal with some of the material supplied by the Department—related to an investigation of Ambassador Butler by the fraud prevention and discipline section concerning failure to acquit certain accounts, as I understand it. I think as we go through the answers we will see what picture will emerge there.

To begin with the matter of the woman's sexual harassment: my concern was always this; not to determine the facts of the matter but to ensure that she gets justice. I asked for a job description of the position she held. I have it. The job description is PN6138; she is a secretary and her duties are to perform secretarial, typing and clerical duties for the consular and administrative section and like duties, as distinct from the head of the mission, who, of course, is a full plenipotentiary; a very powerful man. As I have said before, we are looking at a master-servant relationship. I asked for the letters of advice that were given by the Department to the woman concerned, because I wanted to see firstly who had signed them. It seemed to me to be quite unjust that Mr Forrester, the man who had recalled the husband, also had carriage of investigating the wife. It seems to me to be a very strange set of circumstances.
The information that has been given in answer to my question is this. I said:

speech.para: I want to see the form of the letter that she wrote—
because I had been advised that she had written a letter—

and I want to know who helped her write it. Secondly, I want to see your letter to her again with her particulars erased; and I want to see whether, in the same letter, you advised her that she could make a formal complaint to the Secretary as well as to an external agency which could cost her money. Can I have those two documents, please, Minister?
The response that I have says:

Legal advice has been sought in this matter. The advice is that the complainant's letter should not be released without the consent of the complainant and the person against whom the complaint is made.
The plot thickens! The response continues:
The Department does not have information in regard to who, if anyone, helped the complainant write the letter.

para.tab: There are two letters from the Department in which advice was provided to the complainant in the terms of Senator Bishop's question. It would be appropriate in the terms of privacy—

speech.para: Whose privacy?—
considerations to release the following extracts relevant to the question.
There is one letter written on 12 August and, of course, there is no signature provided. It says:
I would like to remind you again of your right to take up this matter formally in terms of paragraph 3.4 of the Public Service Commission's guidelines on eliminating sexual harassment. My own view—
says the anonymous writer—
is that given that one of the parties is a very senior officer of the Department—
he is a bit special—

it would be appropriate for any formal investigation to be conducted by an external agency such as the Merit Protection and Review Agency under Section 50 of the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act. This is an option suggested for such cases in the PSC guidelines and one which would be supported by the Department.

So here we have it. She has the right to make a formal complaint to the Department but, `oh no; it's a very senior officer of the Department. For heaven's sake, we can't do it here'. I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to be responsible and he said he would be. In a moment, I am going to ask him what he personally has done in the matter.
The second letter, of 26 August, again unauthored and goodness only knows in what context, states:
I continue to believe that, if you wish to lodge a formal complaint, it should be lodged with an external agency, for reasons I have outlined to you earlier.

That is, Mr Butler is a very senior officer. That is the reason given. Quite plainly, I can only see, by reading between the lines, that the complainant has come back and said, `But I don't want to do that' and the Department has come back at her and said, `Well, you're going to have to do it'.

para.tab: I will go back and find the time, the date and the place when the Minister said he would take responsibility in this matter because, as we know, ambassadors are appointed—this is going to be relevant to all three ambassadors: Butler, Burke and Boucher—by the Governor-General in Executive Council on the recommendation of the Minister. Therefore, it is the Minister's responsibility. So I ask the Minister: what has he personally done to find out whether or not justice has been done in this case and how far has it progressed to his personal knowledge, as he agreed to take responsibility?

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —As to how far the matter has progressed, the informal conciliation process conducted by Mr Forrester was not successful, as I think I told the Estimates Committee. Mr Forrester formally ended his part in the process on 26 August. Both the complainant and Mr Butler were informed of this fact in writing. It does remain open to the complainant, as has always been the case, to lodge a formal complaint.

para.tab: We have consistently advised the complainant, as Senator Bishop has just pointed out, that if she wished to lodge a formal complaint she should approach an external agency with the appropriate investigative powers. The reason for that, if I might interpolate in answer to that criticism at this point, is the language of section 5.5 of the Public Service Commission personnel management guidelines on the elimination of sexual harassment. Section 5.5 of those guidelines states:

speech.para: Especially where senior staff are involved it may be desirable for the investigation to be carried out by someone from outside of the area, e.g. someone from another office of the department, or another department, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission or the Merit Protection and Review Agency.

The judgment that has been made by the Department, which I endorse, is that, given the sensitivities, the degree of difficulty of this matter and the degree of publicity it has attracted, not to mention the efforts of Senator Bishop to allege bad faith by various people in the Department in this matter, it would be appropriate for the matter to be dealt with by an external agency if it is to be further pursued.

para.tab: The complainant has been advised that the departmental workplace harassment contact officers remain available to meet with her if she so wishes. She was contacted as recently as 16 October and invited to a meeting in the Department to go over the options available to her. Those options, I may again mention for the record, are spelt out in detail in paragraph 3.4 of the Public Service Commission guidelines. The options are described as extending to, among other things, lodging a grievance directly to the Secretary under Public Service regulation 83 and, if not satisfied, request that the grievance be referred to the Merit Protection and Review Agency under Public Service regulation 84. My understanding is that no such grievance has been so lodged.

talk.start.para: —Exactly.

—That is a matter for the complainant, not for the Department. The complainant may also directly approach the Merit Protection and Review Agency under section 50 of the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act, lodge a complaint with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission under the Sex Discrimination Act, and seek advice from a lawyer as to possible remedial action under the larger civil or perhaps even criminal law. They are the options; they have been communicated to her on a number of occasions and that is where the matter rests.

para.tab: The complainant has advised us, I am told, that she is still considering the options available to her to resolve the matter and is not yet ready to inform my Department whether or not she wishes to pursue the matter further. I do not think it is remotely appropriate for this matter to be further pursued by the Department, let alone me, in that particular environment that I have just described. The options are available to her; it is entirely up to her to determine how she wants to move from now on.

Might I just address two other matters: first, the opening salvo from Senator Bishop about the job description for the woman in question and the master-servant relationship that is necessarily involved in a job relationship of that kind. I simply again make the point, as I have on numerous occasions, that the realities of that kind of relationship do cut both ways. Yes, on the one hand, that might well be thought as creating an intimidating situation in which harassment might be thought to be able to be got away with. On the other hand, equally, the existence of that power relationship can be applied in a quite different way because of the nature and extent of the reputation that is at stake, the significance of that reputation, the desire of the person to maintain it and the ease with which that reputation can be brought into question simply by an allegation being made, one being put in the public domain or pursued in the public domain in the way in which this one has been.

So there are, as we all know simply from common knowledge of human nature, two ways in which one can look at this situation. It is simply quite inappropriate for Senator Bishop to make the continuing assumption that she has that the problems about this whole affair lie only on one side of the equation.

Finally, on the subject of the letters that were the subject of our reply and which appear in extracted form on page 79 of the additional information supplied, those letters were over the signature, I am told, of Mr Forrester. I do not think there needs to be any confidentiality maintained about that, but there is a question of very real confidentiality involved in releasing the letters in question without the consent both of the complainant and of the person against whom the complaint was made.

talk.start.para: —Has the complainant been asked?
—Not yet.
—So you did not even bother to ask her?

—That is a tendentious way, again, of describing the situation. Senator Bishop can ask these questions nicely and pleasantly and I will do my best to respond to them, but she really does not make it very easy when she starts snapping and snarling in that tone of voice without any obvious provocation. Senator Bishop would win the Olympic standing jump for offensiveness in terms of her ability to launch assaults without any visible, obvious prior events, prior run-up or prior provocation. We all get a bit sick of it.
—Ask the fellow with a scar on his forehead how he feels about it.
—Whenever I am offensive against Senator Bishop, I can assure Senator Knowles that it is with excellent provocation—with outstanding, objectively ascertainable reason.
—Ask the fellow with the scar on the forehead who collided with the ashtray.
—Someone said you also throw staplers.

—I think the risk Senator Bishop runs, if I might put it gently, is not that I will ever throw anything at her, but that one of these days I will quietly, deliberately walk across the chamber and garrotte her. That is the problem she confronts; not my throwing anything at her. Be that as it may—
—Before you do that, it might be better to get back to the—

—Mr Chairman, I am sorry. I am used to the intemperate language of the Minister—and overseas dignitaries also are becoming increasingly more used to it. But I am afraid that is showing a man who is unbalanced. I would seriously ask whether we ought not find a psychiatrist to help him. Clearly he should not be let loose in foreign ports to go around insulting foreign dignitaries. Mr Chairman, I ask your advice: what are we to do with him?
—Garrotte him.
—That is going a little bit far, I think.
—Any other form of action that Senator Knowles might have had in mind would be quite equally inappropriate in the circumstances.
—Let us get back to the matter at hand; that might be better.

—One matter raised with great indignation by Senator Bishop was the suggestion that it was somehow outrageous that there could be some requirement of consent by the person against whom the complaint was made. In this respect, I simply make the point that, under privacy principle No. 11 of the Privacy Act 1988, personal information—and this is of a kind which presumably contains material in the nature of allegations of the kind that are in issue here—shall not be released to a person, body or agency unless one or more of the exceptions set out in those principles apply. Briefly these are:

speech.para: (a) the individual concerned is reasonably likely to have been aware, or made aware under Principle 2, that information of that kind is usually passed to that person, body or agency;
(b) the individual concerned has consented to the disclosure;
(c). . . the disclosure is necessary to prevent. . . threat to the life or health. . .
(d) the disclosure is required or authorised by or under law; or
(e) the disclosure is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law. . .

It is the judgment of the Department—I think we all found on legal advice—that none of those exceptions is applicable in this particular case. That is the reason why the answer has been given to Senator Bishop in the form that it has. Fundamental privacy considerations are involved here and it would not seem appropriate, let alone within the terms of the Privacy Act, for any exception to be made to the prohibition against governmental release as to those matters. If the grievance persists—and this is the nub of the issue, of course—it is perfectly open to the complainant to pursue that grievance in a whole variety of other ways that I have already mentioned.

talk.start.para: —It really will be a cause for despair when ordinary Australians realise that a man who uses the language and acts in the way that the Minister does is exercising powers of state. Let me refer to this woman's future and her course of justice. The Minister read the guidelines in the Act. But he did not bother to read that there must always be an adherence to the principles of natural justice. How can anyone expect logic or justice to be relevant to a man who is as intemperate as this? He has stood there and basically told us, in a most incoherent manner, that quite simply he does not give a damn. He has Mr Forrester doing his work for him. Mr Forrester recalled the husband.

para.tab: I think the dates are also quite interesting. The complainant commenced duty at the embassy in Thailand on Monday, 16 December 1991. She ceased to be employed on 28 February 1992. The husband arrived in Bangkok on 26 September 1991. He undertook language training until 31 October 1991 and commenced duty on 1 November 1991; and they both came home in March 1992. Something very funny has been going on in that embassy.

There was the curious conversation between Mr Butler and Mr Forrester. This was admitted to. Mr Forrester brings home the husband and the wife comes with him. Mr Forrester is given the job of being the so-called conciliation officer. Where are the laws of natural justice being followed here? With the attitude of the Minister, how can we hope that the woman is ever going to get redress?

Among the options, and the one that is the most important in a case like this, is the right of the complainant to lodge a formal grievance under section 83. But when her husband was recalled, as she was a locally engaged employee she came back with him and lost her employment. I ask the Minister: is she eligible to make a complaint under section 83 of the Public Service Act now that she has resigned because she wanted to come back to Australia with her husband who was recalled by Mr Forrester, the person who was in charge of her case? Is she eligible to make a complaint under section 83?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I have already conveyed that information to Senator Bishop in the Estimates Committee hearings. My clear understanding is that yes, she is.
—With regard to her letter, the Minister indicated to me that she was not asked if it were to be released. Was Mr Butler asked?
—Not yet.

—These hearings took place in September; we are now in November. This woman has been waiting for months, and yet the Minister does not see fit to have his officers even ask if my request can be acceded to. Why were they not asked? Was it because of incompetence?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I do not know why the—
—Contempt of the Parliament, perhaps?

—No, respect for the privacy of individuals and a desire, I guess, not to push the matter further than the parties wished it to be pushed in the knowledge that we had that the party in question, the complainant, who was perfectly capable in any one of the number of ways that I have already mentioned of taking steps to move the issue forward, has not so chosen. In that environment where she is still clearly considering her position, she may well be, for all I know, profoundly embarrassed by the cause celebre Senator Bishop is seeking to make of this case. In that kind of environment, I for one do not think it is appropriate for the Department to be taking some unilateral steps to give this issue further privacy-invading prominence. But, if Senator Bishop wants us to seek the response of the complainant and of the person referred to in the letter, we will do so.

para.tab: I might also say that there is some assertion that this material was only made available to Senator Bishop yesterday. I am told that the replies in question were submitted to the Committee or tabled on 24 September. It is now 11 November. If Senator Bishop has not chosen to pursue this with the Committee secretariat, that is her problem, not ours. We did our best to make the material available.

talk.start.para: —I said, and I will repeat it so that the Minister understands: this information was lodged in the Senate within the last 48 hours. That means it went on the public record within the last 48 hours. That means anyone who is interested in the matter has had access to it for 48 hours.
—It has been available to you since 24 September.

—Excuse me, I have the floor. I have made the point that for the people who are interested in this matter—aside from senators who may have access to material which is not on the public record and, as such, may not be dealt with until it is—it was only put on the public record 48 hours ago.

para.tab: We will go back. In September I asked the Minister's Department to release that letter to me. The Minister is now telling me that he has not even asked the people whose consent, he tells me in formal advice, would be necessary to so release it. Mr Chairman, that in my view is contempt of the Parliament. I would be interested in your view.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The only thing that involves any contempt is the way in which Senator Bishop is treating these proceedings. I have given my response as to why I do not think we should be careering around seeking to further invade the privacy of the people concerned, unless it is very clear that at least one of those parties wants this matter to be pursued. The best evidence that she has not made that decision is her failure to take any of the action that has been available to her.

para.tab: I make the second point that if Senator Bishop were dissatisfied with the answer that was given to her—the answer that she has been referring to of making reference to these considerations of requiring consent—she had an opportunity to express that dissatisfaction herself immediately on receipt of this material which was available to her through the Committee secretariat on 24 September, just a few days after the Estimates Committee hearing. She did nothing of the kind. She was saving herself up to grandstand again on this occasion. Well, I am not impressed and I do not think anybody else will be either.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.
