talk.start.para: —I know that the Minister has difficulty following this. It may be due to the fact that his brain becomes addled when he flies so many hours; I do not know. The point I was making related to when the material became available on the public record. The fact that I may or may not have had access to it as a member of that part of Estimates Committee B which dealt with Finance and Treasury and not Foreign Affairs and Trade is another question—and that is a matter that the Minister would not have countenanced.

para.tab: However, the important point is this: I asked for the material; the reason the Minister has given me that he cannot let me have the material is that he would first have to have the permission of both parties involved. Now we hear that nobody has ever asked those people whether that material could be made available to me. Has it occurred to the Minister that this woman is frightened? Has it occurred to the Minister that she is intimidated by the fact that her argument is with a head of mission, a full plenipotentiary? Mr Forrester had the power to bring back her husband, and did so; he had the power, therefore, for her to lose her job as well. Mr Forrester wrote and said, in very plain language:

speech.para: My own view is that given that one of the parties is a very senior officer of the Department—
that is, `we look after our own'—
it would be appropriate for any formal investigation to be conducted by an external agency such as. . .
I put to Mr Forrester that there is no mention in the letter about the ability to make a complaint under section 83. There is no mention of that in the second letter on the 26th when he says:
I continue to believe—
`I' being a First Assistant Secretary—
that, if you wish to lodge a formal complaint, it should be lodged with an external agency, for reasons I have outlined to you earlier.

That is, `We don't want to know about you; you are an embarrassment. You are causing embarrassment to one of our own'. I put it to the Minister again that this case is a cause celebre for three reasons: Mr Butler chose to go on the record and talk about how he dimmed the lights in his office and how he had soft music playing; he chose to make those statements. Nobody prodded him, nobody asked him to do it, he elected to do it. That report was then picked up in the newspapers here and it became a cause celebre.

para.tab: The plight of this woman then came to my attention through a variety of sources. It was quite clear that she was being intimidated. I then raised the matter in this Parliament because the Minister is well known for looking after mates. Ambassador Butler is a mate, as Brian Burke is a mate, as perhaps Boucher is a mate. All these people are being looked after by the Minister and he personally will not take responsibility. It is simply not good enough for a Minister of the Crown to say, `She is an inconvenience, I don't want to know about her' and to have his Department give her advice that says, `Go away lady, we don't want to know about you'. I ask the Minister again: when will he take personal responsibility for actions concerning senior people in his Department and not concur in the reasoning that says, `He's a very senior officer, you know; please go away'?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The lady in question has been made aware of her section 83 option, if not specifically in the language of that particular letter—
—Where?
—I am told on a number of occasions, quite specifically, by two ladies sitting right next to me.
—In writing?

—She has been taken through the options available to her on numerous occasions. The ladies in question are the workplace harassment contact officers—Miss Sue Pascoe and Mrs Sally Ramsey. If Senator Bishop thinks either of them is frightening or intimidating, I think she has a rather different view of human nature than most people would have. They are people whose specific responsibility, whose assignment within the Department—with a responsibility to all officers of the Department, be they ever so high or ever so low—is to try to come to a sympathetic understanding of the nature of these complaints and to process, to move those complaints forward, in a way that is satisfactory and acceptable, in the first instance, of course, to the complainant herself. That is their responsibility: to try to resolve these issues and to make absolutely clear what the options available are. That is the process that has been followed from the outset in this whole affair.

para.tab: Mr Forrester has told Senator Bishop in evidence before the Estimates Committee that he has had only a fairly limited direct contact, either in person or in writing, with the complainant; that by far the majority of the contact has been through the particular female officers of the Department who are tasked with this responsibility. We have tried to handle this matter in a sensitive way. The only person who is approaching it in a different way, to my knowledge, is Senator Bishop. It is most unfortunate, as I have said on many occasions, that she has chosen to address this issue in this way.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —Every time Senator Evans has risen to his feet today to give us an answer—it does not matter whether it is me asking the questions, Senator Hill, Senator Kemp or anyone else—he has been telling us that, whatever the problem is, it is somebody else's fault. Now it has turned into the good lady's fault. Now it is my fault. Earlier it was Senator Kemp's fault. It was the reporter's fault for daring to report what the senator said with regard to the dog incident in China. Every time we see a problem in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, it is somebody else's fault.

para.tab: What we have to do here is establish some comparisons. We have to know whether this is a one-off, isolated case, or whether there are precedents and how this Department handles this question of harassment generally. The only way we can do that is to look at another case study. This case study involves a lady in Bonn. She writes:

I have been encouraged by the Richard Butler case to ask you for an investigation into the unfair ending of my employment at the Australian Embassy in Bonn, Germany, in July 1990 after fourteen years of efficient service.
In brief, there were numerous breaches of the rules against sexual harassment (such as bra strap pulling and bottom patting) in the Consular Section caused by—

speech.para: and she names the person—

which were reluctantly tolerated, not to destroy the good working atmosphere. It was not feasible to turn to the young A-based EEOLO who could not be expected to tackle more senior A-based colleagues. Finally things got worse and the previous loving attention turned into nastiness. Everything I did successfully for 14 years was criticised and put on paper commencing in May 1990. The final shocking act came in early July 1990 when the SAO—
and she names him—

called me into his office during lunch hour, blackmailing me that I had one hour to resign or I would lose all the entitlements due to me after 14 years at LE 6 level. I repeatedly tried to see [the] Ambassador . . . he avoided me. I was sacked for alleged misconduct and in the process of picking up my personal property from the Embassy on 5th July 1990—
the person whom she named earlier—
punched me in the stomach, so hard that I fell backwards.

para.tab: I took action successfully in the German courts which decided in my favour and awarded me 110,142.58 DM from the Embassy one year later. This amount, however, did not include my entitlement to 2% gratuity (as outlined in the Conditions of Service) of 12,362.— DM.

I ask for no sympathy for the stress and embarrassment the behaviour of your former Bonn officials have caused to me . . . for completely ignoring the many personnel problems in [the] Embassy. However, you should be aware that in a diplomatic city like Bonn your officials have made it impossible for me to get work in any other Embassy. I have very good references covering my work performance at the Embassy. . .

speech.para: She names the referees, who include senior ambassadors such as Ambassador Ashwin and others who are well known in the service. Her letter continues:

para.tab: I therefore respectfully request that you make a declaration that I was given unfair treatment in this matter and that some action should be taken against—

speech.para: and she lists the people she named. The letter concludes:
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should be advised not to send such unsuitable representatives to important overseas posts which certainly damage Australia's good reputation.

para.tab: Yours sincerely

speech.para: She then adds a postscript which relates to Mr Butler and some occurrence with unpaid bills in Bonn. The bottom line is that, since I have raised the Butler case—as I said, not to judge it but to see that the woman gets natural justice required under our laws—I have had not one, not two, not three, but a number of women who have been in the service who have come to see me. Some of them simply are frightened of being identified and put through the wringer again. They do not want to go on the record. Here is a woman who is brave enough to do it.

para.tab: It is all very well for the Minister to sit there and bluster and carry on as he has done today, for the world to see. Yet we have people who are within the Minister's jurisdiction, within the portfolio responsibility that he has and—surprise, surprise—his duty as a Minister is not merely to gallivant around the world meeting somebody here and making a speech there, it is actually to run his Department.

talk.start.para: —Insult them.

—That is quite right, he gratuitously insults them wherever he is and causes embarrassing incidents. That aside, the Minister has the responsibility to run an efficient and effective department. Quite clearly, he is not doing it. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of this case I have just outlined to him. If he is not, will he look into the matter. How many other cases do I have to bring to his attention until he, personally, will ensure that justice can be relied upon by people who feel they have a proper grievance.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has, at any one time, a total of 4,500 employees, in round figures; 2,400 Australians or Australian based people and 2,100 locally engaged. It is hardly surprising that with that number of people spread over so many workplace locations around the world—in many instances, in quite difficult and sometimes dangerous conditions—there should on occasions be instances of alleged workplace harassment. The important thing is that these instances, when they do arise, are dealt with according to proper process in a measured and sensitive way.

para.tab: Mr Chairman, there is really not much point in me responding to Senator Bishop if, every time I seek to do so, she engages in other conversations and does not listen. It is very rude behaviour for Senator Bishop to ask a question and then not listen to the answer.

talk.start.para: —How many times do I have to bring them to your attention?

—I am making the general point, which I think any objective or fair-minded person would appreciate, that that is the basic framework within which we are operating. In a massive organisation with a very large number of people, very often in stressful situations, the important thing is to have a proper process. I was advised a few days ago that a former locally engaged staff member at the Australian Embassy in Bonn has lodged a complaint with the Merit Protection and Review Agency—one of the procedures we have constantly referred to as available to complainants in these situations—alleging sexual harassment by two departmental officers formerly posted to the Embassy.

para.tab: That letter of complaint was received by the MPRA on 30 September, and a copy was received by my Department on 7 October. I am further advised that the allegation against the two departmental officers is now being investigated. Of course, it would be simply inappropriate of me to comment further on the matter while that investigation is proceeding, not least, in order to protect the privacy of the parties involved.

As to the particular legal matter which Senator Bishop has referred to, I am advised that some action was taken in a German labour court relating to the dismissal of this particular person, and a settlement was ordered by that particular labour court. I understand that that certainly did not bear in any direct way upon the sexual harassment allegations which are now being made. They will be pursued in an appropriate—

talk.start.para: —Like the other one.

—Senator Bishop does not seem to have got the point about the other one. We do not have a complaint formally lodged with the Secretary for an internal investigation under section 83, or with the Merit Protection and Review Agency or with any of the other available avenues. We had a request for the matter to be looked at earlier in the year. We had an agreement to a conciliation process, which is expressly provided for under the Public Service Commission departmental guidelines that deal with this matter. All that material has been put on the public record. That process ran its course, unsuccessfully it seems in terms of getting an agreed outcome. The options have been communicated in writing, and more extensively and more often by the two ladies who I referred to before.

para.tab: It is most inappropriate to suggest that I am ascribing fault to anybody when I simply describe that sequence of events. I am not ascribing any fault, for God's sake, to the two of my departmental officers involved. I am simply stating a matter of fact. Senator Bishop is so bitter and twisted about these things that she ascribes evil or bad intent, or neglect to every single thing that she hears about, reads about or comes across. It makes it very difficult for any of us to conduct departments of state in an ordered way. The kind of contempt she is constantly directing to public servants in this place, either to their faces in the Estimates Committee, or by interjection as she did this morning, does not do Senator Bishop any credit whatsoever, nor does it lend any credibility at all to the causes that she espouses.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —I would like the Minister to remember that this matter is ongoing; we will expect reports on a regular basis. The one part the Minister did not quote from the guidelines for sexual harassment contact officers and personnel officers is 4.8 which states:

speech.para: Whether or not a victim wishes to make a complaint about an individual, once management becomes aware that there appears to be a problem in a particular work area it has a responsibility to do something about it.

Well, the Minister did, did he not? He recalled the husband, brought the wife back, she is off the payroll and Mr Forrester wrote to her saying, `Go and find a solution elsewhere'. The Minister is not off the hook.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I need to respond to that final salvo if only, once again, as I have done on many occasions, to try to distinguish between the two very different strands of this particular matter.

para.tab: The matter relating to the officer's recall from Bangkok is a completely separate and distinct matter from the matter relating to the harassment complaint by the spouse. The sequence of events, as my Department became aware of them, essentially is this: on 20 February of the year in question Mr Forrester gave the officer reasons for withdrawing him from the post. On 24 February the spouse contacted the Department by phone and by fax to report the alleged harassment which occurred on 14 January, some weeks earlier.

On 25 February the workplace harassment officer first spoke to the spouse about the options available. On 26 February—these are running in separate streams, but the dates run in this sequence—the officer faxed to Mr Forrester a message saying that he agreed with the opinion that he return home, but he did not accept the reasons for the conclusion of his posting. That is an interesting variation on the chronology that Senator Bishop identified before. On 26 February the posting was terminated. On 11 March the officer and his spouse left Bangkok.

It was a conjunction of certain of these events, but the sequence was as I have described. The suggestion that Senator Bishop began with at an earlier stage of this discussion this afternoon, that no reasons were given, was expressly countered by what Mr Forrester said in evidence—or what was certainly said during the course of the Estimates hearing. I am advised again that that was the situation. The officer in question was well aware of the reasons for recall. Of course it had nothing whatsoever to do with the alleged harassment situation as it existed in the post, and of which the Department first became aware only four days after the reasons were given for the recall being imminent.

talk.start.para: —I take it that the bottom line of all the words that the Minister has used is that he intends to do absolutely nothing about the matter; that he is not taking responsibility for the matter; and that 4.8 says that irrespective of whether the person wishes to make a complaint, for whatever reason, there is still a responsibility for the Minister to do something about it. But I take it he is telling us he is going to do nothing. I ask the Minister whether that is right.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Senator Bishop's capacity for dissimulation and outright deception knows no bounds. Paragraph 4.8 is under the heading, `Informal management action' in the section `Informal mechanisms'. It states:

speech.para: Whether or not a victim wishes to make a complaint about an individual, once management becomes aware that there appears to be a problem in a particular work area it has a responsibility to do something about it.

Obviously, in a particular workplace involving tension, ongoing difficulty, complaints and concerns being expressed, in the interests of workplace efficiency and morale, the situation cannot be allowed to continue and something has to be done about it. The particular workplace situation we are talking about was in Bangkok, on 14 January, involving two people, neither of whom are now at that post. One of them is in the UN, the other has come back to Australia and is no longer working for the Department, but she still has the capacity to raise the issue.

talk.start.para: —You fixed that up. She is no longer employed.

—Instead of darting off in another direction when she is shown once again to be mouthing inanities and falsehoods, would Senator Bishop please just focus on the particular bit of deception and dissimulation she tried to perpetrate upon this chamber a few minutes ago. That is the context of 4.8. Obviously, it has nothing to do with any ongoing responsibility of anyone to pursue this matter. That is a separate and distinct issue. That is being dealt with in the way that I have described. I make the judgment that I have responsible senior officers who have handled the matter absolutely by the book until now, and it would be quite inappropriate for me, or any other Minister in this situation, to go careering around seeking to personally intervene to take the matter forward when it is not even clear that the woman in question wants to take the matter forward. That is the way the matter is being handled. I make no apology for it whatsoever.
—Just so we understand, I understand that the Minister is saying that he is not going to do anything about it. That is it, is it?

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I paused in case the Minister wanted to reply to Senator Bishop, but I do not think he is going to. The affair of Mr Burke and his breach of regulations concerning the purchase of cars has been a long and unsatisfactory matter. I am sure that the Minister would not come in here today and say otherwise.

para.tab: The matter was unsatisfactory in a number of ways. Firstly, it was unsatisfactory in that in the Estimates Committee on 4 September 1991 the officers and the Minister said that no breach of the regulations had occurred. It was only as a result of our continuing to press the matter that it was then further investigated almost a year later at the Estimates Committee. We immediately found out that Mr Burke had breached the regulations, and that was acknowledged by the Minister and by the Department. That was unsatisfactory. If the matter had not been pressed, we would have been left with the statement of the Minister of 4 September 1991 that `No breach occurred'.

Secondly, the matter was unsatisfactory in that an officer of the Department clearly misled the Estimates Committee on 4 September 1991. He misled the Estimates Committee when he said that a particular memorandum which set out the obligations upon the Ambassador by the Department `had not been distributed to him'—that is, Mr Burke. The Minister supported his officer in those terms a little later in the Estimates Committee when he agreed that the document had not been distributed to Mr Burke. A year later, Senator Evans says that both he and the Department now accept that the document had been distributed to Mr Burke.

talk.start.para: —No, I didn't.
—I hope the Minister did because it is on the record now—
—The matter in issue was the way in which it came to Mr Burke's attention.

—Here we go again. There is no other way to interpret other than in simple English language that the document was given to Mr Burke. A year ago, the Minister said it was not; he now accepts that it was. There is a separate dispute about whether Mr Burke understood the contents of that document, and the Department apparently decided that Mr Burke did not understand it or did not read the relevant paragraph.

para.tab: The bureaucrat concerned justified misleading the Senate by saying that, in bureaucratese, if that is the expression, he could claim that the document was not distributed because, even though he knew it was given to Mr Burke, Mr Burke had not signed an acknowledgment of that and therefore he could come before the Senate and say it was not distributed to Mr Burke.

On no sensible interpretation can that explanation stand. The facts are that the document was given to Mr Burke and the relevant officer misled the Senate Estimates Committee on 4 September 1991. There was no other interpretation open to the Estimates Committee but to believe that that officer was saying that the document was not given to Mr Burke—in fact, at that time the officer knew that the document had been given to Mr Burke. That is an unsatisfactory aspect of this matter.

I regret that, even though the officer was pressed in the subsequent Estimates Committee a year later, he was not prepared to acknowledge that in those terms but fell back again on trying to develop this argument that, because Mr Burke did not sign the acknowledgment, it was legitimate for him to come into the Parliament, through the Estimates Committee procedure, a year before and put on the record that Mr Burke had not got the document, it had not been distributed to him. That was very unsatisfactory.

I am not suggesting that the officer deliberately misled the Committee, but I am very frustrated by that interpretation. For me not to make the claim that the Committee was deliberately misled is to be very generous in favour of that officer, but I will not press that further except to say that it is another unsatisfactory aspect of this matter.

What worries us particularly is that, in relation to Mr Burke and the pursuit of his breach of regulations, there seems to have been a very different approach by the Department and the Minister to alleged breaches in relation to other people.

talk.start.para: —He's a mate.

—My colleague says, `He's a mate'. That seems to colour the way in which the evidence was put to the parliamentary Committee in September 1991 in terms of this very generous interpretation by the Department that, because Mr Burke did not sign the acknowledgment, it was prepared to find in his favour that he did not read the document and did not understand it, or certainly did not read the relevant paragraph.

para.tab: That is a very helpful interpretation to Mr Burke, and an interpretation that does not seem to be open to anyone else. Everyone else is expected to abide by the regulations, but Mr Burke is excused, even though he had the document, even though he has had all the training and experience of someone who has risen to the office of a State Premier. The Department is prepared to accept that he either did not read the relevant paragraph or did not understand it and, therefore, it should find in his favour that he did not deliberately breach the obligations contained therein. So I find in that instance the approach of the Department very different to other cases.

Then there is the astonishing development in relation to subsequent apparent breaches of the regulations when this matter became public knowledge. The approach of the Department was to send officers to Dublin to regularise the affair. The specific instruction Mr Davin was given before he went off to Ireland was: `if possible to devise a means by which any vehicles purchased by Mr Burke in excess of his entitlements could be regularised'—in other words, `He may be in breach but see if there is a way to sort it out without having to take any further action against Mr Burke'.

In this second way, there seems to be a distinction in the way in which the Department and the Department's Minister went about dealing with Mr Burke and the apparent breaches of the regulations that had come to the attention of the Department and possibly the Minister. Related to that was the overall way in which the Burke case was handled as compared with other cases.

I do not want to mention names here, but I have material on other cases where, in not dissimilar circumstances, the approach of the Department has been to send officers, equipped with notes of authority that give them the right to seize books and papers, et cetera, to gain evidence to prosecute an officer for an alleged breach of these regulations.

But that is a totally different approach to that which was applied in the case of Mr Burke. As I said, the way in which it was applied in the case of Mr Burke was to see if there was a way in which the Department could help him out of this predicament. The background to that is that Mr Burke was a Labor mate. He was somebody who had to be looked after, whereas these other officers do not have the same political connections, and they can be treated differently. I regard that as highly unsatisfactory. All of this has taken 12 months of struggle to get out of the Department.

So the bottom line is that we find that Mr Burke did breach the regulations. But we are now told that no action can be taken against him because he is no longer under the authority of the crown, which is handy for Mr Burke. But that may be the case. Secondly, in relation to those parts that could potentially be regularised so that there would not be further breaches, the Department bent over backwards to help Mr Burke through this difficulty. Thirdly, the Department took an astonishing interpretation of the documents and his knowledge in all the circumstances to the effect that it accepted that he did not know the regulations, even though the regulations had been given to him. Fourthly, as I said at the outset, I also object to the way in which the Senate was misled in the Estimates Committee by an officer who believed that in the terms of the bureaucracy he could come into the Parliament and say that the document was not distributed to Mr Burke, even though he knew that it had been delivered to Mr Burke, because Mr Burke did not sign an acknowledgment of receipt of that document.

So overall—and I guess this matter is coming to a close—it is a highly unsatisfactory affair. I do not think the handling of it is something of which the Department should be proud. I certainly do not think the handling of it is something of which the Minister should be proud. But then again, as we have found in this instance and in a few others—Senator Richardson's Marshall Islands affair comes immediately to mind—if one has a very close link with the Labor Party, if one is a mate, then when one runs into a clash of interest with this Department and this Minister one seems to have an advantage over others who do not have such a close association.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Needless to say, I reject absolutely the allegations of mateship and misjudgment associated with that which began and ended Senator Hill's contribution. I try to do these things with scrupulous fairness and respect for the individuals that are involved. Nobody in my position can sensibly do otherwise. I have not been a Minister for nearly 10 years without being acutely aware of the responsibilities that one has in that respect when it comes to these personnel matters. Be that as it may, the three specific features of the whole affair that Senator Hill chooses to concentrate on today and describe as unsatisfactory require, I guess, some very brief comment from me. I do not propose to give any extended discussion of these things because they have been the subject of exhaustive discussion, I think we would all acknowledge, in Estimates Committee B.

para.tab: As to the business of whether or not a breach occurred, yes it is the case that it was subsequently discovered a very long time after the initial response was given that there had been a brief overlap period—a matter of days or weeks; it is still unclear—right at the beginning of the saga in question at which Mr Burke did hold one more car than he had been given departmental authorisation for or that he was entitled to. That is acknowledged and I do not make anything more of that except to say yes, I accept that that was unsatisfactory, that that was not fully investigated in all respects, as it no doubt should have been at the time, to establish that there was a technical breach of that kind. But it was a breach that was subsequently regularised.

As to the second matter raised by Senator Hill, that the officer in his evidence did mislead the Committee—Senator Hill was kind enough to say that he did not regard it as an exercise in deliberate misleading, but he did say at the outset that the officer misled the Committee in saying that the circular had not been distributed to Mr Burke—I guess it is a matter of how one chooses to deploy words in this situation. The point that we have always tried to make very clear and which has not in any way been countermanded by any evidence that Senator Hill has heard in the Estimates Committee is that the circular was certainly never `distributed' in the way that it should have been through proper briefing of procedure and accompanying signature and documentation to indicate that the person in question had been taken through it and was aware of all its contents.

Secondly, while it was obviously the case—and this has not been contested—that the document in question was given to Mr Burke as an attachment to a memo in response to a particular query from Mr Burke, it has been said over and over again that the context in which that particular exchange took place was a very limited and narrow one in which the officer in question was responding to a very specific request from Mr Burke for advice as to one particular aspect of the car matter, namely, about the extent to which one could hold a car without incurring significant mileage while still being consistent with the letter and spirit of the rules. That was the matter that was highlighted when the document was handed over. That was the matter that was addressed in the accompanying memo.

As we have said on many occasions, that being the context of that particular handing over of the memo in question and that being accompanied by a series of subsequent denials by Mr Burke that he was aware of the basic elements of that memo, it was quite appropriate, I think, for the senior departmental officers to take the position that they consistently have that they could not in conscience make any judgment or determination that Mr Burke was aware of his precise obligations in this respect on the basis of that communication. So that is where I think that matter has to rest. There is nothing being hidden. All the material is on the public record. It is just a question of how one chooses to characterise it. As to the question of different standards being applied to Mr Burke as compared with other people who may have been caught up in similar difficulties in these kinds of disciplinary matters—

talk.start.para: —It was not on the public record in 1991. It had to be brought out by FOI and journalists—
—No, I do not accept that.
—Well, it is fact.
—The matter in issue is different standards being applied.
—How do you think senators were supposed to interpret that—that he hadn't got the document was the only possible interpretation, wasn't it?

—We have been through this and I do not think anything useful is going to be added to the public record by further linguistic exchange on that matter. The context has been clearly described. It has been exhaustively canvassed in Estimates B, and that is where it is.

para.tab: As to differential treatment, all I can say is that in terms of addressing questions about matters such as Mr Burke's state of mind, which Senator Hill has just referred to again, it is always appropriate where the evidence is at best equivocal, which was the case here, for the benefit of the doubt, when it comes to any ascription of potential dishonesty of something of that kind, to be attached to the person in question.

I have been assured and the Committee was assured by the departmental officers that exactly the same benefit of the doubt would have been applied to any individual, any head of mission, any senior officer caught up in a similar situation. I can only express my confidence that I am sure that would be so. Certainly it was not a matter in which I, or any other member of the Government or anyone else with a political role, played any role. It was dealt with strictly and scrupulously as an administrative matter, as these things should be. As to the question of discipline, the difficulty was that by the time this matter came to light Mr Burke had already announced his resignation and even the application—

talk.start.para: —By the time it came to light?

—Well, in May 1991 he had submitted his resignation. The matters that Senator Hill was exercised about, the officer going across to Dublin to deal with the car matter and to achieve a regularisation of the payment by Mr Burke of large amounts of duty that he otherwise may not have, all of that was done after Mr Burke had indicated that he was resigning anyway from the job. So, even had it been appropriate to apply a disciplinary sanction in the form of a dismissal or something of that kind, it would have been manifestly inappropriate to do so.

para.tab: There was no question, however, for reasons I have already indicated, of there being a disciplinary sanction because: first, the matter was regularised, and there was no continuing breach when the matter was resolved in this way; and, secondly, as to the state of mind or the intention, or knowledge, which might have given rise to a disciplinary proceeding notwithstanding a subsequent regularisation, there simply was no conclusive evidence, and the benefit of the doubt had to be given.

What has been shown up as unsatisfactory by this is the absence of an array of disciplinary weapons or sanctions, if you like, available to deal not only with political appointees—heads of mission and that kind of status, so far as their long term association with the Public Service Act is concerned—but also with ordinary members of the Public Service who do assume the status of unattached officers when they go on postings abroad.

We have taken action, as I have previously indicated, to raise with the Public Service Commission this particular anomaly. As a result of that, Senator Hill might be interested to hear, the Public Service Commission has advised that it does think that appropriate amendments are necessary to the Public Service Act and that the Office of Parliamentary Counsel has been instructed to draw those up. Regrettably, time ran out and made it impossible to proceed with that this session. But I certainly hope that there will be some legislation introduced to fix that up so far as Public Service Act people are concerned.

The difficulty in dealing with non-Public Service Act people remains. It has been suggested to us, I am told, by the Public Service Commissioner that perhaps the best way of dealing with that is in future terms and conditions documents there be an explicit sanctions provision of some kind, yet to be determined, built in, giving a contractual right to respond in some appropriate way when these situations arise.

So we are alerted, as a result of these problems, to that hiatus—gap, if you like—in the present legal provisions that are available, and we are doing our best to fix that. That is where this matter, as Senator Hill said, should now rest.

talk.start.para: —Senator, I am glad you actually referred to Mr Burke's appointment as a `political appointment' because, let us face it, that is what it is. I challenge you on the fact that you said that you were not acting any differently towards Mr Burke as a mate. Maybe you would care to tell the Senate why he has been treated so differently all the way along the line. He has had preferential treatment that only a mate could get.

para.tab: There is no other posting that we have been able to discover in all our investigations through the Estimates committees, questions or anything else that has had the type of treatment that Mr Burke has had—with the extra number of trips that he was allowed; the extra number of visits home that he was allowed; the excessive quantity of phone calls that he had; the extra holidays that he had; the extra cars that he had; and, to add to that, the poor management at the Embassy, where every budget allocation at the post in a given year had been overspent. Yet here we have a situation where, as Senator Hill just said, he is treated differently from every single solitary other ambassador, and you think that that is quite acceptable.

Minister, there is no point in saying to us that all of this came to light after he quit. Let us face it: if you had had half a wit about you, you would have cut him loose a lot earlier than saying to him `Come on Brian, baby—jump before I push', because you knew that you were hoisting yourself on your own petard. It was becoming crystal clear to everybody. Everybody in Western Australia knew that. We knew it here. You knew it. And yet you continued to defend a mate. It might be highly honourable to defend one's mates. But when it is at the expense of the Australian taxpayers and our reputation overseas, surely a limit has to be drawn somewhere along the line. Why do you still today continue to defend a man who has led us into disrepute in Ireland, who has not done the job well, and who has been given special treatment? That favoured treatment is just indefensible.

Minister, I ask you whether the Department had provided the Western Australian Inc. Royal Commission with the details of the excessive telephone bills that Mr Burke had, which I know he ultimately—only after parliamentary questioning in here—had to repay a proportion of? Did the Department provide a chronological list of phone calls—not the phone numbers, because I have never been interested in the phone numbers; that is totally and utterly a breach of privacy—or any other list to the WA Inc. Royal Commission? If so, will you also provide that to the Senate, please?

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —I simply do not accept the premise of all that: that there is some systematic pattern of differential treatment being meted out to Mr Burke. Tracking back over a long series of issues that have been dealt with, each of them exhaustively in this place or in the Estimates committee or both—
—But all proving to be correct.

—Well, each individual matter that did have difficulties attached to it, such as the car matter, was addressed and resolved in the way that we have discussed. The perhaps excessive use of telephones and the inappropriate or inadequate procedures that were employed in relation to them, and the rule of thumb percentage rule that was applied, and so on, to the differentiation between official and private calls—all those issues, as they came to light, were addressed. Allegations were made about trips or visits or whatever, but I am not aware of there being any unresolved questions about that. Questions have been raised from time to time, but some visits were specifically authorised in the context of Mr Burke's particular skills as a trade ambassador, as we thought at the time on the available evidence.

para.tab: Other issues arose as a consequence. Mr Burke found himself in a very difficult situation, as I recall, in having to prepare himself for his appearance before the Western Australia Inc. Royal Commission. That made some specific provision for leave, trips to Australia, extended holidays and so on appropriate in those circumstances—which simply had not arisen in any comparable case before, so it is very difficult to compare them.

So I just do not accept that there is any particular pattern that emerges here that requires justification. Everyone is very conscious of the need to be scrupulously strict in applying rules to people who are appointed otherwise than from the Public Service. Those rules have been applied each time to the extent that there are procedural problems that have come to light. To the extent that there are problems about absence of sanctions that have come to light, we are addressing those, as I have said.

The reference that I made to political appointments, which got Senator Knowles a little excited at the outset, is simply a term of art to describe those appointments which are made from time to time by governments. I think we have fewer of them now than at any previous time in living memory that are made of non-career diplomats to postings for good individual reasons in individual cases. I do not resile from that description. It is a convenient one, and it does not carry with it any connotations.

Finally, as to the question of releasing details of telephone calls, on the basis of legal advice, including advice from the Privacy Commission, my Department decided that in relation to the release of telephone logs from the official residence in Dublin, the protection of privacy had to be paramount. That matter, in general terms, has been made clearly on the record. That legal advice was just as applicable in its terms to voluntary release to the Royal Commission as it would have been in its terms to voluntary release to the media or to anyone else. The Privacy Act applies. There has to be some good reason because of the privacy invading potential of this.

It was always open to the Royal Commission to subpoena documents in question had the Royal Commission believed that these documents would have been helpful to it in the pursuit of its inquiries. I say very clearly for the record now that were my Department to receive a subpoena from the Royal Commission, compelling production of the telephone records in question, we would fully comply with our legal obligations. The way the Privacy Act is structured, it is capable of being overridden by a subpoena, a royal commission or a court in that way. But it is not capable of being overridden through a voluntary release purely in response to a less than totally formal subpoena request. That is the reason why that matter has stood where it has.

talk.start.para: —Will you provide the chronological list? I am not interested in the phone numbers.

—Can I get clear what Senator Knowles is asking for. A copy of logs was given to Senators Hill and Knowles. That is with the telephone numbers deleted. What is the problem? What does Senator Knowles want? She said she is not interested in the telephone numbers. She has been given the list without the telephone numbers. It is the existence of the telephone numbers that constitutes the privacy invasion.
—The list does not have the actual dates; it is only groups.

—I think Senator Knowles has the only list we have. I will explore that matter further. If she can indicate with a little more precision what exactly she does not have and she thinks she should have and is available, I will be happy to oblige to the extent I can within the legal constraints available to me.

—Finally, I ask the Minister why there was no monitoring of things such as the phone bills, the extra trips, visits and everything such as that and poor management where, as I said before, every budget allocation had been overspent in a given time? It is wrong, with respect, to suggest that the reason Mr Burke kept on coming back to Australia and going on holidays and everything else was to do with his preparation of his case for the Royal Commission. All of this was happening long before Premier Lawrence had been bludgeoned into announcing the Royal Commission.

para.tab: All of that was going on and on, undetected by the Department. Why would that remain undetected by the Department for so long until most of those issues were raised here in the Parliament or by journalists or by people overseas who knew that Mr Burke was no longer in the post and had extraordinary absences from the post at the time? I make the point that this was out of the ordinary for diplomats and long before the Royal Commission was called.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —It is very difficult for me to respond in any broad brush way without specific allegations about what Senator Knowles is talking about. I have already indicated that there were some earlier matters which caused controversy—a trip to Romania and so on, and the Hancock matter—which were the subject of questions and answers in this place and explanation about a specific authority having been sought and given based on the specific circumstances of the case.

para.tab: I am not aware—that I can recall anyway—of any allegations being made about any systematic questions arising about possible misuse of leave and holiday provisions other than in the context of the Royal Commission. I genuinely cannot recall, nor can my advisers. I suspect that Senator Knowles might possibly be linking those later events back to the Hancock thing and running the two together with nothing much in the middle.

talk.start.para: —His trips to Western Australia were before the Royal Commission was announced.
—Yes, before the Royal Commission started its formal hearings but there were earlier—
—Before it was announced.
—God forbid that we open all this up again, but if Senator Knowles has some specific instances she wants to draw to my attention to correct the record or whatever, I would be happy to receive them.

para.tab: More generally, the Department's philosophy about management has been one so far as possible of devolution to posts, putting responsible people in charge, having periodic audits to see that they are doing the job well, but not trying through a vast clerical apparatus back here to second guess every single transaction, every single leave sheet, every single car registration document or whatever. To do that would produce an impossibly inefficient bureaucratic system. Consistent with good management principles everywhere, we are trying to go down the path of devolution and a lot more authority these days is invested in posts' management systems than previously. The ultimate responsibility for the effectiveness and efficiency of those posts rests with the head of mission at the time, but he obviously has staff people associated with him.

There were some weaknesses that showed up in the financial administration of this post. There are other weaknesses that show up from time to time in other posts of which I become aware and they are dealt with as best as possible within the Department. They do not usually get anyone very excited in here or anywhere else because they do not have the political piquancy of this particular affair, but these things necessarily occur. We deal with them as best we can.

As I indicated to the Estimates Committee, an exercise was set in train quite recently of going across and having a full exploration at a departmental investigation level of how the affairs of the post were conducted through that period and reviewing the performance of the personnel involved. That investigation has showed, essentially, that there were some problems about funds control. In particular, during one period there were some problems about procedures being incompletely exercised. There was no evidence that anyone could discern of any fraudulent behaviour or any mismanagement on a scale that would justify objectively some kind of disciplinary proceeding. But there were some things that went wrong. Basically, the systems had been improved and the performance of the people, some of whom overlapped with people who were there at the time all this happened, had improved under the spotlight and under the pressures that had been put upon them to improve.

Essentially, there were some management failures. I frankly admit them. I have said that in the Estimates Committee but I do not think they were quite as serious as has sometimes been suggested. Certainly—I conclude on this note—they were not the product of any process of benign neglect specifically directed to this post because of Mr Burke's personal history; on the contrary.

talk.start.para: —The Committee will move to program 8. If there are no matters to be raised, that concludes—

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

talk.start.para: —Before we conclude, I said that I would table today the food aid evaluation report as it related to the Sri Lankan program. I do so now.
—How about the other one?
—The Indonesian one is not yet in a condition, I am told, that will be capable of production. But with Mr Kerin overseas and his having to clear it, it will not now be until some time next week.
—And the DIFF one?
—Has it been put back again?
—Just hold your racing hormones, Senator Kemp. Can Senator Hill remind me about the DIFF one?
—The examination of DIFF.

—I said that was subject to considerations of possible commercial confidentiality and intergovernmental confidentiality. I said that about a couple of other things Senator Hill asked for. That was not something I undertook to do in a—
—The National Institute for Economic Research.

—The analysis of the DIFF thing. We are looking at that against the criteria of intergovernmental and, in particular, commercial, confidentiality. I fully acknowledge that it is an appropriate subject matter to go on the public record but I just do not know what is in this particular report. That will have to be looked at.
—Are you still looking at the report of the joint review on the PNG constabulary?
—Yes, that was the same criterion—at least not a commercial one but certainly an intergovernmental one.

—That concludes the Committee's consideration of the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I thank the Minister for his assistance. The Committee will now move to an examination of the estimates of the Department of Finance. As with other departments, I will consider it according to the running sheet. Several matters are listed under program 1, Budget development and management. Are there any matters that require discussion?

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Mr Chairman, one matter that was debated at some length in Estimates Committee B was Supply Bills (Nos 3 and 4). I want to pursue a little further the debate that we had in the Estimates hearings on this matter. The Supply Bills that were introduced—Supply Bills Nos 3 and 4—were, as I think the Government itself agreed, extraordinary Bills. They were introduced without precedent in the sense that they were introduced on the day of presentation of the Budget as distinct from later on. That made those Bills unprecedented.

para.tab: I wonder whether, on reflection of the issues raised during the Committee discussions on this matter, Senator Button can tell the Committee the reasons for that unprecedented action and why the presentation of those Supply Bills could not have been delayed until there was a more demonstrated need for them to be introduced than could possibly be the case on Budget night. Given that there was no knowledge on Budget night of precisely when the Appropriation Bills would be passed, it seems extraordinary, as we pointed out in the Estimates hearings, that the Government would need to introduce a supply Bill at that time. Certainly, Supply Bills have been introduced in Budget sessions, but normally when a more demonstrated need has arisen. I would appreciate any further comments that Senator Button might be able to make on that, given the seemingly extraordinary circumstances.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —There is really nothing to add to what the Committee was told and what it has recorded in its report. It was a timing issue in order to obtain money for the purposes which are referred to in the Committee's report and which were referred to during the Estimates Committee hearings.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I want to press Senator Button a little further on that point. In particular, I would be interested in his view, which again was a matter that was pursued at some length in the Estimates hearing, as to whether the early passage of those Supply Bills meant, in effect, that the Government, if it had chosen to go to an early election during the Budget session, would have had access to about $170m more for spending in advance of the election than would otherwise be the case.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —No, Senator. The motivation was that this money was for employment programs relating to an issue which is constantly raised by people like the senator in the Senate. It was for that reason and no other. There is no question of considering an early election in the course of the decision about these matters.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Can I get it clearer than it seems to me to be at the moment as why to Supply Bills Nos. 3 and 4 were introduced on the night of the Budget when there was no knowledge at that time as to precisely when the money, the subject of the Supply Bills, would be required, nor any precise knowledge of the likely passage date of the Budget or the Appropriation Bills. I know in the Estimates Committee hearings it was said that the normal time for the passage of the Appropriation Bills was towards the end of November and the Government would need the money before that.

para.tab: There is no guarantee that the Bills would have taken more or less time than that average time, and the Government would have had ample time in the course of September or October to have introduced those Supply Bills, if in fact it found that the funds were required. Supply Bills do not require a long passage of time, as we know, and the Opposition has always given them speedy passage when the need has arisen.

Again I think the replies we have had to date as to the necessity for the particular timing of the introduction of these Bills, namely on Budget night itself which is an unprecedented measure, is matter that has not been answered satisfactorily, and certainly not to my satisfaction or to the satisfaction of too many of my colleagues.

I again ask the Minister whether he could be a little more specific as to the reasons for that, given the background that I have just mentioned, in particular the ability the Government would have had to pass the Supply Bill, if it had been introduced later and had required speedy passage.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —If the senator can cast his mind back to the Budget context, it was one in which the predominant concern with the Government and elsewhere was the issue of employment. In terms of local government programs, which these Supply Bills were directly related to in expenditure items, it was determined that we should get on with that issue as quickly as possible.

para.tab: It is as simple as that. The Committee has heard all this and I cannot add anything to it. If the senator wants to believe there is some aberration or plot in it, he will go away believing that, but there was not.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Would the Minister be able to advise the Senate as to how much of the funds that were appropriated in the Supply Bills have actually been expended?

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —No, we cannot do that at the moment. I guess it is a question of hope springing eternal in the human heart, or ours anyway. One always hopes that these matters can be dealt with more quickly than the structure of government in Australia sometimes allows. I guess that was the aspiration. But in so far as the amounts actually expended at this time, I cannot tell Senator Short that at the moment.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I must say I am surprised that the Minister cannot. This was a matter which was the subject of considerable debate in the Estimates Committee. Surely there was an anticipation that this matter would be followed up here in Committee. It was said that the Supply Bills were required urgently, and hence the debate about their introduction, because of the need for those funds in advance of the passage of the Appropriate Bills. Do I take it that the information is not available to the Department, or are there other reasons why that information cannot be given to me now?

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —Essentially, the answer is that there were a range of departments involved and no precise view is available to the Department at the present time.
—No precise information is available to the Department?
—No view is available to the Department at the present time.
—What does that mean? How do you mean `no precise view' is available to the Department ?

—The position is that the provision of those figures would require the Department to consult with some other departments. That information cannot be provided now, but I think I could provide it tomorrow, perhaps at the end of Question Time.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —If we are still dealing with the Department of Finance tomorrow, as we may be if we are abiding by the normal adjournment time tonight, perhaps we could take that up in the morning.
—You can take it up in the morning.
—Does the Minister mean that the information will not be available in the morning?

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —No. All I am saying is that I am giving the senator an undertaking that I will seek to have that information for him by the end of Question Time tomorrow. That is my best offer at this stage. If I can do better I will.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —What I am saying to the Minister is that I think it is important that that information be available before this Committee reports on the appropriations for the Department. If the information is not available before we conclude dealing with the Department of Finance, then I think we would reserve the right at this stage to defer finality of Department of Finance appropriations until that information is available.

para.tab: One of the other matters that was debated during the Estimates Committee hearing was the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The report of the Committee on page 7 had this, amongst other things, to say about it. The report says on page 7 that it was confirmed by the Department that AMF payments to particular States for particular purposes had not been spent on those purposes. The Department further said that this was a practice which it regarded as:

speech.para: . . . not a practice that either the Commonwealth or the States would normally countenance.

Nevertheless, there was evidence that instances had been documented over a number of years where this was the case. I just want to raise this matter again because I consider it a very important matter. I would hope that Senator Button might be able to provide some further information to the Committee about this matter. During the discussions I think I asked for any specific examples where payments to particular States for particular purposes had not been spent on the intended purpose, at least the purpose that had been intended so far as the Commonwealth was concerned. I am not aware that I received any detailed examples following that. Could I just clarify that that is the case?

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —The request before the Estimates Committee, as I understand it, in search of these examples, for purposes of accounting and economic history, was to go back over 20 or 30 years. That required the Department of Finance to obtain information from a range of departments. It has written to all departments seeking that information, but does not have sufficient information at this stage to provide an answer.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I would need to check the record, but I am not sure that I did ask for examples going back 20 or 30 years. I thought it was just over the last five or 10 years. Has the Department been able to obtain any information to date? If so, could it be made available to the Committee?

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —During the Committee hearings, Senator Short said:

speech.para: Could you provide the Committee—and you might need to take it on notice—
as well they might—
with a list of the cases where that has in fact occurred over the last, say, decade.
The Chairman intervened and said:
Let us say 20 or 30 years.

talk.start.para: —Well, I didn't.
—That does not matter. Senator Short is a part of the Committee. We then had this answer from Mr Barrett:

speech.para: We would have to go to the relevant departments concerned to get that information.
Senator Short then said:
That is all right.
Mr Barrett went on to say:
At this time I would just say advisedly that I am not sure what resources this will take up. I assume you are not expecting us to do a large exercise on it.
Senator Short is then quoted as saying:
One would hope that the list is not so long that it would take an undue number of resources.
Mr Barrett said:
No, but it is the investigation, it is not the paper. . .

He was referring to the task upon which they were engaged. So that extract from the transcript of the Estimates Committee, I think, sets the parameters, for want of a better word, in which this investigation had to be conducted. I think it is clear from that that there was some understanding that it would take some time.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I am not suggesting that it would not take some time, of course. I am asking whether any information has as yet been forthcoming in response to this matter. I think this debate took place on 22 September, which is six or seven weeks ago. Has the Department received any response to date that it can communicate to the Committee?
—No. Some departments have replied and there are no examples in their cases, but there is no answer which would satisfy the questions that were directed at the Estimates Committee hearing.
—Did the Department of Finance in its request to departments seek responses by a particular date? If not, when does it expect to be able to provide the information requested?

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —I am advised by the Department that the Department of Finance made an original approach to the departments. There was no response to these questions which was satisfactory from the Department's point of view. The Department has contacted departments again and put a deadline for response of Friday of this week. It has also been advised by the Auditor-General that, to his knowledge, there are no examples of the kind raised at the Estimates Committee.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I do want to spend a little more time on this matter. I accept the point about the timing, but I would hope the Department would take measures to get a response on this matter, with any specific material, to the Committee as quickly as possible, because the matter is of considerable importance. It impinges on a variety of issues going to the heart of the financing of government. It is very relevant to the whole question of the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States because many of the payments we are talking about are to State governments for particular purposes.

para.tab: I have raised many times in the past in this chamber that we have seen special deals done on specific payments to the States which have been, in effect, kept secret from other States and, indeed, have largely escaped the Loan Council and Premiers Conference arrangements. We have had numerous examples of those over recent years. We have had ongoing payments of this nature to South Australia, ostensibly for one purpose, but in fact used for other purposes over each of the last five or six years, from memory, and it is an amount now totalling well over $100m. We have had similar payments to other States. Western Australia is another one that comes particularly to mind.

It is a matter of very serious concern that over recent years the Commonwealth appears to have been turning the Advance to the Minister for Finance into a virtual slush fund for the Commonwealth to make payments to favoured States for anything it likes, with the nature of the transaction, and indeed the very existence of the transaction, not coming into the parliamentary arena for some months at least; in many cases, as a result of the timing of these transactions, avoiding the normal scrutiny processes of the Parliament totally.

Many of the payments to the State governments that have been made under seemingly secret deals around the time of the Premiers Conference each year eventually turn up in obscure tables hidden well into the mass of Budget papers and are almost impossible for the average observer, commentator, and politician for that matter, to dig out.

That is a matter of very considerable concern. Its importance has been highlighted in recent weeks with the breach by the Victorian Government of the Loan Council borrowing guidelines. Although that is not directly related to the Advance to the Minister for Finance, it is a very important example of what I am talking about because, in essence, what I am talking about is the misuse of the Advance to the Minister for Finance in the sense that it is being used in ways that it was never originally intended to be used. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is supposed to be for unforeseen circumstances. In many cases in recent years where payments have been made to State governments through the Advance to the Minister for Finance, in no way could they be described as being characterised by unforeseen circumstances. Of course, the second criterion for the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance is that the circumstances be urgent.

In each of the last five or six years at least, we have seen payments made for deals done around about Premiers Conference time. These deals, using the Advance to the Minister for Finance, have been done not in the full public gaze of that Conference; rather they have been done between the Commonwealth and an individual State or between the Commonwealth and more than one State with no-one knowing about them until they turn up in the relevant Budget paper, No. 4 I think, at the time of the August Budget. It does not normally then get the scrutiny through the Estimates committees or in any other way that is required for most expenditures by the Commonwealth.

As I say, this is a matter I have raised on many occasions, and I think I have had a positive response from the Department of Finance to many of the questions about what I would describe as the misuse of the Advance to the Minister for Finance—certainly, at best, one could say the very loose application of the criteria of `unforeseen and urgent' to requests made for its usage, particularly in terms of payments to individual States. I have been encouraged by the positive responses I have had from the Department accepting many of the points I have made. I hope that the Minister will be able to tell the Senate whether the concerns that I think we have all expressed—certainly I have expressed them—and that the Department has acknowledged in recent years have been dealt with. If the Minister could tell the Senate what further steps have been taken to prevent the misuse of the AMF in the ways that I am referring to, I would find that helpful before going on to any further questions.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —That is a nice little speech which is largely plot rhetoric, if I can call it that. To start by mixing up the Advance to the Minister for Finance with the question of Loan Council borrowings by States illustrates the extent of the plot theory. The criterion is `urgent and unavoidable' in respect of the use of the Advance to the—
—Urgent and unforeseen.

—`Urgent and unforeseen' in terms of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. In spite of all Senator Short has said, I am advised that over the last few years there has been no different pattern of the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance from that in any other period. The same criteria have been applied and there is no different pattern of use that can be pointed to.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —That is precisely my concern; that is precisely the point on which I asked the Minister to comment. We have had this debate several times over recent years. My understanding of that debate, particularly in Estimates Committee and particularly from the responses from the Department of Finance, is that the Department of Finance has accepted the validity of many of the points that I have raised over recent years about the `looseness' at best in the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I am aware that the pattern has probably not changed much over recent years, but what I am saying to the Minister is that the pattern should have changed; there should be a much tighter application of those criteria, particularly in so far as they relate to payments to State governments. What I am asking of the Minister and seeking information on is whether in fact there has been any action taken to tighten up the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, so that the ways in which it has been abused so regularly in recent years do not continue.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —The officials instructing me do not agree with the view Senator Short has just expressed. If Senator Short has gained some particular warmth or comfort from answers that have been given to him—and I think he used an expression something like that earlier—then I do not think it is there. As I am advised, the recent applications have not fallen into the category of `looseness', which I think was the way Senator Short described them. The criteria have been met and the pattern of use has been the same as it has been in the past.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I wonder whether the Minister would care to comment on my understanding that, in each of at least the last five years, arrangements have been made at around the time of the Premiers Conference, which is normally held in June, for deals with individual States—and over the last five years those States have included New South Wales, Tasmania, South Australia, Western Australia and I think Victoria—for a deal between the Prime Minister or Treasurer of the day and the Premier of the particular State for a payment for a particular purpose for which subsequently the Advance to the Minister for Finance was used and which then eventually turns up, I think, in Budget Paper No. 4. For those payments the criterion of `urgent and unforeseen' is used, despite the fact that invariably there is no discernible urgent nature about the payment and certainly no unforeseen nature, given that for most of them it has been a regular pattern from one year to the next to make a payment for this particular purpose using the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

para.tab: I believe that there is no way in which such regular annual payments using the Advance to the Minister for Finance can possibly be regarded as unforeseen. Indeed, it would appear that it has been known for up to 12 months in advance that that was going to be the way in which the Advance was used. It is that matter that concerns me very considerably. It is on that matter I believe that the Department of Finance publicly expressed in the Estimates committee some sympathy with the views and the concerns that I have expressed. If nothing has been put in train to attempt to change that practice and that type of use of the AMF, then I put to the Minister: will the Department look at a much tighter use of the AMF using those criteria? If it is not the case that we will look at it more tightly, what we are really admitting is that the Government will continue to use the AMF as a slush fund to enable it to make payments and special deals with its mates in individual States to suit the whim of the governments of the day without proper parliamentary scrutiny.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —Senator Short keeps coming back to the question of whether there is sympathy with his view. The answer to that question is no, there is no sympathy over here with his view. In the view of the Department, the payments met the criteria necessary for the use of the funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, in relation to urgency, where a competent authority has approved payments in each case, and also in relation to the question of unforeseen circumstances. However, that does not preclude the Department from taking note of Senator Short's invitation to continually keep an eye on this matter and see whether the mechanisms can be improved or might need to be improved at any given time.

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —Am I correct in my understanding—and I am afraid I do not have particular reference here, but I might seek advice from the Department—that during the discussions at the Estimates hearings on 22 September, the Department of Finance did say that the arrangements to which I am referring do undermine accountability and proper program evaluation? It was not just in relation to the payments to State Governments. It also related to the matter—about which I have asked the Department to provide information—of whether payments have been made for one purpose but used for others. I am quite certain the Department agreed with the proposition that these arrangements did undermine accountability and proper program evaluation. I would relate that, in the same way, to the discussions we have just been having because I think it is part of the same discussion. I ask the Minister: if that is the case, what is going to be done to improve accountability and proper program evaluation?

speech.speaker: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

talker.name: Senator BUTTON
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

talk.start.para: —I understand Senator Short wanting to make it part of the same discussion. Senator Short referred to the discussion on 22 September. Senator Short's question to Mr Barrett is important to record. It reads:

speech.para: So does that mean it is possible that moneys which ostensibly are payments to a State, or anywhere else for that matter, that ostensibly are to be used for a particular purpose, could in fact finish up not being used for that purpose?
Mr Barrett replied:
I think there are cases documented over a number of years where moneys that have been appropriated to the States for particular purposes seem to have been used for other purposes.
I think that is common knowledge to everybody here. He goes on:

I think that is well accepted, but it is clearly not a practice that either the Commonwealth or States would normally countenance. In essence, the whole nature of the accountability and responsibility is to ensure that the moneys appropriated for the particular programs are spent on these purposes. That would be the basis on which any subsequent evaluation or assessment of how well that program had performed would be based.

I do not know whether Senator Short can construe that as sympathy. Mr Barrett is saying that, over a number of years, there have been instances where payments to the States have not always been used for the purposes specified. That seems to be quite common knowledge.

para.tab: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

para.tab: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to regulate certain video material.

tab.tab: That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Aulich Sen T.G.

talk.start.para:
