—Tonight I want to raise one particular issue in response to a visit by Mr Robert Corbin, the President of the National Rifle Association of the United States, to this country. Mr Corbin was interviewed on the ABC's
PM
program on Monday, 9 November 1992. I find it a fascinating and slightly frightening interview.

para.tab:
Before I actually look at some of the issues that Mr Corbin raised, I would like to quote from a brochure which has just come to hand today. It is a quote, in fact, from
Playboy
magazine which relates to Dr Alfred Kinsey and his position as a world authority—or supposed world authority—on sexuality. As all those people who read about these matters know, Dr Judith Riesman has recently exploded a number of the myths and has exposed some of the inherent bias and fraudulent methods, as she puts it, used in Kinsey's research.

The net result of Dr Riesman's exploration of this particular issue has been that magazines like
Playboy
—dedicated primarily I guess to the propagation of a fairly sexist male viewpoint about the world—have been put in a situation of some difficulty. For example,
Playboy
stated in October 1988 that Riesman's research `puts men's magazines on the endangered species list'.

Here is a quote from
Playboy
which in many ways summarises some of the problems that I believe people like Mr Robert Corbin want to export to Australia. This comes from someone who is very annoyed indeed about the effect of Dr Judith Riesman's views about sexuality. It says:

speech.para: I would have taken a .357 magnum, walked up to her and said, `Judith, you are history'.
That was in March 1991. It is a very interesting, and some say slightly American, view of how to oppose those people who disagree with you.

talk.start.para: —Who said that?

—One of the commentators in
Playboy
. It is interesting that, of all the things you do, you do not argue a particular case with someone; you threaten to walk up to them with a .357 magnum and make them history.
—Like Jeff Kennett.

—You can be history, or you can make history. In his interview, Mr Corbin brought home to many of us the essential differences that have so far existed between the Australian view towards guns and what seems to be now the quintessential American view about the use of firearms and the value they have to individuals and their families.

para.tab: Mr Corbin does not just represent some nut organisation. Mr Corbin, as President of the National Rifle Association, represents an organisation that has 2.4 million paid up members. It has an annual budget, according to the congressional lobbying records, of $US88m. I will indicate in a minute what Mr Corbin thinks about the effect he and his organisation have on politicians and their views about, for example, guns.

Mr Corbin has been invited here by many Australian shooting organisations. Obviously, as he has indicated, he is here to discuss the gun issue. He has indicated that he is here to give advice not only to the shooting lobby but also to a significant number of politicians, as he puts it, in discreet private meetings, about the way they should deal with the gun issue.

Mr Corbin does not pretend to be someone who gives advice about the most intelligent way to have gun control legislation. In fact, Mr Corbin boasts that he is a partisan person who represents a partisan organisation that has, as one of its major aims, the right of Americans to bear arms. We are not talking about the eighteenth century when the American Constitution was written; we are talking about the twentieth century when most Americans live in an urbanised or suburbanised society where guns are not exactly necessary to defend them against bears, hostile Indians or other dangers of the frontier.

In this interview, Mr Corbin indicated quite clearly that the National Rifle Association, as a lobby group, has taken on politicians in the United States and, as he puts it, `we have unseated many of them'. He said:

speech.para: We are a very powerful organisation in the United States. We are feared by many people. Just as in this most recent election we believe we have elected a pro-gun House of Representatives and a pro-gun Senate. The United States A rated people.
If you are pro-gun, you are A rated; presumably, if you are not pro-gun, you are some lesser species that should not be elected to the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: —They have a national capital which has the highest murder rate in the world.
—Exactly, and I will come to some of those figures in a minute. Why was Mr Corbin here? As he puts it:

speech.para: I was invited over here to tell the people who invited me just how we do it in the United States. Our institute for legislative action. How we go about lobbying. How we conduct ourselves. Like, we send out to every candidate, from whether you are running for President all the way down to a constable in a precinct of a county, questionnaires asking how they stand on the gun issue. Then, in many cases, we are not that wealthy that we can go all over the United States—
although, $US88m is not bad wealth—
in every race, we just don't have that kind of money, but we do pick key races where we think we have an opportunity to win.
The interviewer says:
You say guns don't kill people, people kill people.
He said:
That's correct.
Mind you, what he did not was quote his predecessor, the President of the NRA, who said:
All guns are good guns. There are no bad guns. I say the whole nation should be an armed nation. Period.
Thus spake NRA President, Joe Fossey in 1991.

para.tab: I understand that there are many people in this country who need guns for various reasons. Obviously, there are more of them in the Northern Territory, Queensland, outback New South Wales and, for some weird and unaccountable reason, Tasmania. Tasmania seems to have an incredible per capita ownership of guns. As we all know, Tasmania registers only pistols and all the rest are unregistered. At one time, Tasmania was seriously considering setting up a manufacturing industry to make semi-automatic and automatic machine-guns. Then again, that was Tasmania in the time of Robin Gray.

It is very interesting that Mr Corbin is coming here to tell the gun lobby how it ought to start to influence the Australian legislatures. He will be talking about how to raise funds, how to pressure members of parliament, and how to ensure that an organisation at least appears to be an organisation which has the capacity to knock off uncooperative members of parliament. It would be very nice to know that all of us, as members of parliament, can come into this chamber and believe that there is no single interest group out there which can make a decision about our career—one group, and one group only. After all, we do represent a wide spectrum of constituents, we hope, rather than a particular powerful interest group.

That is the first point I raise tonight. The real issue is not whether some crazy American, part of a wealthy lobbying group in the United States, is coming here to teach our gun lobby how to do it—how to influence us; it is whether we believe that single issue lobby groups should utterly take control of the destiny of members of parliament in this place and in other legislatures.

talk.start.para: —What about the ACTU?

—I understand what Senator Brownhill is saying, and that he is trying to indicate that the ACTU is one individual powerful lobby group. It does not compare with the gun lobby, Right to Life, et cetera. Even to raise that issue is, in many ways, to belittle the problem that we have in Australia now. We are at the crossroads for the way that we as a society, and we as legislators, determine what happens with the guns in this community.

para.tab: I will look at some of the figures that relate to the gun lobby. In Australia there is already a disturbing increase in the ownership of guns. For example, 3.5 million guns of all types now exist in Australia. In 1979 there was one gun for every five or six people. In Australia it is now one in four. More than one-quarter of all Australian households possess a gun. More than one-third of all murders reported to police are committed with firearms. Gunshot wounds are the most common cause of death amongst homicide victims.

As we all know, and it is commonsense, the death rate for victims assaulted with guns is several times that of those assaulted with other weapons. In other words, if there is a domestic argument in a house and there is a gun available, if there is ammunition in the house and it is loaded, it is more likely to be used, and it is more likely to be used in a lethal fashion than any other instrument of assault whether it be an axe, a tomahawk or whatever else is around the place. That is statistically the case. The police forces and various institutes of criminality agree that those figures are perfectly supportable.

The figures of the Australian Bankers Association reveal striking increases in the number of armed hold-ups in banks. For example, in Queensland in 1980 there were eight armed hold-ups of private banks. Seven years later, in 1987, the figure had risen to 45. I accept that recession may affect the way people behave and the desperation in which they act, but the fact that in Queensland alone armed hold-ups increased from eight to 45 is an indication of the trend.

The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training recently met with about 40 street kids in Perth. Senator Panizza might be interested in this. There were three young people in that group to whom we were talking who had already been convicted of armed hold-ups at least once and some more than once. They were young people aged from 24 down. To look at some of them, butter would not have melted in their mouths, but in that group there were young people who, because of access to guns and because of their desperation in these harsh economic times, have been prepared to involve themselves in armed hold-ups.

All of us know that various types of murders occur with guns in this country. They occur with lunatics such as Wade Frankum just blasting people away in shopping centres because something happened to his girlfriend or whatever. There are various reasons for that. There are others who get involved in domestic arguments where they simply take the most lethal weapon they can find readily to hand and blast their partner or their children away. There are others who, out of desperation, plan hold-ups and believe that is the way they can pay for a heroin habit or, for that matter, make enough money to survive.

How many people now have we seen who have been killed in cold blood, by accident or in desperation in shops simply because they resisted someone who might have got away with a couple of hundred dollars? A person's life has gone for a couple of hundred dollars because some desperate young kid has managed to get hold of a gun. That is what the banks say.

Between 1968 and 1971, almost 6,000 Australians took their own lives by using guns or explosives. The police are asked to undertake horrible jobs in all sorts of places, from picking people up off roads and going to the family and saying, `I am sorry, your son'—or daughter, or husband—`has been wiped out on the highway', to all the other jobs they have to do. What is the position of the police now? Many of them are under real threat, and the figures show it. Between 1976 and 1985, nearly all of the 65 murders of on-duty Australian police officers were committed through the use of firearms or bombs. Sixty-five policemen on duty in nine years were knocked off by guns or bombs. They are the people who are protecting us. They have a rotten job to do. They were on-duty policemen. The figures do not include those who were off duty.

The point I make on behalf of a number of legislators in this community, State and Federal, is that I am heartily fed up with the gun lobby and with gutless Ministers, at the State level in particular, who will not stand up to the gun lobby and say that enough is enough. For example, some say that the Labor Party lost under Barrie Unsworth because it stood up on the gun issue. They will not stand up in a bipartisan way and say, `Look, this is not an issue for one political party to use to triumph over another in certain electorates'. But there are some who will stand up and say, `The community is fed up with the availability of guns in this community, particularly semi-automatic weapons'.

It is bad enough that half the videos that our kids see are full of violence and, I believe, are genuine encouragement in some cases for the feeble-minded and the immature to actually go and commit violence if guns are available. The key is the availability of those sorts of weapons.

Some States have started to move, and they have started to move because the political scandal of them doing nothing after these massacres has forced them to move. But we are now starting to lose our momentum. The press, who work on a 7 1/2-day week basis in terms of the capacity for issues to stay alive, has forgotten all about it. So have many of the Ministers around this country.

I am saying two things tonight. The first is that the legislators in this country will have to start to show more courage, perspicacity, intelligence and a greater capacity to discuss this issue right down to the wire, at which time we will have to ask what sort of a society we want. Do we or do we not want a society that relies on guns to solve arguments, which sees the gun as a method of proving a person's manhood?

Secondly, I want to get a message through to Mr Corbin. Mr Corbin has not shown himself to be particularly tolerant of alternative viewpoints in the US. It simply knocks off people on single issues whenever it suits it, regardless of that legislator's ability or otherwise. I say to Mr Corbin: `You have blood on your hands. Get out of this country as quickly as possible. Cease your private meetings with individual members of parliament. We do not want you here. We do not want to be like the United States with all its problems with gun laws. It is about time you went back to America'.

That is my message tonight. I can assure Mr Corbin that I speak on behalf of a significant part of the Australian community, including my own electorate in Tasmania, who are fed up, first, with the gutlessness of politicians on this question and, secondly, with someone from America with its failed record on violence in the community coming here and telling us how we ought to be running our legislatures in the matter of gun control.

talk.start.para:
—I had not even thought to speak on the adjournment debate tonight, but while I was in my office I heard Senator Aulich speaking about the National Rifle Association of the United States and its visitor to Australia—I did read about this visitor—and I decided to come down to the chamber and put my own piece on the matter into
Hansard
.

para.tab: If Senator Aulich is leaving the chamber, one message I would like to get across to him before he goes is the difference in definition between a gun and a rifle. If he did any military training, he would know that there is a rather coarse way of getting someone to remember, but I will tell him about that privately.

talk.start.para: —It is highly academic to a person who has a bullet in him.

—Yes, but there is a difference. I must disclose my interest here. I am a Vice-Patron of the National Rifle Association of Australia and Vice-Patron of the West Australian Rifle Association. I do not know what the National Rifle Association of the United States stands for—I plead total ignorance on that—but the reason I am speaking here tonight is to make sure that Senator Aulich and anyone else who may be listening knows what the National Rifle Association of Australia stands for.
—We are not saying you are reactionary. Registered gun clubs are not a problem.

—I listened to Senator Aulich. If he does not want to listen to me, that is up to him, but I gave him a fair go and I would expect the same. I know what the National Rifle Association of Australia stands for. In Australia, despite the efforts of the present Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), the NRA of Australia is still under the auspices of the Department of Defence. There were attempts in 1987, when I first came to this place, to remove it from the Department of Defence, but it is still there. The policy of the coalition is to keep the NRA of Australia under the auspices of the Department of Defence.

para.tab: The National Rifle Association of Australia in its competitions uses only rifles; it does not use guns. They are full-bore, centre-fire and generally single-shot. Magazine type rifles were used up to about 10 or 15 years ago. I have had extensive experience in competition and rifle shooting. We used to leave the magazine out because it used to add weight. The weight is cut down and is a safety angle. Only one bullet is used at a time as the target is marked. All that is used is a full-bore, centre-fire with no magazine. As I said before, there is a distinction between a rifle and a gun.

On behalf of the National Rifle Association of Australia, I want to say that no massacre has ever occurred in Australia at the hands of a member of a club under the auspices of the National Rifle Association of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I am glad to hear that.
—Senator Collins can laugh as much as he likes.
—I said that I was glad to hear that.

—Well, if you are glad to hear it, then what were you laughing about? I am very happy that you are glad to hear it. I just did not know what you were laughing at. But the point is that no member of the National Rifle Association or any rifle association of any State in Australia has ever been involved in a massacre. Nor has there been a weapon belonging to one of those members used in a massacre in Australia. That is definite. Further to that, it is almost impossible to carry out a massacre with a single shot rifle—because it is only a single shot anyhow, and, hopefully, if someone were to use one of those, someone would mow him or her down before there was a chance to put a second slug in.

para.tab:
The competitive shooters of Australia that are under the auspices of the National Rifle Association are very good, honest, upright sporting citizens. I know that Senator Aulich did not reflect on the National Rifle Association of Australia or its members, but as that fellow who came from America is mentioned in
Hansard
—I do not even remember his name, and I am not very interested—I want to put it in context that the National Rifle Association of Australia stands for something far different from what, as Senator Aulich pointed out, the Rifle Association of America stands for. It is far different.

I am still a member of a rifle club. We are not politically motivated as a rifle group. All the NRA wants to do is to keep the use of those military ranges. The NRA uses the military ranges and the military uses the odd private rifle ranges. In fact, there is a private range in Melbourne that is used by the military. The NRA and the military have a good relationship. Their members are honest, upright persons who are there for competition and nothing else, and some members have won gold medals at the Olympics.

I do not want to hold the Senate up any further tonight. I just wanted the opportunity to put the position of the NRA of Australia in case it has been confused with any points that Senator Aulich might have made about the National Rifle Association of the United States.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 May 1991:

para.tab:
With reference to
The Energy Guide
booklet, distributed to every Australian household, which is described as `brought to you by the Australian Government and the Australian Consumers' Association', would the Minister advise:

(1) Whether the promotional television campaign publicising the distribution of the booklet would be prohibited as `prescribed material' under the Government's proposed broadcast ban legislation; if not, why not.
(2) Whether the publication prior to an election of a booklet `brought to you by the Australian Government' would be affected by any other legislation.
(3) Whether there are any guidelines controlling the use of taxpayers' funds for direct mail promotions and/or print advertising, either during an election period or otherwise.

(4) How incumbent governments would be prevented from abusing their access to print media and direct mail promotional facilities, given that these will assume much more importance if political broadcasts are banned.

talk.start.para: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: Part IIID of the Broadcasting Act 1942, which included a ban on election period political advertising including advertising which included `prescribed material' as therein defined has been held by the High Court to be invalid. The proscription of advertising including `prescribed material' is therefore inoperative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 May 1991:

para.tab:
With reference to the experience during the 1987 Federal election campaign, when the most-watched current affairs program in Australia,
60 Minutes
, proposed that its election-eve broadcast should feature only the Prime Minister, whilst excluding the Leader of the Opposition from the program:

(1) Would a broadcast such as that originally proposed by
60 Minutes
, which would give unbalanced coverage by featuring exclusively the candidate of one party, be regarded as a `political advertisement' under the definition contained in the `Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill'.
(2) Would there be any opportunity for aggrieved parties or individuals to obtain equal time, whether free or not, under the proposed legislation.

(3) Can the Minister confirm that under the proposed legislation, as noted by Michelle Grattan in
The Age
on 19 March 1991, if a party thinks the media coverage is biased, it will have no way of putting its views on the electronic media independently of news and current affairs programs.

talk.start.para: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: Part IIID of the Broadcasting Act 1942 has been held by the High Court to be invalid. The prohibition on political advertising, along with the free political broadcasts time provided for by that part are therefore inoperative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 29 May 1991:

para.tab: Can the Minister advise of any countries, other than Albania, China, Haiti, Iran, Iraq, North Korea, Syria or Yemen, that ban political advertising without allowing `free time' for political parties to present their views directly to the electorate.

talk.start.para: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: Part IIID of the Broadcasting Act 1942, which was inserted in that Act by the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991, provided for an election period ban on political advertising and freetime for candidates. This system operates in most western democracies in one form or another. According to the Report of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosure, Canada, the United Kingdom, France, Denmark, Japan, Israel, Austria and Ireland all prohibit or restrict election period advertising and provide freetime for candidates.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 3 June 1992:

para.tab: (1) Does the Liberal Party receive any funds from the advertised 0055 number, which is said to provide `more fightback information'.
(2) Would any such funds received have to be declared under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918; if so, would the name and address of each and every caller have to be declared by the Liberal Party.

(3) If the name and address of each and every caller could not be ascertained, would each such call be considered to be an anonymous donation; if so, would it be legal under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

talk.start.para: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) I am not in a position to advise whether the Liberal Party receives any funds from the advertised 0055 number.

(2) Any amounts received after 30 June 1992 must be included in the Annual Return required to be lodged with the Australian Electoral Commission within 20 weeks after 30 June 1993. Only the names and addresses of those who provide amounts of $1500 or more in total to a Party during the financial year must be disclosed.

(3) The question of whether anonymous donations may have been paid does not arise in this instance—as any funds received by the Liberal Party from its 0055 service would be amounts received 1) from The Company providing the Telephone Information Service and 2) not as donations but as money received for services provided.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 August 1992:

para.tab:
With reference to statements by Professor Allan Fels that the Trade Practices Commission has accepted that the closure of the Brisbane
Sun
and
Sunday Sun
newspapers were due to their failure to make a profit, that the Commission reached this conclusion after conducting extensive informal inquiries and that no further action would be taken:

(1) On what basis did the Commission reach the conclusion that the newspaper industry and the community in general were wrong in their belief that the ultimate financial beneficial control of these two newspapers was by Rupert Murdoch's News Limited Group.
(2) What credence can be given to informal inquiries and what access was the Commission given to financial records of Sun newspapers, News Limited or its associates.
(3) Was the Commission refused access to any such records.
(4) Who was interviewed by the Commission during these latest informal inquiries.

(5) What evidence did the Commission find to refute a strong belief by many people in the Brisbane newspaper industry that both the
Sun
and
Sunday Sun
newspapers were deliberately run into the ground.

(6) If the Commission accepts the claim that the
Sunday Sun
was not financially viable, how does it explain the fact that Brisbane now has a flourishing market for three Sunday newspapers and is being targeted by a fourth Sunday newspaper from the Gold Coast.

(7) If the Commission had decided the
Sun
and
Sunday Sun
could have been run at a profit, what powers does the Commission have to take action.

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has been advised by the Trade Practices Commission that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) The Commission reported at length on the relationship between News Limited and the independent papers in 1989. The report concluded that the management of the independent papers controlled their day to day operations free of any News Limited influence.
(2) The Commission was granted access to all financial information it requested.

(4) The Commission contacted the former management of the
Sun
and the
Sunday Sun.
The Commission also contacted News Ltd and Citibank concerning financing and supply arrangements.

(5) Market inquiries showed that the papers closed primarily because of falling circulation, falling advertising revenue and mounting losses. In the absence of evidence that there has been conduct in breach of the Trade Practices Act, the Commission does not make assessments about commercial decisions.
(6) While it is true that there are three weekend newspapers available in Brisbane, the Commission notes that the new entrants are basically southern papers and not Brisbane ones.

(7) The Commission's role is to enforce the Trade Practices Act. It can take companies to Court for anti-competitive behaviour if it considers that there is evidence of a contravention of the Act. It cannot order companies to act in the most competitive manner and, in particular, it cannot force companies to continue in a market when it is not viable for them to do so in the commercial judgment of those companies.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 14 October 1992:

para.tab: (1) Why did taxation form such a minor part of the Minister's agenda in New Zealand during the review of the Closer Economic Agreement.

(2) At a time when many barriers to the free flow of trade between our two countries have been eliminated, why does the Government still countenance the imposition of a double tax burden on trans-Tasman companies thereby causing a major disincentive to new investment.
(3) Why is there an absence of reciprocal crediting of company tax under each country's dividend imputation scheme and withholding tax on fully franked corporate profits.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) Taxation was on the agenda agreed by the Australian and New Zealand Governments for the 1992 Review of the Australia—New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (CER), in acknowledgment of the importance the business community attached to trans-Tasman taxation issues. In the course of the 1992 CER Review, a great deal of valuable preparatory work was completed. Australian and New Zealand officials held a series of intensive discussions on trans-Tasman tax issues, including those identified by the two business communities; a joint paper that canvassed in considerable depth trans-Tasman aspects of taxation of equity was prepared; and model Double Taxation Agreements were exchanged.

Formal negotiations to put in place possible new trans-Tasman taxation arrangements did not, however, commence in the 1992 CER Review time-frame. The reasons for this were explained to the business community in the Joint Media Statement on the 1992 CER Review, released by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr John Kerin, and the NZ Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Philip Burdon, on 7 October 1992.

Both Governments recognised that aspects of the tax arrangements being discussed were unprecedented and would have wide-ranging implications, including in relation to fiscal sovereignty, revenue and broader international tax policy objectives. In view of these considerations, it was acknowledged that further steps could not be taken until both Governments had conducted the careful and thorough analysis necessary to decide the best outcome.

It would be remiss of the Australian Government to make any precipitate decision on trans-Tasman taxation issues or enter into negotiations without first carefully weighing up all the potential costs and benefits to Australia of any new trans-Tasman tax arrangements.

(2 and 3) Trans-Tasman taxation arrangements are governed by the existing Australia-New Zealand Double Taxation Agreement (DTA). The DTA eliminates most instances of international double taxation (which occurs where the same income of the same taxpayer is taxed by the two countries).

Economic double taxation of dividends, first in the hands of companies and then in the hands of shareholders, has been identified by the Australian and NZ business communities as a disincentive to trans-Tasman investment. Such double taxation occurred domestically in both countries until the introduction of domestic dividend imputation systems and was, therefore, previously not an issue in the trans-Tasman context.

By conscious design, neither countries' imputation system allows credit against residents' personal tax liabilities for company tax paid in the other country (or any other country) as they do for domestic tax. In Australia's case, the cost of providing imputation credits for NZ taxes would include:

answer.para: the direct revenue costs that would be involved;
possible indirect revenue costs in the form of reduced source country taxation that could arise if it led to a substantial net movement of capital from Australia to New Zealand;
potential revenue losses resulting from possible opening up of tax avoidance avenues;
the possibility of treaty shopping (setting up a business in Australia or New Zealand to take advantage of tax concessions) by third country enterprises;
reduction in national economic welfare if there were a diversion of Australian investment abroad from third countries to New Zealand in response to changed taxation arrangements; and
possible inability to quarantine any arrangements to New Zealand.

para.tab: In addressing the business community's interest in reducing possible double taxation of income distributed to shareholders from trans-Tasman equity investments, it is necessary to weigh these potentially serious risks and costs against possible benefits. This assessment is still in progress.

Fully franked dividends are not subject to Australian dividend withholding tax. New Zealand does, however, levy a withholding tax on fully franked dividends. This is an issue of concern to the Australian business community. It has been discussed as part of the preparatory work on trans-Tasman taxation issues done in the context of the 1992 CER Review and remains a matter Australia will want to address.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 13 October 1992:

para.tab: (1) Is the Minister aware that the new pharmaceutical arrangements, where the chemist must view the health card of low income earners before the pharmaceutical goods are dispatched without payment or for low payment, are causing extreme payment problems for chemists located in country towns dispatching scripts to outlying remote country patients.

(2) Could a system similar to the one which has been introduced for the outback Aboriginal communities be instituted that will allow the chemist to accept the script if he/she has viewed the card and its number previously in these situations.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The new arrangements whereby pharmacists must view an entitlement card to confirm that a person has an entitlement to free or concessional prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, are not, to my knowledge, causing payment problems for chemists located in country towns who service remote areas.

(2) The Health Insurance Commission, which administers the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, has advised pharmacists who are in remote areas and who do not see patients on a regular basis, to contact the Commission for special assistance in correctly identifying their patients' pharmaceutical benefits entitlement numbers. Such arrangements are already in place for some pharmacists who supply outback Aboriginal communities. These arrangements ensure that the pharmacist has a correct record of a patient's entitlement. Where a pharmacist is satisfied that a patient continues to be eligible for medication at a free or concessional rate, the pharmacist need not sight an entitlement card on all occasions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 November 1992:

para.tab:
With reference to the situation described by the `Japanese Citizens Concerned about Plutonium' in its advertisement in the
Australian
of 5 November 1992 `Can Australia Stop the Death Ship?'
(1) Can the Government explain why it has not protested to Japan about the planned plutonium shipments.
(2) If the route of the shipments is near Australia, will the Government be advised by Japan if the ship enters the Australian Fishing Zone.
(3) Would the Government provide emergency assistance if requested by the ship and would it allow the ship to enter an Australian port.
(4) Has the Government made any contingency arrangements to respond to any emergency near Australia involving the shipments.
(5) Will Australian uranium be involved in the first or subsequent shipments.

answer.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) The Government appreciates the genuine concern in Australia and in the international community about the plutonium shipments and considers that ensuring their safety and security must be the paramount objective. The Government does not accept, however, a number of the advertisement's claims about the safety of the shipments which are technically unsubstantiated and unsustainable.

Strict international guidelines on safety and physical protection measures for plutonium transportation are in place, having been developed over many years, including by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). They include stringent testing to ensure the integrity of the casks in which plutonium is transported.

The Government has conducted an intensive examination of all aspects of the planned shipments to ensure that any implications for Australia could be fully considered. Australian and Japanese officials have discussed the security and safety arrangements for the shipments in the course of regular consultations under the 1982 Agreement between Australia and Japan for Cooperation in the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy. Australia has also discussed the arrangements with the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and with the United States, which has an agreement with Japan on physical protection and safety arrangements for the shipments. Under that agreement, the United States has approved the transportation plan for the shipments. Japan has also provided publicly information on arrangements for the shipments, including information on the construction and equipment of the transport ship and its escort vessel.

As I said in my answer of 16 September to a question without notice in the Senate (Senate
Hansard
pp 961, 962), on the basis of all these exchanges and careful examination of all the issues, the Government has satisfied itself that the physical protection and safety arrangements for the shipments meet or exceed international standards for the transport of plutonium.

In regard to the advertisement's criticism of Japan's planned plutonium use, as I said in the Senate on 15 September in answer to a question without notice (Senate
Hansard
pp 864, 865), the Government would not support the stockpiling of plutonium by Japan or any other non-nuclear weapon state. In this context, the Government accepts Japan's clear and frequent statements that, as a fundamental principle, it will not possess plutonium in excess of the amount required for its nuclear power program.

Japan is almost totally reliant on imported fuel for power production and has pursued nuclear fuel reprocessing as one way of enhancing its energy independence. The plutonium shipped from Europe will be used on an ongoing basis in Japan's nuclear fuel recycling program. All nuclear facilities in Japan are subject to continuing intensive IAEA safeguards and the Government has no reason to doubt Japan's commitment to the use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes only, in accordance with its obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

In all of these circumstances, a Government protest to Japan would not be appropriate. The Government will, however, continue to take the closest possible continuing interest in all aspects of the issue and in particular in the question of safety and security of the shipment.
(2) Australia does not know the route and does not expect the Japanese Government will depart from its clearly stated intention for security reasons not to advise other countries of the route.

Japan is not under any international legal obligation to advise Australia of entry of the plutonium ship into the 200 nautical mile Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ). The ship is entitled under international law to transit the AFZ and other countries' 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ). However, Japan has said that, in principle, the ships will not be routed through countries' EEZs.

(3) If emergency circumstances were to arise in the course of a shipment and Japan requested Australia's assistance, the Australian Government would consider such a request in accordance with the international law applicable to ships in distress.

In the case of assistance to the ships at sea, under the 1982 Law of the Sea Convention, which is generally regarded as declaratory of customary international law in this respect, assistance would be required to the extent that it could be given without serious danger to rescue personnel and equipment.

In the case of port access, under the customary international law relating to the sovereignty of coastal states and also under the 1923 Geneva Convention on the International Regime of Maritime Ports, to which both Australia and Japan are parties, it would be within the discretion of the Australian Government to determine on a non-discriminatory basis whether port access would be granted. Port access is normally granted to ships in distress but safety would be a paramount consideration in deciding whether to grant access to the plutonium ship.

(4) Appropriate arrangements, involving a number of Government Departments and Agencies, including the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre, are in place to coordinate an Australian response to maritime emergencies, including any emergency involving the plutonium ship. Such arrangements would be activated promptly if an emergency arose.

answer.para: Australia has a capacity to assist ships in distress but the exact nature of the response would depend on the nature of the emergency.

para.tab: (5) Australian-obligated plutonium is not involved in the first shipment. Australia is, however, a significant supplier of uranium to the Japanese nuclear fuel cycle and, under the 1982 Australia and Japan nuclear cooperation agreement, Australian-obligated nuclear material may be reprocessed, subject to stringent safeguards and physical protection requirements specified in the agreement. A proportion of the plutonium returned to Japan over time will therefore have an Australian safeguards obligation.

Any such material will always be subject to an Australian bilateral safeguards agreement. While in the jurisdiction of Japan, it is subject to the 1982 nuclear cooperation agreement between Australia and Japan.

While in France, the material is subject to the nuclear safeguards agreements between Australia and France and Australia and EURATOM. Those agreements provide strict controls to ensure that all Australian-obligated nuclear material (including plutonium) is used exclusively for peaceful, non-explosive purposes, is fully accounted for, and is subject to internationally agreed levels of physical protection.
